questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with longstanding epigastric pain, bloating, anorexia, and acid reflux. He has a past history of peptic ulcer disease which was treated with pantoprazole. An upper endoscopy is done and a biopsy of his gastric mucosa is shown below. What is the next step in his management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with longstanding epigastric pain, bloating, anorexia, and acid reflux and has a past medical history of peptic ulcer disease. The given histopathology slide shows lymphoepithelial lesions suggestive of a gastric MALToma. This suggests that the patient has had chronic gastritis, and the most common cause of chronic unremitting gastritis is an underlying untreated Helicobacter pylori infection. The next step in his management would be to prescribe antibiotics to treat an underlying Helicobacter pylori infection as this bacteria has been strongly implicated in the causation of gastric MALTomas. 

H. pylori eradication therapy leads to loss of the inflammatory stimulus which is responsible for causing the recruitment of lymphocytes to the gastric epithelium. Thus patients with chronic gastritis with known peptic ulcer disease are presumed to have been colonised by H. pylori and require treatment with antibiotics. This also helps in tumor staging, as, if the patient does not respond to antibiotics, it is indicative of a higher grade of MALToma which would require more aggressive management. 

Extranodal marginal B-cell lymphomas usually arise at the sites of chronic inflammation. Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) is not present in the normal stomach but can be induced, typically as a result of chronic gastritis. H. pylori infection is the most common inducing factor of MALT and is often found in association with MALTomas. The presenting complaints are similar to adenocarcinoma and include abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and anorexia.

Histologically, MALTomas show dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the lamina propria. The neoplastic lymphocytes infiltrate gastric glands to create lymphoepithelial lesions. MALTomas express B-cell markers like CD19 and CD20, but not CD5 or CD10. 25% of the cases are positive for CD43. Eradication of H. pylori with antibiotics has shown to be an effective therapy for MALToma. Surgical resection has no role in the treatment unless there has been some complication like perforation or uncontrollable bleeding. Chemotherapy is indicated only if the patient does not respond to antibiotic therapy. 

Related Pearl: Types Of Gastric Ulcers

This is the classification given in Harrisons 20th ed, Principles of Internal Medicine.

          Type II                 Antrum    Low to Normal Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI

questions.text: A mother of a 1-month-old infant is concerned about her baby's slow weight gain. The baby is exclusively breastfed and otherwise healthy. What is the most likely explanation in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the slow weight gain in an exclusively breastfed and otherwise healthy infant is most likely due to insufficient feeding, i.e., insufficient intake of the hind milk.

While breastfeeding, the mother should allow the complete emptying of one breast before switching over to the other. It is because the baby needs both foremilk and hindmilk for optimum growth. 

Foremilk is the one that is secreted during the initial feed. It is watery and quenches the thirst of the baby. It is rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water. Hindmilk is rich in fat and provides energy. It gives a sense of satiety to the baby. Hindmilk comes towards the end of the feed. 

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

  • Colostrum is secreted in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains a large number of antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 
  • Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.
  • Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the optimum growth of the baby as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.
  • A mother who delivers before 37 weeks secretes preterm milk that contains proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobulin, and calories as needed by the preterm infant.

The given image shows watery foremilk (left) and hindmilk which is rich in fat (right).

Other options:

Option A: Lactose intolerance can present in newborn infants with severe osmotic diarrhea at the commencement of breastfeeding. However, primary lactose intolerance rarely manifests in children below 5 years of age.

Option C: Foremilk is secreted initially during breastfeeding. So even in short sessions of breastfeeding, foremilk intake is adequately met.

Option D: Milk protein allergy is generally associated with cow's milk. The child here is exclusively breastfed; hence, milk protein allergy is unlikely.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male patient was hospitalized with pneumonia and started on cephalosporin. After a few days of therapy, the patient develops easy bruisability and hematuria. Lab investigations show elevated PT and aPTT. Which of the following cephalosporins was administered?

PT- prothrombin time
aPTT- activated partial thromboplastin time
questions.solution:
The cephalosporin administered would be Cefoperazone.

The elevated prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) indicate a deficiency of the common clotting pathway factors (I, II, V, or X).

Cephalosporins that contain a methylthiotetrazole (NMTT) group can cause hypoprothrombinemia (factor II) and thereby bleeding problems. This is because NMTT cephalosporins inhibit the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase in the liver, which is the key enzyme for vitamin K-dependent carboxylation, a posttranslational modification that is essential for the biological functions of coagulation factors. 
NMTT group containing cephalosporins includes cefamandole, cefmetazole, cefotetan, and cefoperazone.

Vitamin K epoxide reductase is also the target of anticoagulants like warfarin. Oral administration of vitamin K can prevent this problem.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the emergency department with right hemiplegia following a cerebrovascular accident. Cranial nerve examination reveals deviation of the tongue to the paralyzed side on protrusion. Identify the cranial nerve affected in this patient.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with right-sided hemiplegia and tongue deviation to the paralyzed side on protrusion is suggestive of hypoglossal nerve injury. In the given image, the nerve labeled as '3' is the hypoglossal nerve.

The hypoglossal nerve (XII cranial nerve) supplies the muscles of the tongue. It leaves the cranial cavity through the hypoglossal canal (anterior condylar canal). It supplies 3 extrinsic muscles (all excluding palatoglossus) and all 4 intrinsic muscles of the tongue.

​​The hypoglossal nerve is tested clinically by asking the patient to protrude tongue. Normally, the tongue protrudes straight forward. If the nerve is paralyzed, the tongue deviates to the paralyzed side.

The image below shows location the cranial nerves in relation to the brainstem:


Other options:

Option A: The oculomotor nerve is a purely motor nerve arising from two nuclei: the main motor nucleus and the accessory parasympathetic nucleus. The main nucleus lies at the level of the superior colliculus of the midbrain. The accessory parasympathetic nucleus (Edinger-Westphal nucleus) is situated posterior to the main nucleus. 

Option B: Facial Nerve arises from the brainstem at the pontomedullary junction. The facial colliculus is present on the floor of the fourth ventricle at the level of the lower pontine tegmentum. This colliculus contains the abducens nerve nucleus and the fibers of the facial nerve, which form the internal genu as they travel around the abducens nerve nucleus.

Option D: The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) arises from the substance of pons and is responsible for sensory input from the face, as well as motor functions such as chewing. Its sensory pathway involves three branches: the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) divisions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman has come for the prenatal karyotyping procedure shown below. What is the best time to perform this procedure?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is chorionic villus sampling (CVS). The best time to perform chorionic villus sampling is 11–13 weeks.

Chorionic villus sampling:
Study material: Chorionic villi from trophoblastic cells of chorion frondosum
Time: 10 to 13 weeks (transcervically), 10 weeks to term (transabdominally)

Indications

  • To detect chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome.
  • To detect inborn errors of metabolism like phenylketonuria.
  • For DNA analysis in hemoglobinopathies, thalassemia, and sickle cell anemia.

Complications: abortion (CVS> Amniocentesis), limb reduction defects and oro-mandibular defects (when done before 10 weeks)

Drawback: not suitable for the detection of neural tube defects.

Below is an image showing the procedure of amniocentesis vs chorionic villus sampling.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with a two-year history of progressive autonomic dysfunction, including orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence, and erectile dysfunction, along with signs of parkinsonism. MRI of the brain shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely additional feature to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Positive family history of a similar condition
Presence of tau protein in glial cytoplasmic inclusions

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of progressive autonomic dysfunction, parkinsonism, and the MRI finding of the 'hot cross bun sign' is indicative of Multiple System Atrophy (MSA). It is a type of atypical Parkinson's disease (Parkinson's plus syndrome) as there is more symmetric motor involvement than Parkinson's disease. 

It is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by autonomic dysfunction, parkinsonism, and cerebellar symptoms. The "hot cross bun" sign on MRI is a characteristic finding associated with MSA, particularly the cerebellar subtype (MSA-C), and is caused by degeneration of pontocerebellar tracts. The histological hallmark of MSA is the presence of cytoplasmic inclusions containing alpha-synuclein.

Other options:

Option A: Positive family history of a similar condition - MSA is typically sporadic and not usually associated with a positive family history, unlike some hereditary ataxias or familial Parkinson's disease.

Option C: Presence of tau protein in glial cytoplasmic inclusions - MSA is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein in glial cytoplasmic inclusions, not tau protein. Tau protein inclusions are more commonly associated with other neurodegenerative disorders, such as progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) and corticobasal degeneration (CBD).

Option D:  Significant improvement with levodopa - Patients with MSA generally do not have significant or sustained improvement with levodopa, which helps differentiate MSA from Parkinson's disease, where levodopa is typically effective.

  • Poor response to levodopa

questions.text: Biopsy from the thyroid gland from a patient suffering from cold intolerance, weight gain and hair loss shows diffuse infiltration of lymphocytes and lymphoid follicles. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopic features of Hashimoto thyroiditis include intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centers. Cold intolerance, weight gain and hair loss indicates hypothyroidism which supports the diagnosis. 

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in women between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase. 

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well-demarcated from the adjacent structures. 

Clinical features of Hashimoto's thyroiditis are as follows:

  • More common in women (10 to 20 times)
  • Diffusely enlarged, painless, lobulated gland
  • Patients usually present with hypothyroidism (due to alteration in thyroid function by infiltration of lymphocytes and resultant fibrosis)
  • Hashitoxicosis: initial transient phase of thyrotoxicosis

Microscopic features include: 

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centers 
  • Atrophic thyroid follicles  
  • Hurthle cells: Epithelial cells lining the follicles containing eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. They represent the metaplastic response of the normally low cuboidal follicular epithelium to chronic injury.

Other options: 

Option B: Graves disease classically presents as hyperthyroidism and heat intolerance.  

Option C: DeQuervain thyroiditis or granulomatous thyroiditis is characterized by aggregates of lymphocytes, activated macrophages, plasma cells and multinucleate giant cells.  

Option D: Riedel thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by extensive fibrosis of the thyroid gland and adjacent structures.

questions.text: A forensic psychiatrist is evaluating a patient who shows a pronounced sexual arousal for partners with tattoos, piercings, and other forms of body modifications. This preference is referred to as?
questions.solution:
Stigmatophilia is a paraphilia characterized by a strong preference or sexual arousal from partners with body modifications such as tattoos, piercings, scars, or other marks. 

Other examples of Sexual paraphilia include

  • Piquerism: involves sexual arousal from stabbing or cutting the skin of another person (option A)
  • Hebephilia: involves a sexual preference for early adolescent children (option C)
  • Troilism: involves sexual arousal from watching one's partner engage in sexual activity with another person (option D)
  • Eonism/Transvestism: Sexual gratification is achieved by wearing the dress of the opposite sex.
  • Fetishism: Gets sexual gratification by merely seeing or feeling female body parts, certain articles belonging to a woman, such as a sari, footwear, stockings, undergarments, hankies, hairpins, etc.
  • Masochism: Sexual gratification is obtained by being tortured by the sex partner. (opposite of Sadism)
  • Sadism: Sexual gratification is achieved by inducing pain in the sex partner.
  • Voyeurism/Peeping Tom or Scotophilia: Sexual gratification by secretly watching others getting undressed, taking a bath, performing sexual intercourse, etc.
  • Nymphomaniac: A type of perversion of excessive sexual desire in a woman
  • Satyriasis: Excessive sexual desire, arousal, and drive in men.
  • Frotteurism: Gets sexual gratification by pressing/rubbing his genital part through the dresses worn, against the body parts of a female in front of him.
  • Undinism: Gets sexual gratification by watching the act of passing urine or defecating by a woman

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic liver disease has been admitted with alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Which of the following benzodiazepines is not suitable for the management of an acute episode of seizure?
questions.solution:
Diazepam is not preferred for the management of an acute episode of seizure in a patient with alcohol withdrawal syndrome and liver disease. 

Diazepam is contraindicated in liver disease because it is extensively metabolized by the liver. An impaired hepatic function can lead to reduced clearance and accumulation of the drug and its active metabolites, increasing the risk of prolonged sedation, respiratory depression, and other adverse effects. Additionally, patients with liver disease may already have altered mental status and respiratory function, which can be exacerbated by diazepam.

Benzodiazepines safe for liver disease include: LETO

Lorazepam
Estaszolam
Temazepam
Oxazepam

Alcohol withdrawal is one of the most common causes of seizures in adults. The major objective of drug therapy in the alcohol withdrawal period is the prevention of seizures, delirium, and arrhythmias.

In patients without any liver disease, Specific drug treatment for detoxification involves two basic principles:

1) Substituting a long-acting sedative-hypnotic drug for alcohol 
2) Gradually tapering the dose of the long-acting medicine.

Because of their wide margin of safety, benzodiazepines are preferred. Long-acting benzodiazepines, including chlordiazepoxide and diazepam, have the advantage of requiring less frequent dosing. Since their pharmacologically active metabolites are eliminated slowly, the long-acting drugs provide a built-in tapering effect. A disadvantage of long-acting medicines is that they and their active metabolites may accumulate, especially in patients with compromised liver function.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient newly diagnosed with hypertension expresses confusion about his condition. The medical officer invited him to a health education session scheduled for 10-15 minutes, with fewer than 30 attendees. During this session, he used visual aids such as diagrams and illustrations to help the patient understand his diagnosis and management better. Which health communication method is used in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
The health communication method is used in the above scenario is chalk and talk approach, commonly known as lectures.

Lectures in health communication fall under the category of group approaches, typically involving gatherings of up to 30 individuals and lasting between 15 to 20 minutes. It is usually combined with audio-visual aids to make the sessions more effective like: 

  • Flipcharts
  • Flannelgraph
  • Exhibits
  • Films and charts

The disadvantages of this approach are : 

  • Students involved to a minimum extent
  • Learning is passive
  • Health behaviour not necessarily affected

Methods of Health Communication:

  • Individual approach like home visits and personal letter
  • Group approach
    • Lectures/Chalk and talk
    • Demonstrations
    • Discussion methods
    • Group discussions
      • Panel discussion
      • Symposium
      • Workshop
      • Conferences
      • Seminars
      • Roleplay
  • Mass approach like TV, radio, posters, exhibitions, etc.

Other options :

Option A: Group Discussion:  It is a form of communication where multiple individuals come together to exchange ideas, discuss a topic, solve problems, or make decisions, considered very effective in health communication. The group usually includes 6-12 members seated in a circle, to clearly see each other.

Option C: Demonstration:  A method of teaching or presenting information where actions, processes, or techniques are shown to an audience to illustrate how something works or how to perform a task or a procedure. 

Option D: Symposium: It consists of series of speeches on a selected subjected presented by an expert, where the audience may raise questions, but no discussion among the members takes place.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with atrial fibrillation is administered esmolol for rate control. Which of the following characteristics best describes esmolol?
questions.solution:
Esmolol is a beta-1-selective blocker and belongs to the class II antiarrhythmics. It is used for rapid rate control in conditions such as supraventricular arrhythmias, arrhythmias associated with thyrotoxicosis, perioperative hypertension, and myocardial ischemia in acutely ill patients.

Beta-1 selective beta blockers, also known as cardio-selective beta blockers, preferentially block the beta-1 adrenergic receptors primarily located in the heart. By selectively targeting the heart, they reduce heart rate, decrease cardiac output, and lower blood pressure, thereby reducing myocardial oxygen demand and improving symptoms and outcomes in cardiovascular diseases

Additionally selectivity makes them particularly useful in treating cardiovascular conditions with a lower risk of causing bronchoconstriction and is thus favored in conditions such as asthma or COPD due to their reduced likelihood of exacerbating these conditions.

Examples include atenolol, metoprolol, bisoprolol, and nebivolol.

Related Pearl: Cardioselective beta blockers: Mnemonic

Cardioselective Beta blockers Act At Nothing But Myocardium Exclusively.

  • C: Celiprolol ( III )
  • B: Bisoprolol
  • A: Acebutolol
  • A: Atenolol
  • N: Nebivolol ( III )
  • B: Betaxolol ( III )
  • M: Metoprolol
  • E: Esmolol

( III ) - Third generation beta blockers. All the others are second generation beta blockers

questions.text: A histologist is studying the structure of lymphoid tissue. The below finding is seen in which of the following lymphoid tissues?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows Hassall's corpuscles; these are seen in the thymus. These are small rounded structures present in the medulla of the thymus. They have a central core of degenerated epithelial cells that stain pink. Around this is a circle of epithelial cells that stain pink with hematoxylin and eosin stains. The function of these corpuscles is not clearly understood.

Histology of thymus

The thymus is a lymphoid tissue that is arranged in the form of lobules. The lobules are separated from each other by connective tissue. 

Each lobule is made up of an outer darker staining cortex and an inner pale-staining medulla. The medulla contains pink rounded masses called Hassell's corpuscles.

Structure of a lymph node

Each lymph node is bean-shaped. The concave part consists of the hilum, through which the blood vessels enter and leave the node. Microscopy shows the following features:

Each lymph node is surrounded by a thin capsule. Below the capsule is the clear space, which is called the subcapsular sinus. 

The lymph node contains the outer cortex and an inner medulla. The cortex consists of densely packed lymphocytes and therefore stains dark. Numerous follicles can be seen in the cortex. Each nodule has a pale-staining germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. The medulla consists of lymphocytes arranged in the form of anastomosing cords. It appears pale. Numerous blood vessels can be seen in this area.

The image below shows the histology of the lymph node:

Structure of spleen (Option A)

The spleen is the largest lymphoid organ of the body.

Microscopic features of the spleen:

It is surrounded by a thick capsule. This capsule extends into the organ forming trabeculae. The substance of the spleen consists of red pulp and white pulp. In red pulp, the lymphocytes are diffusely distributed and contain numerous sinusoids. In white pulp, the lymphocytes are densely packed and arranged in the form of cords around the arterioles.

When cut transversely, the cords are similar to the nodules in the lymph nodes. They have a pale germinal center surrounded by a ring of densely packed lymphocytes. However, there is an eccentrically placed arteriole within the germinal center.

The image below shows the spleen: WP- white pulp, RP- Red pulp, CR- central arteriole.

Structure of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (Options B and C)

The aggregations are in the form of lymphatic follicles. Germinal centers may be present. Between the nodules, there is diffuse lymphoid tissue, which is called a parafollicular zone. The nodules predominantly consist of B lymphocytes with T lymphocytes in the diffuse areas.

They lie close to the epithelium. They are not surrounded by a capsule and also do not have connective tissue septa. They have a supporting network of reticular fibers. Examples are palatine tonsils, Peyer's patches, and lymphoid nodules in the vermiform appendix.

The image below shows Peyer's patches.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child is brought to the clinic with a common cold and the parents give a  history of stridor, dyspnea, and intercostal retractions shortly after birth. On examination, you notice that he has biphasic stridor.   What is the most probable etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
The finding of biphasic stridor in this scenario is highly suggestive of congenital subglottic stenosis.

Subglottic stenosis is a congenital or acquired condition characterized by a narrowing of the upper airway extending from just below the vocal folds to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. 

Congenital subglottic stenosis is the most common cause of biphasic stridor in children. The subglottis is the narrowest part of the upper airway in a child. The symptoms of congenital subglottic stenosis usually present shortly after birth and include biphasic stridor, dyspnea, and suprasternal, intercostal, and diaphragmatic retractions. In this child, edema, and secretions caused by the common cold further narrow the subglottic region, leading to the symptoms.  Abnormal cry, aphonia, or hoarseness occur when the vocal cords are affected. In acquired subglottic stenosis, there is a history of laryngeal insult or prior intubation and symptoms appear 3-4 weeks after the same.

Diagnosis is made by airway radiographs and confirmed by direct laryngoscopy. The percentage of stenosis is determined and graded using the Myer Cotton system from grades I through grade IV, indicating the severity.

Management includes dilatation and endoscopic laser surgery for grades 1 and 2 subglottic stenosis, and laryngotracheal reconstruction with cartilage graft augmentation in grades III and IV subglottic stenosis. Mitomycin C is used in the management of subglottic stenosis post-operatively, in order to prevent re-stenosis.

Other options:

Option A- Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital anomaly causing stridor in a child. which typically presents with low-pitched, inspiratory stridor which is exacerbated by crying and agitation.

Option C- Croup is caused by the parainfluenza virus, and typically presents with symptoms of fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness of voice. In severe cases, the child might develop respiratory distress with hypoxia and cyanosis.

Option D- Bilateral vocal cord paralysis can also cause stridor in infants and children. Congenital central nervous system lesions such as Chiari malformations and myelomeningoceles can cause bilateral vocal cord paralysis which leads to respiratory distress, high-pitched inspiratory stridor, and a weak cry. 

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

X-ray neck shows steeple sign

questions.text: A 23-year-old female with a travel history to Egypt a few weeks back presents with hematuria. Urine microscopy revealed the following structure. What is the characteristic feature of hematuria in this condition?

choices.text: Hematuria at the beginning of micturition
Presence of vermiform shaped clots in urine
Hematuria at the end of micturition
Presence of cuboid shaped clots in urine

questions.solution:
The egg of Schistosoma haematobium is seen in this patient's urine microscopy characterized by a typical terminal spine. Patients infected with Schistosoma haematobium characteristically have terminal hematuria i.e. hematuria seen during the end of micturition.

The classic presentation of patients infected with Schistosoma is described as painful terminal hematuria. (According to Comprehensive Clinical Nephrology, 6th Ed). The prevalence of hematuria ranges from microscopic to gross. Ulcers undergo a healing process including fibrosis, resulting in the formation of calcified granulomas beneath the atrophic and contaminated mucosa. This leads to the distinctive cystoscopic manifestation of sandy patches, as well as the radiological manifestation of linear bladder calcifications. 

Schistosoma haematobium is characterized by ovoid non-operculated eggs with a brownish-yellow transparent shell and a characteristic terminal spine at one of the poles.

Schistosoma haematobium primarily causes genito-urinary schistosomiasis. The adult worms live in the veins of the urinary bladder.

Cercaria larva are the infective form of schistosomes. Cercaria infects man by penetrating the skin which can lead to intense irritation and skin rash at the site of cercarial penetration (known as swimmer's itch).

After penetrating the skin, the cercariae lose their tails and become schistosomulae which travel through peripheral venules to the systemic circulation, to the inferior mesenteric veins, finally reaching the vesical and pelvic venous plexuses, where they mature and lay eggs. The eggs that are passed in urine are embryonated and hatch in water under suitable conditions to release the free-living ciliated miracidia.

Miracidia penetrates the tissues of the snail and reaches its liver. Inside the snail, first and second-generation sporocyst stages are seen. Large numbers of cercariae are produced by asexual reproduction within the second-generation sporocysts and are released into the water. Metacercaria and redia stages are not seen in schistosomes.

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis.

Other options:

Option A: Hematuria at the beginning of micturition also known as initial hematuria is seen in patients with bleeding from a possible prostatic or urethral source.

Option B: The presence of vermiform clots in the urine suggests hematuria from the upper urinary tract. 

Option D: The presence of cuboid-shaped clots in urine suggests hematuria from the bladder. Patients with Schistosomiasis have classical painful terminal hematuria instead.

  • Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni

questions.text:
A 48-year-old working in the ship repair industry presents with a gradually progressive cough and difficulty breathing. Chest X-ray shows multiple linear opacities in both lower lungs. Investigations reveal diffuse interstitial fibrosis. Which of the following will be seen in this patient's pulmonary function tests?

DLCO: Diffusion capacity of lung for carbon monoxide
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 48-year-old patient working in the ship repair industry with linear opacities on chest X-ray and diffuse interstitial fibrosis is asbestosis. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern; hence, decreased DLCO will be seen.

Asbestosis results in diffuse interstitial fibrosis leading to restrictive lung disease. Findings of pulmonary function testing:

  • Decreased total lung capacity (TLC), vital capacity (VC), and residual volume (RV) due to diffuse fibrosis
  • In restrictive diseases, both FEV1 (Forced expiratory volume in the first second) and FVC (forced vital capacity) are reduced but FEV1/FVC ratio is normal or even increased as FVC is reduced to a greater degree due to decreased compliance.
  • An FEV1/FVC ratio > 0.7 signifies restrictive lung disorder, whereas <0.7 is seen in obstructive diseases.
  • Damage to the pulmonary capillaries due to fibrosis causes a decrease in diffusing capacity, resulting in reduced DLCO.
  • Flow volume loop in restrictive diseases shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy developed bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen produced green colonies on Hektoen enteric (HE) agar and pink coloured colonies on DCA. What is the mechanism of action of exotoxin produced by this bacteria?
questions.solution:
The bacteria implicated here is Shigella and the mechanism of action of exotoxin produced by it is inhibition of 60S ribosome.

Shigella is one of the causes of bacillary dysentery. It produces an exotoxin also known as Shiga toxin or verotoxin. The mechanism of action is almost similar to Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). It consists of two subunits A and B. The B subunit binds to globotriaosylceramide receptors on the target cell and then the A subunit gets internalized. The A subunit leads to inhibition of 60S ribosome, leading to shut down of protein synthesis.

Shigella can be cultured from stool samples on the following media:-

  • Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA), Xylose lysine deoxycholate (XLD) agar:- pale or pink colonies without H2S production (Salmonella produces H2S)
  • Salmonella Shigella(SS) agar:- colourless colonies
  • Hektoen enteric (HE) agar:- produces green colonies

questions.text: In a study investigating the impact of a dietary intervention on cholesterol levels, researchers enrolled 300 participants. After 3 months, the mean reduction in LDL cholesterol was found to be 20 mg/dL with a standard error  of 2 mg/dL. What is the 95% confidence interval for the mean reduction in LDL cholesterol?
questions.solution:
The 95% confidence interval (CI) for the mean reduction in LDL cholesterol in the given scenario is 16-24 mg/dL . 

The 95% CI is calculated as: 

95% CI = Sample mean (x̄) ± 2 × standard error. 

Here, (x̄) = 20 mg/dL

           standard error = 2 mg/dL.

Therefore, the confidence limits are 16-24 mg/dL .

Related Pearl: Confidence Limits and Interval

Confidence limits are the upper and lower limits of standard errors within which a parameter value is expected to lie.

Generally, 95% confidence limits are used and they are approximately equal to the sample mean plus or minus two standard errors, i.e., 95% confidence limits = Sample mean (x̄) ± 2 standard errors.

The general formula is confidence limits = x̄ ± zσ x̄. 

  • Where z is 3 for 99.7% Cl
  • z is 2 for 95% Cl
  • z is 1 for 68% Cl

The difference between upper and lower confidence limits is called the confidence interval. Since the standard error will decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size, the width of the confidence interval will also decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size.

questions.text: A young man presented to the emergency after he injured his arm in a road traffic accident. He was bleeding profusely from his brachial artery. Which of the following suture materials would you use for the repair of the artery?
questions.solution:
Nonabsorbable monofilament suture material like Polypropylene is ideal to repair the brachial artery. 

The vascular anastomosis requires an accurate and watertight closure. Hence it requires a non-absorbable material that can provide tensile strength for a longer period. In addition to this, the material should also be non-braided to avoid platelet adherence to the suture material. Hence, polypropylene which is a non-absorbable monofilament is used for vascular anastomoses.

Important suture materials used in the clinical practice are:

  • Polyglactin (Vicryl)- This is an absorbable suture material and is commonly used in gut anastomoses, biliary anastomoses, and kidney and ureter surgeries.
  • Polygylcaprone (Monocryl)- This is an absorbable suture material and is used in the subcuticular suturing in the skin
  • Silk- It is a naturally available, non-absorbable suture material. It is used in skin, two-layer bowel anastomosis, and in securing the external drains.
  • Nylon- It is a non-absorbable suture material. It is used in abdominal wall mass closure, hernia repair, and neurosurgery.
  • Polydioxanone - Absorbable suture material with a longer wound support period. 

Silk, a non-absorbable material of biological origin, will fragment with time and lose its strength, and hence should never be used in vascular anastomoses for fear of late fistula formation.

questions.text: What is the molar ratio of glucose to sodium in WHO low osmolality ORS and the rationale of this depends on which of the following transporter?
questions.solution:
The molar ratio of glucose to sodium in WHO low osmolality ORS is 1:1. The rationale behind this is based on the sodium and glucose cotransporter 1(SGLT-1).

In most cases of acute diarrhea, sodium, and chloride are actively secreted from the gut mucosa. However, the glucose-dependent sodium pump remains intact and functional transporting one molecule of glucose and dragging along a molecule of sodium and one water molecule across intestinal mucosa resulting in repletion of sodium and water losses. The glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption is the principle behind replacing glucose and sodium in a 1:1 molar ratio in the WHO oral rehydration solution (ORS).

The low-osmolality World Health Organization (WHO) oral rehydration solution (ORS) is now the global standard of care in the management of acute gastroenteritis. Oral rehydration is the preferred mode of rehydration and replacement of ongoing losses except for those with severe dehydration that might necessitate intravenous resuscitation. The osmolarity of low osmolarity ORS is 245mosm/L.

Other options:

SGLT-2 is present in the kidney

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical changes is not seen in a chronic alcoholic patient?

choices.text: Increased amount of pyruvate is converted to lactate

questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic alcoholism, there is an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio. As a result, several metabolic adaptations occur:

Within the cellular cytoplasm, elevated levels of NADH favor the transformation of pyruvate into lactate, which can lead to lactic acidosis. The resulting lack of pyruvate leads to insufficient production of oxaloacetate. This insufficiency, in turn, suppresses the process of gluconeogenesis and can cause hypoglycemia.

Diminished oxaloacetate, reduced pyruvate, and an abundance of NADH can inhibit the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle. This inhibition leads to an accumulation of Acetyl CoA, promoting ketogenesis. The heightened presence of acetyl CoA leads to an increase in fatty acid synthesis. However, the fatty acid is not broken down, leading to fat buildup in the liver, known as fatty liver or steatosis.

Alcohol consumption can further exacerbate these conditions by promoting the release of Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS). This can cause damage to the mitochondria and induce cell death, or apoptosis.

Lactic acidosis also affects the excretion of uric acid and can lead to an acute attack of gout. Additionally, alcohol inhibits certain excitatory receptors, such as N-methyl aspartate receptors, and enhances the effect of inhibitory neurotransmitters like GABA receptors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old cattle breeder presents with fever and joint pains. Lab investigations revealed pancytopenia and a positive standard agglutination test. Which of the following drugs are used for the management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a cattle breeder presenting with fever, joint pains, and pancytopenia with a positive agglutination test favors the diagnosis of brucellosis. Drugs used in the treatment of this condition are rifampin and doxycycline. 

Doxycycline, combined with rifampin given for 6 weeks is a usually given regimen recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO). Another regimen involves a combination of streptomycin and doxycycline. Combination therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ) can be used if tetracyclines are contraindicated.

Brucellosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Brucella species, typically contracted through direct contact with infected animals or consumption of unpasteurized dairy products. The clinical presentation includes undulating fever, musculoskeletal symptoms like arthritis and myalgia, general malaise, hepatosplenomegaly, neurological symptoms in neuro brucellosis, presenting as meningitis or encephalitis. In men, epididymal-orchitis can occur, presenting as testicular pain and swelling.

Diagnostic methods include:

1. Blood Cultures: - Isolation of Brucella species from blood cultures is definitive but challenging due to its slow-growing nature. Cultures typically need to be incubated for at least 7 days.

2. Serology:- Standard Agglutination Test (SAT): Detects antibodies against Brucella. A significant titer is considered diagnostic. Coombs’ Test is used to detect non-agglutinating antibodies in chronic cases. Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA): Detects IgM, IgG, and IgA antibodies.

3. Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR): Molecular methods such as PCR can detect Brucella DNA in blood and other body fluids, providing a rapid and sensitive diagnostic tool.

4. Hematological Tests: May show pancytopenia. Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) can be elevated. Elevated liver enzymes may be present due to liver involvement.

5. Other Body Fluids: Cultures and cytological examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in cases of neuro brucellosis, or joint fluid in cases of septic arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following processes could potentially widen the demographic gap?
questions.solution:
Increased immigration (people moving into the country) is known to increase the birth rate and population size, therefore potentially widening the demographic gap (birth rate - death rate).

A demographic gap is a difference between the birth rate and the death rate. The demographic gap is maximum in the early-expanding phase, characterized by a high birth rate and low death rate. As the demography of the country transitions to the late-expanding phase, both the birth rate and death rate fall causing a decreasing demographic gap. Although the birth rate is falling in the late-expanding phase, it is still higher than the death rate, which causes the population to increase.

Other options: 

Option B: Increasing medical expenditure and cost would only lead to reduced accessibility and therefore high death rate. This would lead to the narrowing of the demographic gap.

Option C: Strict birth control measures would again lead to a reduced birth rate and a narrow demographic gap.

Option D: Emigration is when people move out of their native country to another country. Hence, increased emigration would lead to a reduced birth rate and a narrow demographic gap.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text:
A pregnant lady has undergone a 75 gm glucose tolerance test according to IADPSG guidelines. The blood glucose levels were found to be 95 mg/dL, 173 mg/dL, and 135 mg/dL at fasting, 1-hr, and 2-hr of glucose administration respectively. What is the most appropriate next step in this case?

IADPSG- International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups Consensus Panel

choices.text: Regular exercise only as the values are normal

questions.solution:
In this case, the blood glucose levels were: Fasting: 95 mg/dL (above the threshold of 92 mg/dL), which meets the criteria for gestational diabetes mellitus(GDM) according to the IADPSG guidelines. Thus, this patient should be started on a diabetic diet and regular exercise to manage her GDM. 

The IADPSG has established criteria for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) based on a 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). According to the IADPSG guidelines, the diagnosis of GDM is made if any one of the following plasma glucose values is met or exceeded:

  • Fasting: 92 mg/dL
  • 1-hour: 180 mg/dL
  • 2-hour: 153 mg/dL

Once diagnosed with gestational diabetes, patients are started on conservative management including a diabetic diet and regular exercise. After 2 weeks, a repeat 2-hour OGTT is done. If the blood glucose level is <120 mg/dL, the diabetic diet is continued. If ≥120 mg/dL, insulin is started. Regular insulin and NPH are preferred during pregnancy. If the patient refuses to take insulin, oral hypoglycemic agents (OHAs) like metformin or glyburide can be used.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, G2P1, at 33 weeks gestation presents after an episode of painless vaginal bleeding. She currently has no bleeding. On examination, she is pale but hemodynamically stable. Her uterus is hard on palpation. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows normal variability and no signs of fetal distress. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate initial management step for this patient, suffering from placenta previa with ongoing contractions (hard uterus), is administering nifedipine (tocolytic).

Placenta previa occurs when the placenta attaches in the lower uterine segment, leading to painless, unexplained vaginal bleeding typically after the 28th week of pregnancy. Risk factors include prior cesarean section, uterine surgeries like suction and curettage, advanced maternal age, and smoking.

Macafee and Johnson's method advocates expectant management for placenta previa, aiming to prolong pregnancy until fetal maturity while safeguarding maternal health.

Prerequisites for Expectant Management:

  • Adequate blood supply for potential transfusions.
  • 24-hour availability of cesarean section facilities.

Criteria for suitable expectant management :

  • Maternal health in good standing (Hb ≥ 10 g%, hematocrit ≥ 30%).
  • Pregnancy duration less than 37 weeks.
  • Absence of active vaginal bleeding.
  • Confirmed fetal well-being through continuous monitoring (CTG and USG).

Conduct of Expectant Treatment:

  • Administration of corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone or dexamethasone) for fetal lung maturity if pregnancy is <34 weeks.
  • Prescribed bed rest and monitoring of maternal health indicators such as Hb levels, blood grouping, and urine protein levels.
  • Regular inspection of vulval pads and ongoing fetal surveillance via ultrasound.
  • Provision of supplementary hematinics and Rh Immunoglobulin for Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.
  • Consideration of tocolytic therapy (e.g., nifedipine) in cases where vaginal bleeding coincides with uterine contractions.

Termination of Expectant Treatment: Continued until the 37th week of pregnancy, ensuring fetal maturity. This approach reduces the risks associated with preterm birth and complications related to placenta previa.

questions.text: You notice the capnography of a patient showing the tracing below. Which of the following steps is best suited in his management?

choices.text: Extubation and re-intubation under proper visualization
Stopping the inhaled anesthetic and administering dantrolene sodium
Continue monitoring as the capnogram is normal

questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform shows an elevated inspiratory baseline, which depicts rebreathing. Rebreathing of CO2 may occur due to exhausted soda lime or incompetent expiratory valve in closed-circuit breathing systems. Hence, replacing the soda lime would be the best step in this situation.

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: Exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.

Other options:

Option A - Extubation and re-intubation under proper visualization would benefit a patient with esophageal intubation. It shows a capnograph with some carbon dioxide detected initially followed by the absence of carbon dioxide. Swallowed air in the stomach would cause the initial detection of CO2 which is soon washed out and the ETCO2 comes to zero. Also, breath sounds in the epigastrium are a sign of oesophageal intubation. Endotracheal intubation is characterized by the absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium. 

Option B- Stopping the inhaled anesthetic and administering dantrolene sodium would be indicated in patients with malignant hyperthermia. A dramatic increase in body temperature and muscle rigidity would normally be accompanying features. The increased metabolic rate caused by malignant hyperthermia causes a marked rise in ETCO2.

A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor

K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations

The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, odynophagia, and a muffled voice for the past 2 days. Oropharyngeal examination reveals the image findings. Which of the following nerves would be responsible for causing earache in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever, odynophagia, a muffled voice, and an oropharyngeal examination revealing a congested and edematous tonsil with the uvula pushed to the opposite side is suggestive of peritonsillar abscess (quinsy). In these patients, referred otalgia is seen, due to irritation of the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, also known as the Jacobson's nerve. 

The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve. The glossopharyngeal nerve and the styloid process lie in relation to the lower part of the tonsillar fossa. Therefore, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal/Jacobson's nerve.

Causes of referred otalgia via glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Acute pharyngitis
  • Tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess
  • Post-tonsillectomy
  • Foreign bodies embedded in the base of the tongue or tonsillar area
  • Elongated styloid process

Other options

Option B: The chorda tympani is a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII) involved in taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and parasympathetic innervation to the submandibular and sublingual glands.

Option C: Mackenzie's nerve also known as the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve, CN X), it provides sensory innervation to the laryngopharynx and contributes to the cough reflex.

Option D: Arnold's nerve, i.e., the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (CN X), supplies the concha and the corresponding area on the medial surface of the ear. Causes of referred pain via the auricular branch of the vagus nerve include malignancy or ulcerative lesion of the vallecula, epiglottis, larynx, and oesophagus.

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmics has the property of blocking sodium and potassium channels?
questions.solution:
Procainamide belongs to the class IA of antiarrhythmics. It has the property of blocking sodium and potassium channels.

Class 1A drugs have an intermediate rate of recovery with sodium and potassium channel-blocking properties. These include procainamide, quinidine, and disopyramide. Procainamide is used in the treatment of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome with atrial fibrillation. Procainamide is used in the acute and chronic management of atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation.

Other options:

Option B: Verapamil and diltiazem are calcium channel blockers that belong to class IV antiarrhythmics. It is used in the management of supraventricular arrhythmias and rate control in atrial fibrillation. These agents can be used in the termination and prevention of such arrhythmias.

Option C: Propranolol is a beta-blocker belonging to class II antiarrhythmics agents. It is used for rate control in atrial fibrillation. 

Option D: IV Ibutilide is administered as a rapid infusion for the immediate conversion of atrial fibrillation or flutter to sinus rhythm. It is a class III antiarrhythmic drug that is a potassium channel blocker and restores sinus rhythm by prolonging the action potential duration and effective refractory period. Ibutilide carries a significant risk of Torsades de Pointes. Hence is not preferred in a patient with prolonged QT interval.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child presents with intermittent left-sided abdominal pain and recurrent urinary tract infections over the past few months. On examination, mild tenderness over the left costovertebral angle was present. The delayed intravenous urogram of the patient is given below. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
In a child with recurrent urinary tract infection and delayed IVU showing unilateral hydronephrosis, the most likely cause is congenital pelvi-ureteric junction obstruction (PUOJ).

In this child presenting with intermittent left-sided abdominal pain, recurrent urinary tract infections, and mild tenderness over the left costovertebral angle, along with intravenous urogram findings of moderate dilation of the left renal pelvis and calyces, the most common cause is congenital PUJO. PUJO is a congenital condition where there is a narrowing or blockage at the junction where the ureter meets the renal pelvis. This obstruction leads to dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces leading to hydronephrosis on the affected side. 

PUJO can arise due to various factors, including intrinsic obstruction caused by a segment with poor peristalsis due to muscular hypoplasia. Other contributing factors include a higher level of insertion of the ureter into the renal pelvis and the presence of crossing aberrant vessels at the PUJ. These conditions collectively lead to impaired urine flow from the kidney, resulting in hydronephrosis. It is more commonly observed among males and on the left side.

The Anderson–Hynes dismembered pyeloplasty is the preferred surgical management for this condition especially indicated in cases presenting with persistent pain, hypertension, hematuria, secondary renal calculi, and recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Endoscopic management, specifically endopyelotomy, is typically reserved for treating strictures that develop after previous pyeloplasty procedures.

Vesicoureteral reflux (option B) and posterior urethral valve (option C) are associated with hydroureteronephrosis.

Distal ureteric calculus (option A) is associated with proximal ureter dilatation along with hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was initiated on haloperidol therapy. Two days later, he presented to the hospital with a deviation of eyes, inability to open mouth, and torticollis. What is the first-line management of this case?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of deviation of the eyes (oculogyric crisis), inability to open the mouth (trismus), asymmetric position of the head and neck (torticollis) are pointing towards a diagnosis of haloperidol-induced acute dystonia. The first-line treatment for antipsychotic-induced acute dystonia is diphenhydramine.

Acute muscular dystonia:

This is an extrapyramidal symptom (EPS) that occurs due to the antagonism of dopamine D2 receptors.

Acute dystonia is more commonly associated with high potency typical antipsychotics like haloperidol and occurs within 1 to 5 days of initiation of therapy. 

It occurs most commonly among younger patients and is characterized by muscle spasms involving linguo-facial muscles causing torticollis, locked jaw or trismus, grimacing, tongue thrusting, and oculogyric crisis in severe form.

Treatment:

  1. Anticholinergic agents like benztropine or diphenhydramine, by blocking striatal cholinergic receptors, balance the dopaminergic activity and is given as first-line treatment for dystonia. 
  2. Benzodiazepines (diazepam) antagonizes the excitatory dopaminergic neurons by their GABA agonist action and are used in refractory cases or when anticholinergic use is contraindicated.

Other options:

Option B: Propranolol is used for the management of akathisia.

Option C: Dantrolene is used in the management of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option D: Lorazepam is used for treating anxiety disorders, alcohol withdrawal, and anesthetic medication.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency room with severe burns caused by a nearby explosion. Examination showed burns covering over 60% of his body surface area. Which type of blast injury is this consistent with?
questions.solution:
The blast injury is consistent with the quaternary blast injury. The injury following an explosion causing burns shall come under quaternary blast injury.

Classification of blast injuries:

Primary blast injuries- effect of transmitted blast waves causing overpressure type of injury The middle ear, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract are the most susceptible. Eg: tympanic membrane injury, blast lung, intestinal blast injury.

Secondary blast injuries (the most common type of blast injury)- are caused by flying shrapnel or missiles and other airborne debris propelled by the explosion leading to penetrating/fragmentation type of injuries. These injuries may affect any part of the body.

Tertiary blast injuries- are caused by blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects. It causes blunt type of injuries. Eg: crush injuries and traumatic amputation.

Quaternary and Quinary blast injuries- all other injuries caused by explosions are not included in the above three categories. eg, flash burns, inhalational injuries, crush injuries.  Quinary injury refers to injury caused by the intentional addition of either biologically or radioactively active material to an explosive device.

  • When the explosion is in the water the pressure changes are called underwater blast. Intestinal damage is very common in underwater blast injuries.
  • Solid blast refers to the wave of energy that spreads through the rigid structure when an explosive is detonated near it and people in contact with its structure can be injured.
  • Caecum is most sensitive to intestinal blast injury.

questions.text: A 28-year old woman presents with symptoms of postpartum depression. Her physician decides to prescribe a newly FDA approved oral medication specifically for postpartum depression. Which medication is the physician most likely prescribing?
questions.solution:
Zuranolone is the first FDA-approved oral medication specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It works by modulating GABA receptors, providing rapid relief from depressive symptoms in postpartum women.

Postpartum depression is a type of mood disorder that occurs after childbirth, characterised by sadness, fatigue, changes in sleeping and eating patterns that start within 4 weeks as per DSM 5 or 6 weeks as per ICD 11, and persist for ≥ 2 weeks.

Management strategies include psychotheraoy, social support, and medications. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are generally used off-label, but zuranolone offers a new FDA-approved option for oral treatment. 

Other options:

Option A: Brexanolone is another FDA approved treatment for postpartum depression but is administered intravenously. It increases serotonin levels in the brain but typically takes longer to show effects compared to zuranolone

Option C: Escitalopram is an SSRI often prescribed off-label for postpartum depression, but is not FDA-approved for this condition.

Option D: Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used for treatment of depression but is not used in postpartun depression.

questions.text: A facial reconstruction surgery is planned for a child using the myocutaneous flap from the area marked in the image below. Name the vessel on which the flap is based.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the pectoralis major flap, which is based on the thoracoacromial artery.

The pectoralis major myocutaneous regional flap was first described for head and neck reconstruction. It remains an important reconstructive option due to its ease of harvest, long reach to many parts of the head and neck, and healthy muscle and skin components. The pectoralis flap can be harvested as a musculocutaneous flap or muscle-only flap and is based on the pectoral branch of the thoracoacromial artery. Following flap harvest, a subcutaneous tunnel is created from the donor site, over the clavicles, to the defect. Division of the pectoral nerve branches ensures atrophy of the muscle to reduce the bulge over the clavicle over time.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is an Anti-CTLA-4 antibody used in the treatment of advanced melanoma?
questions.solution:
Anti-CTLA-4 antibody Ipilimumab was the first drug to significantly improve advanced-stage melanoma's survival. Cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen 4 (CTLA-4) plays an important inhibitory role in the control of T-cell activation.

Ipilimumab is a fully humanized IgG1 monoclonal antibody that inhibits cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4).

Other options:

Option A - Pembrolizumab acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and was used for the treatment of advanced melanoma. Now, the FDA has approved the use of pembrolizumab for any cancer with mismatch repair (MMR) deficiency or high microsatellite instability (MSI-H).

Option C - Nivolumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and is used for the treatment of advanced melanoma and relapsed/refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma.

Option D - Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the HER2 receptor. It is used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

questions.text: A non-essential amino acid is involved in the first step of heme synthesis. Which of the following is not a derivative of this amino acid?
questions.solution:
The non-essential amino acid involved in the first step of heme synthesis is glycine. Among the given options Melanin is a derivative of tyrosine and not glycine. 

Glycine is the simplest amino acid. It is non-essential and is glucogenic. It is involved in Heme biosynthesis, which is initiated by the condensation of succinyl-CoA and glycine in the presence of pyridoxal phosphate and δ-aminolevulinate synthase (ALA synthase) to produce δ-aminolevulinate. The Other products obtained from glycine are:

  • Creatine (from glycine, arginine, and methionine)
  • Serine (by reversal of serine hydroxymethyl transferase reaction)
  • Collagen (every third residue is glycine)
  • Glutathione (from glutamic acid, cysteine, and glycine)
  • C4, C5, and N7 of the purine ring structure

Tyrosine is a precursor of melanin, thyroxine, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).

  • Formation of DOPA: Tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosinase to form dihydroxy phenylalanine or DOPA. Tyrosinase is a copper-containing monooxygenase enzyme.
  • Formation of melanin: Tyrosinase acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which is then converted to indolequinone. The indolequinone is polymerized to form melanin.

questions.text: Which of the following aspects of disease management is least likely to be influenced by the iceberg phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The effectiveness of treatment (Option 4) is least likely to be influenced by the iceberg phenomenon, which refers to the concept where only a fraction of cases of a disease are visible or reported, with a larger "hidden" burden below the surface. This is because once a patient is diagnosed and treated, the impact of underdiagnosis or hidden cases on individual treatment outcomes is minimal. Treatment effectiveness depends more on factors such as drug efficacy, patient adherence, and healthcare delivery rather than the overall prevalence of the disease in the population.

Incorrect options:

Option 1: Accuracy of reported prevalence rates: Reported prevalence rates are heavily influenced by the number of diagnosed cases compared to the total number of cases (both diagnosed and undiagnosed). If a disease has a significant hidden burden (undetected cases), the reported prevalence rates will underestimate the true prevalence in the population.

Option 2: Effectiveness of targeted screening programs: Targeted screening programs rely on accurate knowledge of disease prevalence to effectively identify individuals at risk. If prevalence rates are underestimated due to the iceberg phenomenon (many undiagnosed cases), screening programs may miss a substantial portion of the population who could benefit from early detection and intervention.

Option 3: Timeliness of treatment initiation: Timely initiation of treatment is critical for many diseases to prevent complications and improve outcomes. However, if a large number of cases are undiagnosed, delays in diagnosis can occur. This delay can lead to delayed treatment initiation, allowing the disease to progress unchecked in individuals who are not yet diagnosed.

questions.text: Anti-larval measures are being taken for a pond in a village. Which of the following synthetic insecticides are not recommended for such measures?
questions.solution:
DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) is not recommended for anti-larval measures. It is mainly used as a residual spray for the control of adult mosquitoes.

Compounds such as DDT and HCH (lindane) are organochlorine compounds. These are not recommended for larvicidal operations for the following reasons: 

  • Long residual effect 
  • Risk of water contamination
  • Risk of developing resistance in the vector mosquitoes

The most effective larvicides are malathion, fenthion, chlorpyrifos, and abate which can quickly hydrolyze in water. Malathion can be used as a low-volume spray to prevent mosquito-borne epidemics, vector-borne diseases during floods and dengue hemorrhagic fever.

  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.

DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man, after a bout of binge drinking and vomiting, presents with severe pain in the chest and dyspnea. On clinical examination, there is rigidity in the upper abdomen. The chest X-ray shows pneumomediastinum. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: Cervical esophagostomy is performed in unstable patients
Perforation is most commonly seen on the left anterolateral wall
One-stage surgical repair is done in stable patients
Ginkgo leaf sign may be seen on the chest X-ray

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the finding of pneumomediastinum suggest a diagnosis of spontaneous esophageal perforation or Boerhaave’s syndrome. Perforation is most commonly seen on the left posterolateral wall of the lower 1/3rd of the esophagus.

Boerhaave syndrome is the spontaneous perforation of the esophagus caused by vomiting against a closed glottis. They usually have a history of heavy meal intake and alcohol abuse. The posterolateral aspect of the esophagus is the most common site of esophageal perforation due to its structural weakness, which makes it more susceptible to tearing under stress or pressure. This area is close to the vertebral column, creating a point of resistance and increased pressure, especially during procedures like endoscopy or the passage of large or sharp objects. Additionally, the natural curves of the esophagus can contribute to localized stress, further predisposing this region to perforation.

Clinical features include Mackler's triad, which comprises retching, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema. On examination, abdominal rigidity and a crunchy sound on chest palpation (Hamman's sign) due to subcutaneous emphysema are seen.

The investigation of choice is a contrast esophagogram (iohexol) in unstable patients or a contrast-enhanced CT scan in stable patients.

Treatment includes primary closure if the patient presents early and is minimally septic. If the patient is unstable or presents late, the perforated part is resected, and a cervical esophagostomy is performed. A feeding jejunostomy or gastrostomy is performed for nutrition.

The most common cause of mortality in Boerhaave syndrome is mediastinitis (40% to 50%).

Option A:  Esophagostomy, a procedure to divert esophageal contents instead of performing a primary repair of a perforation is indicated when the patient is unstable, when repair is not feasible due to the size of the defect or the fragility of surrounding tissue, or when there is a preexisting esophageal disease.

Option C: Stable, minimally septic patients who present early are managed by a single-stage primary closure.

Option D: Ginkgo biloba leaf sign is seen in subcutaneous emphysema and can be seen on the chest X-ray in patients with Boerhaave syndrome. Air outlines the fibers of the pectoralis major muscle and forms a streaky pattern similar to the branching pattern in the veins of a ginkgo leaf.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of watering eyes and inability to keep eyes opened in a bright room. On ocular examination, the following finding is noted. The finding is a defect in which of the following layers of the cornea?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with photophobia and excessive watering and image showing Haab striae is suggestive of congenital glaucoma. Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in the descemet membrane.

Primary congenital glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure (IOP) which occurs as a result of a developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber. It is not associated with any other ocular or systemic anomaly. It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Diagnosis:

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring

Below image shows hazy cornea.


Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; IV ketamine lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment:

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with a history of frequent frontal headaches. On examination, he has upper eyelid edema and tenderness just above the medial canthus. His CT is shown below. Which of the following air cells, as marked in the CT, can cause his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of frontal sinusitis and the marked structure in the CT is agger nasi, the anteriormost cell of anterior ethmoidal air cells.

Agger nasi communicates with the frontal recess; when enlarged, it may cause mechanical obstruction to frontal sinus drainage, leading to frontal sinusitis.

The ethmoid-sinusoidal air cells range from 3 to 18 in number and are divided into anterior and posterior groups by a basal lamina.

Anterior cells: They open into the middle meatus. They contain-

  • Agger nasi cells: present in the agger nasi ridge
  • Ethmoid bulla: Forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris
  • Supraorbital cells
  • Frontoethmoid cells: In the area of the frontal recess
  • Haller cells: in the floor of the orbit. Lies in the roof of the maxillary sinus, and an enlargement may prevent drainage of the maxillary sinus

Posterior cells: They open into superior meatus. Occasionally, they may also open directly into the sphenoid sinus. They contain about 1-7 cells, the most important one being the Onodi cells. Onodi cells extend as far back as 1.5 centimeters from their anterior wall.

Other options : 

Option A: pneumatization of the middle turbinate, which becomes ballooned out and is called concha bullosa. 

Here is an image of concha bullosa marked with asterixis


Option C: Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal cell that may grow posteriorly, either by the side of the sphenoid sinus or superior to it. Onodi cells are surgically important as the optic nerve may be related to its lateral wall. 


Option D: The superior turbinate, located posteriorly and superiorly to the middle turbinate can become pneumatized. It forms an important landmark to identify the ostium of the sphenoid sinus which lies medially to it. Pneumatized superior turbinate is an incidental finding during radiological examinations. It can lead to nasal obstruction, headache, epistaxis, anosmia, and postnasal drainage.
