questions.text: A patient presented with the following lesions in the axilla. Histopathology of the lesions shows a dilapidated brick wall appearance. Which of the following gene is mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows red inflammatory lesions in the axilla and also the dilapidated brick wall appearance on histology is characteristically seen in Hailey-Hailey disease. It occurs due to a mutation in the ATP2C1 gene.

It is an autosomal dominant disorder occurring due to a mutation in the ATP2C1 gene encoding the SERCA calcium channel ATPase. Due to this, desmosomal function in the suprabasal and basal layers is disturbed, leading to keratinocyte separation and acantholysis.

It causes blistering, particularly in the intertriginous areas such as the axilla, inframammary, groin, etc. Since there is friction in such areas the blisters do not remain intact and can cause fissures and red inflammatory lesions.

On histology, there is a widespread loss of cohesion between suprabasal keratinocytes leading to acantholysis, which is incomplete. Hence, separated keratinocytes are still partially connected to each other giving the appearance of a dilapidated or broken brick wall.

ATP2A2 mutation is seen in Darier disease, which is characterized by dirty, warty follicles, generally on the face and limbs due to dyskeratosis (shown in the image below).

TCA- Tricarboxylic acid cycle
questions.solution:
Citrate acts as a key regulatory molecule in glycolysis and fatty acid synthesis.

Citrate inhibits phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1), the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis. Phosphofructokinase-1 catalyses the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate into fructose-1,6-phosphate.

Citrate also activates acetyl-CoA carboxylase, the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis. Acetyl-CoA carboxylase catalyses the carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to form malonyl-CoA.

Inhibitors of acetyl-CoA carboxylase: long-chain acyl CoA, glucagon, epinephrine, and phosphorylation 
Activators of acetyl-CoA carboxylase: Citrate, insulin, and dephosphorylation

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who had undergone emergency laparotomy 6 days ago for a gastric ulcer perforation presents with abdominal wound dehiscence after repeated bouts of coughing. Which of the following measures could have prevented this complication?

choices.text: Usage of absorbable monofilament suture for closure
Suture length to wound length ratio of 4:1 or more

questions.solution:
Using a suture length to wound length ratio of 4:1 or more would have prevented this complication of abdominal wound dehiscence.

Abdominal wound dehiscence/Burst abdomen is a surgical complication that occurs after abdominal surgery where the rectus sheath opens up and bowel can be visualized directly. It is also known as acute wound failure. It is a mechanical wound failure causing separation of the closed abdominal wound often with evisceration of the contents.

It is the disruption of a laparotomy wound, occurring usually between 5th and 8th postoperative day. Usually sutures opposing the deep layers, i.e. peritoneum and rectus sheath tear through, causing burst abdomen-acute wound failure.

Vertical midline incision is more prone for dehiscence than transverse incision. Mass closure is better than layer-by-layer closure. Nonabsorbable mono filament suture material is used for the closure. Suture bite interval should be 1 cm but not more. Suture length and wound length ratio should be 4:1 or more. Continuous sutures are preferred over interrupted sutures.

Other than technical errors, deep wound infection causes localised separation of the wound which in addition to raised intra-abdominal pressure leads to wound dehiscence.

Wound dehiscence present with pinkish serosanguineous fluid (salmon fluid) drainage from the wound. Patients with evisceration present with sudden ripping sensation that occurs with severe coughing or retching. Wound dehiscence is associated with a high mortality rate. Associated factors that increase the risk are malnutrition, sepsis, cancer, obesity, chronic cough, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a part of the stepwise approach of selecting a P-drug?

choices.text: Make an inventory of effective groups of drugs

questions.solution:
Considering patient compliance is not in the World Health Organisation's (WHO) 5-step approach to selecting a P-drug.

The term "P-drug" refers to a concept developed by the World Health Organisation (WHO) to encourage rational prescribing practices among healthcare providers. The "P" in P-drug stands for "preferred" or "personalised." A P-drug is a medication selected by a healthcare provider as the preferred choice for treating a specific condition within a given healthcare setting.

The selection of a P-drug involves a systematic approach:

1. Define the diagnosis: Identify and confirm the medical condition requiring treatment.

2. Specify the therapeutic objective: Outline the goals and outcomes expected from treatment.

3. Make an inventory of effective groups of drugs: List potential drug classes or groups known to treat the condition effectively.

4. Choose an effective group according to the criteria: Select the most appropriate medication from the identified groups based on criteria such as efficacy, safety, suitability, and cost-effectiveness.

5. Choose a P-drug

questions.text: A patient with plaque psoriasis presents with lesions involving the axillary, inframammary, and inguinal creases. On examination, these lesions are well-demarcated, smooth, moist, and erythematous, with no scaling.  Which of the following types could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with lesions with minimal scaling and moist, smooth surfaces involving flexural areas (the axillary, inframammary, and inguinal creases) in a patient with plaque psoriasis elsewhere suggests a likely diagnosis of inverse psoriasis.

Inverse psoriasis (also called flexural psoriasis or intertriginous psoriasis) refers to psoriasis of the flexural areas such as the inguinal creases, axillae, inframammary, and other body folds. Unlike characteristic lesions of psoriasis, these plaques are thin, with minimal or no scaling. The surface is glazed with fissuring.

Inverse psoriasis may manifest as new lesions occurring on the body or the Koebner phenomenon on top of existing intertriginous dermatoses, or it may be present along with classical plaque psoriasis. It typically involves the diaper area in infants, referred to as napkin psoriasis. It may also affect older, obese patients. An image of inverse psoriasis is shown below:


Psoriasis is characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces. The peak occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years.

Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis. It presents with pruritis and a papulosquamous rash. Lesions can be described as red, scaly, and a well-defined demarcation from the normal skin. The scales often appear white and silvery. The lesions may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring. They are seen in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

Based on morphology, psoriasis is classified into the following clinical variants:

Option B: Guttate psoriasis  - Sudden onset of small lesions on the trunk and proximal limbs, in children. It usually occurs weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis. It is shown in the image below.


Option C: Erythrodermic psoriasis is a severe, rare form of psoriasis marked by generalized erythema covering over 75% of the body surface and accompanied by diffuse scaling. It can lead to severe illness with fever and dehydration. The pathogenesis involves a complex interaction between genetic, environmental, and immune system factors, similar to other psoriasis types. Clinically, it presents with widespread red, scaly skin, often with pustules, and may include systemic symptoms such as fever and dehydration. Image is shown below:


Option D: Seborrhoeic psoriasis or sebopsoriasis presents as thin, demarcated erythema with scales. It is typically seen in areas that are involved in seborrhoeic dermatitis- paranasal areas, external ears, medial eyebrows, hairline, presternal, and interscapular chest wall.

Pustular psoriasis- Appearance of macroscopic pustules within lesions.
Unstable psoriasis (active psoriasis, eruptive inflammatory psoriasis) - Characterized by actively enlarging erythematous plaques, with the development of new smaller plaques

Psoriasis may affect specific sites. These include:

Scalp psoriasis
Follicular psoriasis
Seborrhoeic psoriasis or sebopsoriasis
Flexural psoriasis or inverse psoriasis
Genital psoriasis
Non‐pustular palmoplantar psoriasis
Nail psoriasis
Ocular psoriasis
Mucosal psoriasis

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the cell wall synthesis of a Gram-positive bacterium. During the experiment, they discovered a mutation that disrupts the enzyme transpeptidase. Which antibiotic does this mutation confer resistance to?
questions.solution:
Penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics inhibit the enzyme transpeptidase, which is responsible for cross-linking peptidoglycan strands. A mutation disrupting this enzyme would lead to resistance to penicillin.

Vancomycin inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan precursors, preventing their incorporation into the cell wall, rather than directly affecting the transpeptidase enzyme.

Bacitracin interferes with the dephosphorylation of bactoprenol, a carrier molecule that transports peptidoglycan precursors across the cell membrane.

Daptomycin disrupts cell membrane function rather than inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 2-month-old baby saying that her baby defecates after every feed. This reflex is called as
questions.solution:
The reflex given in the clinical scenario is a gastrocolic reflex. In this reflex, distension of the stomach by food results in the evacuation of the colon. This reflex is mainly transmitted by the autonomic nervous system through prevertebral sympathetic ganglia.

Other options:

Option A- When food leaves the stomach, the passage of chyme through the ileocecal valve increases due to vigorous peristalsis. This forces the chyme into the cecum. This is called gastroileal reflex.

Option B- Entry of food into the small intestine and colon results in the inhibition of gastric motility and gastric secretions. This is called enterogastric reflex.

Option C- Entry of chyme into the colon results in the inhibition of emptying of ileal contents into the colon. This is called colonoileal reflex.

questions.text: A child was brought to a pediatrician with tense blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema. A biopsy of the lesion showed the linear deposition of IgA antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction. What is the first-line drug used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with tense blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema showing IgA antibodies deposition at dermo-epidermal junction is diagnostic of linear IgA disease. Dapsone is the first-line drug used in the management of this condition.

Linear IgA disease is a subepidermal blistering disease, characterized by tense blisters and annular erythema. It is commonly seen in infants and children. These blisters and vesicles develop in an annular pattern which gives rise to a string‐of‐pearls or crown of jewels pattern. Mucosal involvement is common.

The images below show linear IgA dermatosis at various sites. Image C shows a string-of-pearls pattern of blisters and crusts in the perioral area.


The biopsy will show the presence of linear deposits of IgA antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction. Dapsone is the first-line drug used in the management of this condition.

questions.text: An ENT resident performs the following procedure under general anesthesia to wash out the pus in a patient diagnosed with chronic maxillary sinusitis. This patient is usually placed in which of the following positions while performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above image is proof puncture (antral lavage). While performing this procedure under general anesthesia, the patient is placed in Rose's position or tonsillectomy position 

Proof puncture (antral lavage): This procedure involves puncturing the medial wall of the maxillary sinus in the region of the inferior meatus and irrigating the sinus.

Indications:

  • Chronic and subacute maxillary sinusitis with dual purpose of confirming the diagnosis and washing out the pus.
  • To collect the specimen of the antral contents for culture and sensitivity, or cytological examination to exclude early malignancy.

Contraindications:

  • Acute maxillary sinusitis for fear of osteomyelitis.

Note: Sitting position is preferred in all adults when using local anesthesia. But under general anesthesia, the patient is placed in Rose's position or tonsillectomy position 

Rose position is a surgical position that involves head and neck extension with a sandbag near the shoulder blade as shown in the below image.


Other options:

Barking-dog position is a surgical position in which the neck is flexed on the thorax and the head is extended on atlanto-occipital joint. This position is used during laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, and oesophagoscopy.


Reverse Trendelenburg position is lying flat with the head 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. This position is used in ocular and ENT surgeries like minimally invasive cataract surgery and rhinoplasty.


Semi fowler position is lying supine incline at an angle of 30 - 45 degrees. This position is used for patients who have cardiac or respiratory conditions and for patients with a nasogastric tube.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed a weak electrical activity. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
As the patient has pulseless electrical activity (PEA), 1mg epinephrine IV has to be given immediately.

A pulseless electrical activity involves a heterogeneous group of cardiac rhythms, all without a pulse.

The immediate treatment for this is giving chest compressions and 1 mg epinephrine at the earliest until definitive therapy to the cause can be instituted.

It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of cardiac arrest because the treatment for each of them is different and PEA is likely to persist until the cause is treated. If left untreated, PEA may develop into asystole or ventricular fibrillation.

Other options:

Option A: Defibrillation delivers an electrical current to interrupt the disorganized cardiac activity in ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation (shockable rythms) to restore an organized cardiac rhythm. 

Option B: Synchronized cardioversion is a low-energy shock given in sync with the peak of the QRS complex in cases of unstable atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, atrial tachycardia, and supraventricular tachycardias.

Option D: Atropine was removed from the 2010 ACLS guidelines as standard treatment for cardiac arrest patients with a non-shockable rhythm or adults with pulseless electrical activity (PEA) due to a lack of clear benefit.

questions.text: The structure that is related to the area marked 'A' in the given image is derived from:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the left lung and structure related to the marked area 'A' is the arch of the aorta which is derived from the left fourth aortic arch.

In the given image, the left lung is identified by the presence of the vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum - pulmonary artery, principal (hyparterial) bronchus, and inferior pulmonary vein. The image also shows an oblique fissure dividing the lung into superior and inferior lobes.

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures. They give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

The 4th aortic arch persists on both sides and forms different structures on either side:

  • Left side - part of the arch of the aorta between the left common carotid and the left subclavian arteries
  • Right side - proximal segment of the right subclavian artery

  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: A dead body is brought in for autopsy. The cause of death is reported to be pontine hemorrhage. Which postmortem change is delayed in this condition?
questions.solution:
Pontine hemorrhage can lead to delayed algor mortis (postmortem cooling).

Normally, algor mortis begins within 1-2 hours after death, when the body starts to cool down and eventually reaches the ambient temperature. Factors influencing the rate of cooling include ambient temperature, body size, clothing, and the presence of insulation (e.g., blankets). However, In certain conditions, algor mortis may be delayed due to severe disturbances in body temperature regulation before death (for example pontine hemorrhage, heatstroke, septicemia, thyrotoxicosis).

Pontine Hemorrhage is a type of stroke that affects the pons region of the brain, which plays a crucial role in regulating vital functions, including body temperature. In the event of a pontine hemorrhage, the body's ability to regulate temperature can be severely compromised. As a result, the body's temperature remains raised after death, a condition termed postmortem caloricity, thus delaying algor mortis.

Postmortem caloricity can be seen: 

  • When the regulation of body temperature has been severely disturbed before death as in sunstroke, pontine haemorrhage.
  • Increased heat production in muscles due to convulsions as in tetanus and strychnine poisoning.
  • When there has been increased bacterial activity as in septicemia.

Rigor Mortis: This refers to the stiffening of muscles after death, which generally begins within 2-6 hours and lasts up to 72 hours. It is not affected by pontine hemorrhage.

Livor Mortis: This is the pooling of blood in the dependent portions of the body, causing a purplish-red discoloration of the skin. It typically starts within 20 minutes to 3 hours after death and becomes fixed after 6-12 hours, unaffected by pontine hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of pulmonary artery hypertension presents with worsening dyspnea and palpitations. On examination, a high-pitched early diastolic murmur is heard at the left second intercostal space which increases with inspiration. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
The early diastolic murmur described in this patient is characteristic of the Graham Steell murmur.

Graham steell murmur is a high-pitched murmur heard best at the left second intercostal space and is often louder with inspiration. This murmur occurs due to pulmonary regurgitation, which in this case, is secondary to pulmonary hypertension. It can also be seen in patients with COPD due to the development of cor pulmonale leading to pulmonic hypertension. 

Other options:

Option A: Austin Flint murmur: This is a mid-diastolic murmur heard at the apex and is associated with severe aortic regurgitation, due to the regurgitant jet impinging on the anterior mitral leaflet. 

Option B: Carey Coombs murmur: This is a mid-diastolic murmur heard at the apex, associated with acute rheumatic fever. It is caused by inflammation of the mitral valve leaflets, leading to mitral valvulitis.

Option D: Still's murmur: This is an innocent murmur often heard in children. It is a low-pitched, vibratory, or musical systolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border.

questions.text: During your rural posting in a district that is endemic for Japanese encephalitis, a 6-year-old completely unimmunized child was brought to your Primary Health Center. Which of the following vaccines can be given to this child now?
questions.solution:
Among the given options DPT-1 and JE-1 can be given to a 6-year-old child who is completely unimmunized for the age. 

For an unvaccinated child between the age of 5-7 years, the first, second, and third doses of the DPT vaccine are given at one-month intervals. The booster dose can be given at a minimum of 6 months after administering the third dose of DPT up to 7 years of age.

JE vaccine can be given to a child from an endemic district for Japanese encephalitis up to 15 years of age. 

BCG vaccine is given up to 1 year of age. This is because most of the children acquire natural clinical/sub-clinical tuberculosis infection by the age of one year. This will also protect against severe forms of childhood tuberculosis.

OPV can only be given up to 5 years of age.

Vaccines that can be given to an unvaccinated child between the age of 1 - 5 years are DPT-1, OPV-1, measles, and 2 mL of vitamin A. At one-month intervals, second and third doses of DPT and OPV should be given. The second dose of measles is given as per the schedule. OPV/DPT booster dose can be given at a minimum of 6 months after administering their third dose.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with unilateral nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. A diagnosis of an antrochoanal polyp was made after evaluation. Which of the following findings in an antrochoanal polyp would help differentiate it from an angiofibroma?

choices.text: Hard consistency felt on probe testing
Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus seen on CT
A column of air behind the mass seen on X-ray
Conductive hearing loss due to obstruction of eustachian tube

questions.solution:
Antrochoanal polyp is differentiated from angiofibroma by the presence of a column of air behind the polyp on X-Ray (lateral view). It is also called as Dodd sign or crescent sign.

Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavity. It is usually single and unilateral which are more commonly seen in children and young adults. 

It has 3 parts namely

  • Thin antral stalk,
  • Round and globular choanal part, and
  • Flat nasal part.

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice.

Anterior rhinoscopy may miss the antrochoanal polyp when it starts to grow posteriorly. A large polyp may protrude from the nasal cavity and may appear pink and congested. It is soft and can be moved with a probe. Posterior rhinoscopy may reveal a globular mass filling the choana and hanging down behind the soft palate. 

X-ray (lateral view), soft tissue nasopharynx, reveals a globular swelling in the postnasal space, it is differentiated from angiofibroma by the presence of a column of air behind the polyp known as Dodd sign or crescent sign.

Diagnosis is made by radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp. Endoscopic examination reveals the antrochoanal polyp hidden posteriorly in the nasal cavity.

Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

Other options:

Option A: Hard consistency felt on probing is seen in case of hypertrophied middle turbinate. It is differentiated by its pink appearance and hard feel of bone on probing. 

Option B: Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus, often called antral sign or Holman-Miller sign is pathognomic of angiofibroma. 

Optiion D: Conductive hearing loss can also be seen in angiofibroma due to obstruction of the eustachian tube. Hence, this finding is not a differentiating feature.

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A patient was advised to stop taking his diclofenac temporarily as he was about to be started on voriconazole for a fungal infection. The reason for this recommendation is most likely due to their interaction with
questions.solution:
The reason for this recommendation is most likely due to their interaction with CYP2C9.

Voriconazole inhibits hepatic cytochrome P450 (CYP2C19, CYP2C9, CYP3A4, and CYP3A5) enzymes. Diclofenac is an NSAID extensively metabolised by the cytochrome P450 (CYPs) enzymes, particularly CYP2C9.

Hence, voriconazole can inhibit diclofenac metabolism, leading to increased levels of diclofenac in the bloodstream.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not affected in cavernous sinus syndrome?
questions.solution:
The optic nerve is not involved in cavernous sinus syndrome.

Cavernous sinus syndrome (CSS) is a rare condition characterized by ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, ocular and conjunctival congestion, trigeminal sensory loss, and Horner’s syndrome. These signs and symptoms result from the involvement of the cranial nerves passing through the cavernous sinus. The cavernous sinus syndrome affects III, IV, V, and VI cranial nerves.

The cavernous sinuses are two large venous plexuses that lie on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone, extending from the superior orbital fissure to the apex of the petrous temporal bone.

Structures related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinuses are the Oculomotor nerve, Trochlear nerve and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. Within the cavernous sinus are the Abducens nerve and the Cavernous part of the internal carotid artery.

Image showing cavernous sinus and the structures related to it.


Orbital apex syndrome is a condition similar to cavernous sinus syndrome with retro-orbital pain and involvement of 2,3,4,5 and 6 cranial nerves. The differentiating feature is the Optic nerve involvement leading to early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect.

questions.text: X-Ray of a 20-year-old who came to the emergency after a fall on an outstretched hand appears as below. On examination, crepitus is absent, the forearm appears shortened and the three-point bony relation is disrupted. Which of the following nerves is most commonly injured in patients with this condition?
questions.solution:
The lateral X-Ray of the elbow shows the coronoid process of the ulna lying posterior to the condyles of the humerus, which along with the clinical history points to this being a case of posterior dislocation of the elbow. The most common nerve injury associated with it is the ulnar nerve injury.

The order of incidence of nerve injury in elbow dislocation is Ulnar nerve > Radial nerve > Median nerve. The ulnar nerve becomes entrapped commonly as it passes posteriorly around the medial epicondyle.

Elbow dislocation is the most common dislocation in the pediatric age group and the second most common dislocation after the shoulder in adults.

Posterior dislocation is the commonest type of elbow dislocation. It frequently occurs due to a fall on the outstretched hands with the elbow slightly flexed. Other dislocations are postero-medial, postero-lateral, and divergent.

Anterior dislocation occurs when the elbow is flexed and there is a direct blow on the posterior aspect of the elbow joint.

Clinical features

  • The forearm appears shortened.
  • Crepitus is absent.
  • The three-point bony relationship is disrupted.
  • Olecranon is above the intercondylar line

Elbow dislocation is an emergency and has to be reduced immediately. Closed reduction under general anaesthesia(GA) is attempted first. An above elbow POP slab is applied with 90º elbow flexion and mid-pronation for a period of 3 weeks after closed reduction under GA.

Stimson’s 2 step principles for closed reduction

  • step 1 - traction along the long axis of the humerus to counteract the contraction of biceps, triceps and brachialis
  • step 2 - traction along the long axis of the forearm to bring radius and ulna back into position

2 techniques in closed reduction

  • Prone technique- Grab the wrist of the injured arm. Apply traction and slight supination to the forearm. Using the other hand, apply pressure to the posterior aspect of the olecranon while the arm is pronated
  • supine technique- a helper stabilizes the humerus against the stretcher with both hands. Grasp the wrist, and apply slow, steady, inline traction, keeping the elbow slightly flexed and the wrist supinated

Early complications include neurovascular injury. Vascular injuries are rare and involve the brachial artery in open fractures associated with elbow dislocation.

Late complications include myositis ossificans, recurrent dislocations, proximal radioulnar translocation, and ectopic calcifications

The terrible triad of elbow includes

  • Posterior dislocation of the elbow
  • Radial head fracture
  • Fracture coronoid process of ulna

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with moderate to severely active ulcerative colitis is being considered for treatment with a newly FDA-approved monoclonal antibody. This drug works by blocking the action of IL-23, a proinflammatory cytokine. Which of the following drugs is most likely being prescribed?
questions.solution:
Mirikizumab is a monoclonal antibody that works by blocking the action of IL-23, a proinflammatory cytokine. It has recently received FDA approval for the treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative colitis in adults. Mirikizumab has shown significant benefits in clinical trials, including reduced rectal bleeding, stool frequency, and bowel urgency. 

Infliximab, Golimumab, and Adalimumab all belong to the class of TNF-alpha inhibitors. They work by binding to and neutralizing TNF-alpha, another proinflammatory cytokine involved in the pathogenesis of various autoimmune diseases, including ulcerative colitis. 

Other biological drugs used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease:

Anti-TNF therapies:

  • Infliximab
  • Adalimumab
  • Certolizumab

Anti-integrins:

  • Natalizumab
  • Ustekinumab
  • Vedolizumab

questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of hematuria and hemoptysis. His renal biopsy showed crescentic glomerular lesions suggestive of RPGN. Immunofluorescence findings are given in the image below. Which type of RPGN is this condition classified as?

RPGN - Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the immunofluorescence showing a linear, smooth diffuse pattern of staining is suggestive of Goodpasture syndrome, which is classified under type I RPGN.

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical entity with features of nephritic syndrome and rapid loss of renal function. It is a syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and the formation of crescents, but it does not denote a specific etiologic form of glomerulonephritis.

In most cases, RPGN is immune-mediated. Circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are detected in the pauci-immune type of RPGN. Serum analyses for anti-GBM antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, and ANCAs are helpful in the diagnosis of specific subtypes

Based on immunologic findings, RPGN is classified as:

Anti-GBM antibody-mediated disease (Type I) is characterized by linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence and includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. Here, the antibodies are produced against a peptide present in the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM. This serves as the antigen which is common to the alveoli and the glomerulus.

Immune complex deposition (Type II) is characterized by granular deposits of antibodies and complement on immunofluorescence and can be a complication of any of the immune complex nephritides which include:

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • Lupus nephritis
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura

Pauci-immune (Type III) exhibits no characteristic immunoglobulin or complement deposits on immunofluorescence. It includes

  • ANCA-associated
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Microscopic polyangiitis

Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease affecting men more than women, with simultaneous hemorrhagic interstitial pneumonitis and rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis. The GBM antigen is a component of the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of type IV collagen, which is common to both alveoli and glomeruli.

On microscopy, the renal biopsy shows show linear GBM fluorescence for Ig and complement. Electron microscopy (EM) shows the wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal disruptions without any immune complex deposition.

questions.text: You are posted in the general surgery ward as an intern where you are learning wound management and dressing. For each patient with a wound, you are to calculate the ASEPSIS score. Which of the following will you not be taking into consideration while calculating this score?
questions.solution:
ASEPSIS wound score does not take bleeding from the wound into consideration.

The ASEPSIS wound score and Southampton wound score are used to determine the severity of the surgical site wound infection (SSI).

ASEPSIS score includes:

  • Additional treatment
    • Antibiotics for wound infection
    • Drainage of pus under local anesthesia
    • Debridement of the wound under general anesthesia
  • Serous discharge
  • Erythema
  • Purulent exudate
  • Separation of deep tissue
  • Isolation of bacteria from the wound
  • Stay as inpatient prolonged over 14 days as a result of wound infection

questions.text: A 15-year-old child was brought with visible burns on his chest, upper limbs, and lower limbs. He complained of nausea, headache, and a change in voice. SpO2 is 84% and ABG revealed PaO2 of 50 mmHg. He was started on I.V. fluids. What is the next best step in his management?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of a possible scald injury to the airways. The next best step would be to secure the airway using an endotracheal tube.

Prompt intubation should be done before the features of laryngeal edema, such as a change in voice, stridor, anxiety, and respiratory difficulty, develop. A cricothyroidotomy might be needed if intubation fails. Because of this, early intubation of suspected airway burns is the treatment of choice in such patients.

The time frame from burn to airway occlusion is usually between 4 to 24 hours.

Recognition of the potentially burned airway:

  • A history of being trapped in the presence of smoke or hot gases
  • Burns on the palate or nasal mucosa, or loss of all the hairs in the nose
  • Deep burns around the mouth and neck

questions.text: The sleep disorder that occurs during REM sleep is __________
questions.solution:
Nightmares occur during REM sleep.

Nightmares are frightening or terrifying dreams that produce sympathetic stimulation and awakens the person. They occur in REM sleep and are usually associated with lengthy and complex dreams that gradually become more frightening. They commonly occur in children in the age group 3 to 6 years and are rare in adults. 

Night terrors (Option B) are characterized by abrupt arousal from sleep. They occur during stages 3 and 4 of NREM sleep.

The person who is aroused by nighmares usually remembers the dreams, whereas a person having nigh terrors cannot recall the dreams. 

Other options: 

Option A: Sleep walking occurs during NREM sleep. 

Option C: Bruxism most commonly occurs during stage 2 of NREM sleep.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with HELLP syndrome. The treating obstetrician grades the severity of this condition using the Mississippi classification. This classification includes all of the following parameters, except _______.
questions.solution:
The Mississippi classification includes all the following parameters, except bilirubin. 

The parameters included in the Mississippi classification are: 

  • Platelet count
  • Serum LDH
  • Alanine transaminase

HELLP is an acronym for hemolysis (H), elevated liver enzymes (EL), and low platelet count (LP). It usually occurs in patients with severe preeclampsia. The patients typically present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. Hypertension and proteinuria are seen but may be absent in some cases.

In this condition, there is periportal necrosis of the liver, causing an elevation in  the levels of liver enzymes (AST, ALT, and LDH) and bilirubin. Microangiopathic hemolysis manifests as

  • Elevated serum LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) levels
  • Reduced haptoglobin levels
  • Presence of schizocytosis, spherocytosis, and reticulocytosis on peripheral blood smear

Tennessee criteria are used for the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome, while the Mississippi classification system is used to grade the condition. 

  • Tennessee criteria for diagnosis of true/complete HELLP
    • Platelet count <1 lakh/mm3
    • AST >70 IU/L, 
    • LDH >600 IU/L
  • Mississippi classification divides HELLP into 3 grades based on the platelet count, serum LDH, and ALT levels.

Prompt delivery is indicated for ≥34 weeks of gestational age. Cesarean section is the common mode of delivery. Platelet transfusion is required if counts are less than 50,000/mm3. Magnesium sulfate is given as antiseizure prophylaxis, and anti-hypertensives are given for severe hypertension.

HELLP syndrome can also be associated with other complications such as eclampsia, placental abruption, stroke, coagulopathy, and pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus. She has a history of chronic kidney disease. Which of the following statement is correct about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Metformin is contraindicated in all stages of CKD
Pioglitazone is avoided as it is exclusively metabolized by kidneys
Glipizide can be used even in severe renal disease
Linagliptin can be used only after dose reduction

questions.solution:
Among the given statements, the correct one is glipizide can be used even in severe renal disease. Glipizide is the only sulfonylurea class of oral hypoglycemic agent that can be safely used without dose adjustment even in severe and moderate renal disease.

In patients with chronic kidney disease, glucose metabolism is disturbed. The circulating insulin levels are mildly elevated in patients with uremia as there is reduced degradation by the kidneys.

Drug therapy Usage in CKD
Insulin
  • Progressive dose reduction is needed according to the declining GFR.
Metformin
  • Metformin can be used in stages I and II with frequent renal function monitoring.
  • When GFR becomes less than half of the normal, it should be stopped
Pioglitazone
  • It undergoes hepatic metabolism exclusively and can be used without dose adjustment at all stages of CKD.
  • Pioglitazone is related to fluid retention, anemia, and osteoporosis as side effects and can potentially exacerbate bone loss due to renal osteodystrophy. 
Sulfonylureas
  • Should be used with caution and appropriate dose adjustments due to the risk of hypoglycemia.
  • Glipizide however can be used in CKD with no dose reductions as it does not lead to the production of any active metabolites that are cleared by the kidney. 
Dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP-4) inhibitors
(gliptins)
  • These can be used in all stages of CKD with dose adjustment except for Linagliptin (no dose adjustment needed in all stages)

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with severe cyanosis and respiratory distress. A chest X-ray was done as shown below. Which of the following subtypes of this condition causes maximum pulmonary venous obstruction?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with the X-ray showing a snowman appearance of the heart is suggestive of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC). The infracardiac type causes maximum pulmonary venous obstruction.

In the infracardiac variety of TAPVC, the common pulmonary vein drains to the portal vein instead of joining the left atrium. The pulmonary vein gets obstructed as it enters the diaphragm through the esophageal orifice.

TAPVC is a congenital cardiac malformation where pulmonary veins return to the right atrium or systemic venous circulation instead of draining directly to the left atrium.

According to the site of anomalous connection, the TAPVC can be divided into four subtypes:

  1. Supracradiac (Most common)
  2. Cardiac
  3. Infracardiac
  4. Mixed

Percentage of obstruction in different types of TAPVC:

Type of TAPVC  % with significant obstruction 
Infracardiac 95-100
Supracardiac 40-75
Cardiac 5-10
Mixed -

Neonates with severe obstruction to pulmonary venous return (infracardiac group) present with severe cyanosis and respiratory distress. Murmurs may be absent on cardiac examination.

Children with mild or no obstruction to pulmonary venous return (supracardiac or cardiac) develops heart failure due to a fall in pulmonary vascular resistance. They are associated with systolic murmurs.

In the supracardiac variety, the anomalous pulmonary veins enter the innominate vein and persistent left super vena cava. As a result, a large supracardiac shadow can be seen with normal cardiac shadow and gives a characteristic pattern of snowman appearance/ figure of 8 in the chest.

The image given below shows x-ray findings seen in the supracardiac variety of TAPVC.


A 2D echocardiography and doppler are used for the diagnosis of TAPVC where it fails to demonstrate draining of pulmonary vein to the left atrium. The right atrium and right ventricle are often enlarged. ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy.

TAPVC is treated by emergent surgical correction. If surgery cannot be performed urgently, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation may be required to maintain oxygenation.

questions.text: A young man presented with a single painless ulcer on the genitalia without any lymph nodes enlargement. Microscopic examination of a smear from the lesion showed the following finding. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
The causative organism is Klebsiella granulomatis. The image shows Donovan bodies in a WBC showing closed-safety pin appearance. This finding along with the clinical presentation is suggestive of granuloma inguinale/ donovanosis.

Granuloma inguinale, or donovanosis, is a sexually transmitted chronic inflammatory disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a minute, encapsulated, Coccobacillus.

The incubation period varies from 8-80 days, the average being 50 days.

 Four types of lesions have been described in this condition:

  • Ulcerogranulomatous - most common type with painless beefy red ulcers. They are also highly vascular and bleed on touch.
  • Hypertrophic - usually with a raised irregular edge
  • Necrotic - offensive smelling ulcer that causes tissue destruction
  • Sclerotic or cicatricial - with fibrous or scar tissue

Primary lesions can occur on genital and extragenital sites. Lesions are not usually accompanied by lymphadenopathy, but subcutaneous extension of granulo­mas may mimic enlarged lymph nodes (called pseudobuboes). 

The diagnosis is usually made by microscopic presence of Donovan bodies in Wright/Giemsa-stained impression smears. They appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces inside large mononuclear cells. They show bipolar condensation of chromatin giving a closed safety-pin appearance.

Treatment consists of prolonged antibiotic therapy, for a period of 6 weeks with oral azithromycin (1st line), or oral doxycycline (2nd line).

questions.text: A child is brought to the outpatient department with a port-wine nevus on the face and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas. On radiological examination, the given appearance of the skull is seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image of the skull showing tram track sign (gyriform calcification in a curvilinear pattern), along with the history of port-wine nevus and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas point to a diagnosis of Sturge Weber syndrome.

Sturge–Weber syndrome is characterized by a port-wine nevus (along the course of the trigeminal nerve) on the face and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas. It is a congenital syndrome.

There is an increased risk of seizures and intracranial calcifications in the child before 2 years of age. There may be associated hemiparesis, stroke-like episodes, headaches, and developmental delay. The ocular findings commonly associated are choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia, visual field defects, and ipsilateral glaucoma.

Images show port-wine stain associated with Sturge–Weber syndrome.


Features of MRI brain include

  • Pial angioma is seen as a diffuse pial enhancement of variable thickness.
  • Enlargement of the ipsilateral choroid plexus and dilatation of transparenchymal veins that communicate between the superficial and deep cerebral venous systems 

MRI and CT show intracranial calcification respectively. The tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cerebral cortex.


Other options:

Option A: Moya-moya disease is characterized by dilatation of collateral vessels resulting from stenosis of the internal carotid artery appearing as puff of smoke pattern on angiography.

Option C: Von Hippel Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant multiorgan disorder characterized by cerebellar and retinal hemangioblastomas and pheochromocytomas with an increased risk of developing renal cell carcinomas.

Option D: Tuberous sclerosis is a multi-system neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angiomyolipomas, cysts in kidneys, multiple hamartomas, giant cell astrocytomas, and cortical tubers.

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: The biopsy from an indurated plaque-like lesion is shown below. Keeping the diagnosis in mind, all of the following are premalignant lesions of this condition, except:
questions.solution:
The above image shows malignant cells resembling normal squamous epithelial cells with individual cell keratinization and nests of keratin pearls suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Keratoacanthoma is considered a form of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, not a premalignant condition.

Primary cutaneous SCC is a malignant tumor arising from epidermal keratinocytes or their appendages. The white population and people more than 85 years of age are at a greater risk of developing primary cutaneous SCC. Often, mutations of TP53 caused by ultraviolet rays leading to the formation of pyrimidine dimers are seen in SCC. HPV infection also predisposes to a greater risk of developing SCC

SCC often arises in photodamaged skin as a firm plaque‐like, verrucous ulcerated lesion. The lesion is surrounded by induration that usually extends beyond the visible margin of the lesion. 

SCCs with high‐risk features have a greater potential for local invasion and developing metastases. The clinical features of a high-risk SCC are summarised below:

  • Diameter of lesion greater than 2 cm
  • State of immunosuppression
  • SCC over the ear, lip, eyelid, and scalp.
  • SCC arising in burns, scars, chronic ulceration, and radiation damage

First-line treatment employs surgical techniques such as:

  • Curettage and cautery for low-risk SCC
  • Surgical excision for high-risk SCC. 

Option A: Actinic keratosis is characterized by hyperkeratotic lesions that have a low risk of progression to invasive SCC.

Option B: Bowen disease is a form of intraepidermal (in situ) SCC. It characteristically presents as persistent, non‐elevated, plaque(red, scaly, or crusted). It has a small potential for invasive malignancy. 

Option C: Arsenical keratosis: A corn‐like, punctate keratosis caused by arsenic, characteristically affecting the palms and soles, which may progress to squamous cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma

  • UV exposure
  • Male sex- due to more sun exposure
  • Environmental factors-
    1. Psoralen and UVA (PUVA)
    2. Physical agents such as ionizing radiation
    3. Chemical agents such as arsenics
  • HPV-16 & 18
  • Immunosuppression 
  • Smoking
  • Chronic nonhealing wounds, burn scars, and chronic dermatosis
  • Hereditary conditions such as xeroderma pigmentosum, epidermolysis bullosa, and oculo-cutaneous albinism
  • Premalignant conditions like actinic keratosis, Bowen’s disease, erythroplasia of Queyrat

questions.text: A 60 year old female patient came with complaints of  a sudden, intense urge to urinate followed by an involuntary loss of urine. Which of the following drugs cannot be used for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of urge incontinence and bethanechol is not used for the management of this condition. It is a muscarinic agonist that activates M1, M2, and M3 receptors and causes smooth muscle contraction. It is mainly used in post-operative and neurogenic ileus and urinary retention.

Mirabegron is a β3-adrenergic receptor agonist which is used for bladder incontinence. Activation of this receptor in the bladder leads to detrusor muscle relaxation and increased bladder capacity. This action prevents voiding and provides relief for those with an overactive bladder and urinary incontinence. (Option A)

Oxybutynin and solifenacin are muscarinic antagonists that increase bladder capacity by blocking M3 receptors on the detrusor. This results in the relaxation of the bladder. Tolterodine also shows a preference for muscarinic receptors in the bladder. (Option C and D)

The effects of muscarinic antagonists on the bladder are:

  • Lowering of intravesicular pressure
  • Increases bladder capacity
  • Lower the frequency of bladder contractions
  • Alter bladder sensation during filling

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, vomiting, and watery diarrhea. He gives a history of having consumed shellfish and raw seafood a day before. The causative agent showed Kanagawa phenomenon on Wagatsuma agar. Which of the following statements is true regarding the organism implicated here?

choices.text: It shows bipolar staining on microscopy
On thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) agar, it produces yellow colonies
Causes enteritis by producing cholera toxin

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of gastroenteritis, along with culture findings of the Kanagawa phenomenon on Wagatsuma agar, is suggestive of infection with Vibrio parahaemolyticus. It shows bipolar staining. 

Some other organisms showing bipolar staining (safety pin appearance) include:

  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei
  • Klebsiella granulomatis

V. parahaemolyticus causes food poisoning due to the consumption of contaminated seafood, after an incubation period of 12–24 hours. The common sources of infection are raw seafood like mollusks and crustaceans. No enterotoxin like cholera toxin (Option C) has been identified, it cause enteritis by invasion of the intestinal epithelium.

Clinically, patients present with nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, and watery or bloody diarrhea. Fecal leukocytes are often seen in stool samples. Enteritis subsides spontaneously in 1–3 days with no specific treatment. Adequate hydration and electrolyte balance should be restored.

V. parahaemolyticus is a capsulated bacterium. It shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. It is characterized by peritrichous flagella on solid media and polar flagella on liquid media and it gives a positive string test (Option D).

Pathogenic strains of V. parahemolyticus are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This is called the Kanagawa phenomenon and is due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

V. parahaemolyticus grows well on blood agar, where it is identified by its oxidase-positive growth. On thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) agar (Shown in the image below), it produces green colonies, unlike V. cholera colonies that are yellow in color (Option B).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of sudden-onset fever for the past 2 months. She says that the fever lasts for 3-4 days, subsides for a few days, and recurs again. Clinical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly with mild tenderness. The image below shows the vector responsible for transmitting this infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing body louse, Pediculus humanus corporis suggest epidemic relapsing fever. It is caused by the bacteria Borrelia recurrentis. 

Relapsing fever is an arthropod-borne infection due to Borrelia species. It can be of two types: 

  • Louse-borne or epidemic relapsing fever acquired from head or body louse and caused by Borrelia recurrentis
  • Tick-borne or endemic relapsing fever acquired from soft ticks. It is caused by Borrelia hermsii, Borrelia duttonii, and Borrelia parkeri (options A, C, and D)

Patients with relapsing fever present with sudden onset of fever that persists for 3–5 days and then subsides. The afebrile period lasts 4–10 days and is followed by a second attack of fever, chills, rigors, intense headache, and malaise.

During the febrile stages, organisms are present in the blood. During the afebrile periods, they are absent. It may be associated with jaundice and hemorrhages.

Treatment of relapsing fever includes tetracycline, chloramphenicol, penicillin, and erythromycin.

questions.text: Metformin acts via which pathway?

choices.text: JAK-STAT (Janus kinase/signal transducers and activators of transcription)

questions.solution:
The central pharmacological action of metformin is mainly mediated through activation of  AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) and the altering of the energy dynamics at mitochondrial respiration. 

AMPK is a cellular energy sensor that is activated when intracellular ATP levels are low. AMPK activation leads to many metabolic changes, including:

  • Increased glucose uptake and metabolism
  • Decreased hepatic glucose production
  • Decreased lipogenesis
  • Increased lipolysis

Metformin is a first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus. It is also used in the treatment of obesity and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Side effects of metformin are lactic acidosis, gastrointestinal disturbance, and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Contraindications for metformin include :

  • Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) <30 ml/min
  • Unstable congestive heart failure (CHF)
  • Radiographic contrast studies
  • Hospitalized patients who cannot take anything orally
  • Acidosis

Other options:

Option B: Growth hormone primarily acts by activating the JAK-STAT signalling pathway.

Option C:  Pioglitazone is a selective agonist of nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR).  It modulates the expression of genes involved in lipid and glucose metabolism, insulin signal transduction and adipocyte differentiation. These effects increase the sensitivity of the tissues to insulin.

Option D: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that also stimulates insulin secretion. They bind to a specific site on the β cell K-ATP channel complex and inhibit its activity. This causes the cell membrane to depolarize and leads to a cascade of events resulting in insulin secretion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with hepatitis B presents with multiple joint pain, abdominal pain, and discoloration in both hands as shown below.  On examination, his BP was 150/100 mmHg. Vessel biopsy showed fibrinoid necrosis and luminal thrombosis. ANCA is absent. Which of the following can be a possible diagnosis of the above condition?
questions.solution:
A history of hepatitis B, now presenting with multiple joint pain, abdominal pain, hypertension, and Raynaud's phenomenon, is suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) in this patient. ANCA being negative favors this diagnosis.

The microscopic examination of PAN shows segmental, transmural necrotizing inflammation. PAN primarily affects the small- and medium-sized arteries. The kidney, heart and GIT vessels are the most commonly involved ones. Lesions usually involve only part of the vessel circumference, and have a predilection for branch points. Because of these lesions, there can be impaired perfusion to the distal organs, resulting in infarcts and ischemic atrophy. 

During the acute phase, there is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall and fibrinoid necrosis as shown in the image below. The phase of acute inflammation can also be complicated by thrombosis. Older lesions show fibrous thickening of the vessel wall extending into the adventitia. All the stages of the disease activity (acute to chronic) are often present in the same vessel. 

Patients typically present with hypertension (due to renal artery involvement) and abdominal pain and bloody stools (due to involvement of the GIT blood vessels). One-third of the patients with PAN have chronic hepatitis B.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman undergoes in vitro fertilization (IVF) and successfully implants an embryo on the third day after fertilization. Based on this information, what is the estimated date of delivery (EDD) from the date of embryo transfer?
questions.solution:
The estimated date of delivery (EDD) from the date of embryo transfer in this scenario is approximately 38 weeks.

In pregnancies conceived through in vitro fertilization (IVF), Naegele's rule, which determines EDD based on the last menstrual period (LMP), cannot be applied. Instead, the EDD is calculated based on the date of embryo transfer.

If the embryo transfer is done 

  • on the day of fertilisation (day 0): EDD = Date of embryo transfer + 266 days. (This calculation assumes the embryo was transferred on the same day as fertilisation.)
  • 3 days after fertilisation (day 3): EDD = Date of embryo transfer + 263 days. (This is applicable when the embryo was allowed to develop for 3 days in the laboratory before transfer.)
  • 5 days after fertilisation (day 5): EDD = Date of embryo transfer + 261 days (This is used when the embryo was allowed to develop for 5 days (blastocyst stage) before transfer.)

These calculations are adjusted because the human embryo typically takes approximately 266 days from fertilization to develop fully. Therefore, the EDD in IVF pregnancies is based on the date of embryo transfer rather than the LMP.

questions.text: Which of the following markers are seen in Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkins lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Markers expressed in lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s lymphoma are CD15-,CD30- ,CD 20 +, EBV -ve. 

Reed-Sternberg cell (RS cell) is the characteristic tumor giant cell of Hodgkin Lymphoma. It is derived from the germinal center B cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus, with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space.

The image given below shows the diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cell, with two nuclear lobes, large inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm, surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and an eosinophil. 


There are five types of Hodgkin’s lymphoma and each has a variant of RS cells and expresses different Cluster of Differentiation.They are:

  • Nodular sclerosis - Lacunar variant RS cell ; CD15+,CD30+ , EBV -ve
  • Mixed cellularity - Mononuclear  variant RS cell ; CD15+,CD30+ , EBV +ve
  • Lymphocyte-rich -  Mononuclear variant RS cell ; CD15+,CD30+ , EBV +ve
  • Lymphocyte depletion - Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified variant RS cell ; CD15+,CD30+ , EBV +ve
  • Lymphocyte predominant - L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn variant RS cell ; CD15-,CD30- ,CD 20 + EBV -ve

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence. 

Related Pearl: Variants of Reed Sternberg Cells

  • Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich 
  • Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 
  • L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

FIGO - International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics
questions.solution:
The given CT abdomen showing a dilated pelvicalyceal system is suggestive of hydronephrosis of the right kidney and thus, cervical cancer with hydronephrosis is classified as Stage III B according to FIGO staging.

    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement

questions.text: A 35-year-old factory worker presents to the OPD with severe back pain following a workplace injury involving heavy lifting. He is diagnosed with a lumbar disc herniation at L4-L5 on MRI. The patient is employed in an industry covered under ESIC and has worked there for 3 years. What is covered under the extended sickness benefits for this employee under ESIC?

choices.text: 70% of daily wages per day for a period of 91 days
Permanent life pension decided by medical board
Extended cash benefits for a period of 2 years
Vocational rehabilitation services for up to 3 years.

questions.solution:
The extended benefits and duration of entitlement that the employee can expect under ESIC for his condition is extended cash benefits for a period of 2 years.

Extended sickness benefits are available to insured individuals under the ESI scheme who suffer from specific chronic illnesses. This benefit extends beyond the initial 91-day sickness leave entitlement, providing coverage for up to 2 years. During this period, beneficiaries receive approximately 80% of their average daily wages.

To qualify, the insured person must have a continuous employment history of at least 2 years. Intervertebral disc herniation is among the 34 listed diseases eligible for extended sickness benefits under this scheme.

Under the sickness benefit of the ESIC Act, an employee gets a daily payment amounting to approximately 70% of the average daily wage. This benefit is payable for a maximum of 91 days within any continuous period of 365 days. To qualify for sickness benefits, the insured person must remain under medical treatment provided under the Act and must have contributed for at least 78 days during a contribution period of 6 months.

Note: 70% of daily wages per day for a period of 91 days is not part of the extended sickness benefits for the employee under ESIC.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: Following are 2 histology slides of types of bone with their respective gross image attached to the right. Which of the following statements are correct?

choices.text: Image 1 : Cortical bone → marker B ; Image 2: Cancellous bone → marker A
Image 1 : Cortical bone → marker A ; Image 2 : Cancellous bone → marker B
Image 1 : Cancellous bone → marker A ; Image 2 : Cortical bone → marker B
Image 1 : Cancellous bone → marker B ; Image 2 : Cortical bone → marker A

questions.solution:
Image 1 is a  Cortical bone found in the cortex of long bones(marked B).

Image 2 is a  Cancellous bone found at the ends towards the medulla of long bones(marked A). 

Both cortical and cancellous bones are lamellar bones microscopically. In cancellous bones, the lamellae are arranged in piles, whereas in cortical bone, the lamellae are arranged concentrically as a Haversian system. 

The ends of long bones are made of cancellous bone, in which the red marrow persists. The cortex in the shaft of long bones is made of cortical bone conferring a degree of strength for mechanical strain.

questions.text: Preganglionic fibers originating from the inferior salivatory nucleus will pass through ______.
questions.solution:
Preganglionic fibers originating from the inferior salivatory nucleus will pass through otic ganglion.

The preganglionic fibers of otic ganglion originate in the inferior salivatory nucleus and join the glossopharyngeal nerve and its tympanic branch. They travel via the tympanic plexus, lesser petrosal nerve, and pass through the foramen ovale and synapse in the otic ganglion. Postganglionic fibers give communicating branches to the auriculotemporal nerve, which supplies to the parotid gland. When the lesser petrosal nerve is stimulated, it produces vasodilator and secretomotor effects.


Other options:

Option A: Preganglionic fibers originating from the Edinger–Westphal nucleus will pass through the ciliary ganglion.

Option C and D: Preganglionic fibers originating from the superior salivatory nucleus will pass through the pterygopalatine ganglion and submandibular ganglion.

questions.text: According to the  updated VVM guidelines on the oral Rotavac vaccine , which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Vaccine Vial Monitor for Rotavac is located on the label of the vaccine vial
Open vial policy applies to both the old and new products of the Rotavac vaccine
Vaccine schedule has been changed to a 2-dose schedule at 6 weeks and 10 weeks
Rotavac must be stored at -25°C to -10°C at the district level and 2°C to 8°C at the sub-district level

questions.solution:
Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW) has updated VVM guidelines on the oral Rotavac vaccine to change the location of the Vaccine Vial Monitor(VVM), which was initially on the cap of the vial, to the label of the vaccine vial.

The open vial policy is applicable only to this new product of the Rotavac vaccine. Implementation of the Open Vial Policy allows the reuse of partially used multi-dose vials of applicable vaccines under the universal immunization policy to prevent wastage of medication.

The vaccine schedule will remain the same, that is a 3-dose schedule at 6 weeks, 10 weeks, and 14 weeks. It is to be stored at -15°C to -25°C  till district stores and then at 2°C to 8°C at the sub-district level.

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant has a history of recurrent infections. Examination shows fair skin, sparse silver hair, and hepatosplenomegaly. CBC shows pancytopenia. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the LYST gene. What will be seen on a peripheral smear?

choices.text: Giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets
Rod shaped cytoplasmic inclusions in myeloblasts

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with LYST mutation on genetic analysis is suggestive of Chediak-Higashi syndrome in which peripheral smear shows giant granules in granulocytes and platelets. 

The image below is a peripheral smear in a patient of Chediak Higashi Syndrome showing a neutrophil with abundant giant intracytoplasmic granules:


Chediak-Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the LYST gene, which encodes the lysosomal trafficking regulator protein. This protein is crucial for the normal packaging and distribution of granules. The mutation leads to defects in chemotaxis, phagolysosome fusion, T-cell and NK cell degranulation, and ADP granule function in platelets.

Clinical Presentation of Chediak-Higashi Syndrome:

  1. Persistent Infections: Frequent skin, respiratory, and gastrointestinal infections, particularly due to Staphylococcus aureus.
  2. Partial Oculocutaneous Albinism: Reduced pigmentation of the skin, hair, and eyes.
  3. Platelet Dysfunction: Increased bleeding time causing easy bruising and excessive bleeding, despite a normal platelet count.
  4. Neurological Dysfunction: Progressive peripheral neuropathy, nystagmus, and mental retardation.
  5. Accelerated Phase: Characterized by a lymphoma-like illness and hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, a life-threatening condition marked by prolonged high fever, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and cytopenia, which has a poor prognosis.

Diagnosis:

  1. Microscopic Examination: Detection of peroxidase-positive giant primary granules in neutrophils and other granule-bearing cells using Wright’s stain.
  2. Genetic Testing: Confirmation through genetic detection of LYST gene mutations.

Other options:

Option A: Thrombocytopenia with small platelets seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

Option C: Rod-shaped cytoplasmic inclusions in myeloblasts are known as Auer rods and are seen in children with AML

Option D: Atypical lymphoid cells with "cerebriform" nuclei are seen in Mycosis-fungoides

questions.text:

Na+ : 118 mEq/L

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, low levels of cortisol and aldosterone indicates Addison's disease. The embryological derivative primarily contributing to this patient's affected layers of the adrenal gland is the intermediate mesoderm.

questions.text: Emptying of the stomach is inhibited by all of the following, except _____.
questions.solution:
Emptying of the stomach is not inhibited, but rather increased by the secretion of gastrin. Gastrin promotes emptying of the stomach by stimulating the motor functions of the stomach, especially the pyloric pump.

After food enters the duodenum, the duodenal entero-gastric nerve reflexes ensure the inhibition of emptying of the stomach. This mainly includes 3 pathways. They are, via the enteric nervous system directly from the duodenum, via extrinsic nerves that go to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia and then back through the sympathetic fibres to the stomach and finally via the vagus nerve that inhibits the excitatory signals to the stomach at the level of the brainstem. These reflexes inhibit the pyloric pump propulsive contractions and also increase the tone of the pyloric sphincter.

Gastrin is a hormone secreted by G cells located in the pyloric glands of the stomach. It is released into the blood, following which it is transported to the enterochromaffin-like cells of the stomach, resulting in the release of histamine, which stimulates gastric hydrochloric acid secretion.

Other options:

Option A: Increased acidity of chyme inhibits the emptying of the stomach by irritating the entero-gastric inhibitory reflexes of the duodenum. It prevents the subsequent release of stomach contents into the duodenum until the acidic chyme that is already present is neutralised.

Option B: Distension of the duodenum inhibits the emptying of the stomach via the enteric nervous system.

Option C: Cholecystokinin secretion decreases the motility of the stomach as a result of its inhibitory effect on gastrin. It is a hormone that is released from the mucosa of the jejunum and is sensitive to the presence of fats in the duodenum.
