questions.text: A primigravida attended to the antenatal clinic for the first time and was informed about a government scheme in which she will receive 5000 rupees cash in instalments for her first child. This benefit is given under which of the following schemes?
questions.solution:
A cash incentive of 5000 rupees is provided to all pregnant women and lactating mothers under Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY) for the first living child of the family. This is subject to fulfilment of specific conditions.

At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 home-based newborn care visits are provided under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative for women and newborns where assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare is provided free of cost.  It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths.

A cash incentive of 1400 rupees is provided to all pregnant women who underwent an institutional delivery in low-performing states under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY). This scheme is launched under NRHM (national rural health mission) to promote institutional delivery.

Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA). Under this scheme, all pregnant women will receive a free checkup on the 9th of every month. Under PMSMA, a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with symptoms of fever and pharyngitis following his return from a summer camp. On examination, you find signs of acute follicular conjunctivitis with tender and enlarged preauricular lymph nodes. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of pharyngoconjunctival fever. It is caused by adenovirus which is a non-enveloped, space-vehicle-shaped dsDNA virus.

Pharyngoconjunctival fever is an acute highly infectious illness caused by adenovirus serotypes 3 and 7. It occurs as outbreaks, in schools, summer camps, and prisons.

It presents as fever, pharyngitis, and acute follicular conjunctivitis with tender, enlarged preauricular adenopathy. The illness usually lasts for about 1-2 weeks followed by complete recovery.

Other illnesses caused by adenoviruses include-

  • Respiratory tract - Tonsillitis, pharyngitis, pneumonia.
  • Eyes - Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, acute follicular conjunctivitis.
  • Gastrointestinal tract - Acute viral gastroenteritis.
  • Urinary tract - Acute hemorrhagic cystitis. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. Tissue culture, serodiagnosis, and polymerase chain reaction for detection of viral DNA may be used.

Note: Adenoviruses are being used as gene delivery vehicles for cancer therapy and gene therapy. They are also used in oncolytic therapy aimed at directly killing tumor cells by viral lytic replication.

questions.text: While recording evidence in the court of law, the lawyer who had called the witness conducts an examination on the witness. He does this to clarify certain doubts and details raised in the cross-examination. What is this procedure called?
questions.solution:
The above procedure is called the re-direct examination.

Re-direct examination is the procedure done by the lawyer who summoned the witness to correct any mistake or clarify or add any details to the statements of the witness made during the cross-examination.

The witness is not allowed to provide any new matter at this stage. The opponent's lawyer will be allowed to do a re-cross examination (option D) on any new point raised in the re-direct examination. Leading questions are not allowed in re-direct examination.

The sequence of examination in the recording of evidence is as follows -

Sequence of Examination Objective

Examination-in-chief/direct examination (options A and B) by the party that summoned the witness 

To elicit the facts of the case from the witness.

Leading questions are not allowed.

Cross-examination by the defense lawyer

To elicit facts favorable to their case and test the reliability of the witness.

Leading questions are allowed.

Re-examination by the party that summoned the witness

 To resolve doubts that formed during cross-examination and re-emphasize the party's perspective.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby girl is being investigated for recurrent episodes of dermatitis. She develops blisters over the face, hands, and feet on exposure to sunlight. Parents report pinkish discoloration of the child's diapers. Characteristic "monkey-like" facies, delayed eruption and reddish discoloration of teeth are noted on examination.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an 18-month-old baby with characteristic monkey-like facies, blisters over the face, hands, and feet on exposure to sunlight, reddish discolouration of teeth, erythrodontia, and pink stain in diapers are seen in congenital erythropoietic porphyria. 

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria also known as Gunther's disease is autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth. Severe cutaneous photosensitivity is present. Uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulate in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocytes, plasma urine, and faeces.

Portwine urine or pink stain in diapers is seen. When illuminated with UV light, the teeth show a reddish fluorescence phenomenon known as erythrodontia (as shown in the image below).


Other options:

Option B: Porphyria cutanea tarda also presents as blistering photosensitivity but typically manifests in adults. Moreover, erythrodontia is not seen. It is the most common type of porphyria, which is caused by a deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase.

Option C: Erythropoietic protoporphyria presents as non-blistering photosensitivity, unlike in this case.

Option D: Acute intermittent porphyria presents with neurovisceral symptoms after puberty. It presents with abdominal pain and psychosis with no cutaneous features. It may be precipitated by drugs, decreased carbohydrate intake, and infections.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented to the ER with complaints of severe pain behind his chest bone associated with sweating and giddiness. He has a blood pressure of 86/54 mmHg. The electrocardiogram recorded is given below. Which of the following would be efficient management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG showing ST-segment elevation in Leads II, III, and aVF are suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. His vitals shows that he has hypotension and hence, the efficient management in this situation would be a brisk administration of fluids to combat the cardiogenic shock that would set in, if untreated.

Inferior wall MI mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery. While anterior wall infarction shows sympathetic nervous system hyperactivity (tachycardia and hypertension), the inferior wall MI shows parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and hypotension).

Sublingual nitroglycerine, intravenous morphine, and intravenous furosemide can reduce the preload and hence should be avoided in an MI complicated by hypotension.

In the setting of inferior wall infarction, signs of cardiogenic shock should prompt the suspicion of a right ventricular infarction. And the same can be evidenced by ST elevation in the right precordial leads (V4R, V5R, V6R). The diagnosis of right ventricular MI is suspected in patients with inferior-wall MI, clear lung fields (no added sounds onauscultation), and shock. If a right ventricular infarction is suspected, avoid nitrates and increase volume to ensure adequate preload. The right ventricle has less myocardium than the left and relies on adequate preload to function properly. If the right ventricle is damaged, preload reduction from nitrates may result in significant hypotension.

A 30-year-old female presents with a history of recurrent kidney stones and urinary tract infections. Urinary pH is >5.5 and urine anion gap is positive. CT urography reveals medullary cysts. Which of the following renal tubular acidosis is present in this patient?

CT - computed tomography
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of medullary sponge kidney (MSK) which is associated with type 1 renal tubular acidosis (RTA). MSK is characterized by recurrent episodes of UTIs and kidney stones, and medullary cysts on CT urography.

MSK is a congenital disorder affecting the formation of collecting tubules which results in cystic dilation of the medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts. MSK is a sporadic benign condition that is often diagnosed incidentally. It is characterized by medullary cysts that are of variable size.

It is commonly associated with type 1 (distal) RTA, characterized by impaired acid secretion in the distal nephron. This leads to the development of metabolic acidosis with a normal serum anion gap due to impaired urinary acidification. It is also associated with hypercalciuria. The hypercalciuria leads to a tendency to form calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones. The patients can also have recurrent UTIs and hematuria. Urinary anion gap is positive in these cases and urine pH is greater than 5.5.

CT urography shows cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules with a striated appearance and calcifications in the renal collecting system. It has largely replaced intravenous pyelography as the investigation of choice.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy with a normal physique presents with muscle cramps, tingling sensations. Laboratory investigations revealed hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and elevated serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. The response of PTH to urinary cAMP was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis with the above laboratory findings is pseudohypoparathyroidism type 2.

Pseudohypoparathyroidism is an inherited disorder characterized by hypocalcemia and distinctive skeletal abnormalities known as Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy(AHO) , which is absent only in case of PHP 2. This condition results from mutations that impair the function of the alpha subunit of the stimulatory G-protein Gsα. These mutations interfere with the action of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to decreased serum calcium levels and elevated serum phosphate levels. Features of AHO include short stature, shortened metacarpals and metatarsals (brachydactyly), a round facial appearance (round facies), cognitive impairment, and abnormal calcium deposits in soft tissues (heterotopic calcifications.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis had a flare-up of joint pain at 12 weeks of pregnancy which was managed with steroids. After tapering of steroids, which of the following is indicated for maintenance treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hydroxychloroquine is considered safe for use during pregnancy and can be used for maintenance treatment to control rheumatoid arthritis symptoms.

The majority of patients with rheumatoid arthritis experience overall improvement in symptoms during pregnancy, but flares may occur. Low dosages of prednisone are usually used to treat flares during pregnancy, and hydroxychloroquine and sulfasalazine are thought to be the safest disease-modifying antirheumatic medications (DMARDs).

Other options: 

Options A and C: Abatacept and leflunomide, which are common disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) for RA, are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their teratogenic effects.

Option D: There is insufficient experience regarding the use of biologics such as rituximab for rheumatoid arthritis during pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents after sustaining a slip and fall from a ladder. On examination, tenderness over the medial aspect of the ankle is seen. X-ray suggests a distal fibular fracture. Stress testing confirms instability with the eversion of the ankle joint. Which ligament is most likely injured here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an ankle fracture with deltoid ligament injury. 

Deltoid ligament or medial collateral ligament, is a strong triangular band, attached to the apex, the anterior and posterior borders of the medial malleolus. It has 2 layers, superficial and deep. The superficial layer consists of tibionavicular fibres anteriorly, tibiocalcaneal fibres in the middle, and superficial posterior tibiotalar fibres posteriorly. Deep layer consists of anterior tibiotalar fibres, tibiocalcaneal in the middle and deep posterior tibiotalar posteriorly. It is primarily responsible for maintaining stability on the medial aspect of the ankle. The deltoid ligament is extremely strong and stabilises the inside of the ankle. Tears of this ligament are seen when the ankle undergoes an unstable ankle fracture. 

Important ligaments of ankle present on the medial side, and therefore likely to be injured in eversion sprains include:

  • Deltoid ligament (Medial collateral ligament)
  • Spring ligament (calcaneonavicular ligament)

The image given below shows the ligaments attached to the medial side of ankle.


The anterior talofibular ligament is most commonly injured with inversion sprains. Important ligaments of ankle present on the lateral side, and therefore likely to be injured in inversion sprains include:

  • Anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) - most commonly injured
  • Posterior talofibular ligament (PTFL)
  • Calcaneofibular ligament (CFL)

questions.text: You were asked to assist with the tubal sterilization procedure during your residency. The senior resident performs the following type of sterilization procedure. This technique is known as ____
questions.solution:
The sterilization procedure which is shown in the above image is the Kroener technique.

It refers to fimbriectomy done by ligating the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures followed by division and removal of the infundibulum.

Other options:

Option A - Uchida's method

  • The tubal serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube, which is then excised.
  • The proximal end is ligated and buried in the broad ligament.
  • The minimal excision of the tube preserves the potential for tuboplasty.


Option B - Irving's procedure

  • The mid-portion of the tube is ligated and the intervening portion excised.
  • The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament.
  • It is a reliable method but irreversible and may require a laparotomy incision.


Option D - Pomeroy method

  • The most popular technique of tubal ligation is the Pomeroy operation.
  • The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient comes to the clinic repeatedly complaining of a persistent crawling sensation on his skin. He is convinced that he is infested with parasites, despite all medical evaluations showing normal results. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis would be Ekbom syndrome, also known as delusional parasitosis.

Ekbom syndrome is a psychiatric disorder in which the patient has a persistent delusional belief that they are infested with parasites or insects. This condition often leads to significant distress and persistent complaints, despite negative medical or imaging findings. 

Ganser syndrome is also known as hysterical pseudodementia, "Prison psychosis" or "Syndrome of approximate answers". It is a type of conversion/dissociative disorder. It is commonly found in prison inmates. The characteristic feature is vorbeireden, which is also called approximate answers. The answers are incorrect but are related to the question, showing that the person understands the nature of the question asked.

Cotard syndrome is characterised by nihilistic delusions where patients believe they are dead, do not exist, or have lost their internal organs. False beliefs that oneself, others, or the world, is non-existent or about to end also co-exist. However, it is not associated with a belief in infestation of the body.

Charles Bonnet syndrome involves visual hallucinations in visually impaired individuals. 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic woman presents with an ulcerative vulval lesion that bleeds. Biopsy confirms a diagnosis of vulvar carcinoma. The gynecologist is concerned about the involvement of lymph nodes. Which nodes are usually the first to be involved in such cases?
questions.solution:
The superficial inguinal lymph nodes are usually the first to be involved in vulvar carcinoma.

Vulval cancer is generally seen in elderly women and they present with vulvar pruritus, vulvar swelling, lump, or an ulcer. The lump is papular with a raised pigmented area. The ulcers have often everted margins with fissured, cracked, and indurated surrounding skin. They usually bleed and cause offensive vulval discharge. The lesions are most commonly seen over the labia major.  HPV or HIV infection, diabetes, hypertension, and obesity are associated with vulval cancers. 

The order of lymph node involvement in vulval cancer includes mainly the superficial inguinal lymph node, deep inguinal lymph node, and femoral group of lymph nodes. The external iliac, obturator, and common iliac nodes are also involved in the advanced stages.

Surgical morbidity in early vulval cancer can be reduced by restricting unnecessary lymph node dissection but it is necessary for the determination of the extent of primary lymph node (sentinel) involvement. Lymphatic mapping and sentinel node biopsy (frozen section) before or during surgery help to attain an adequate surgical procedure with a good prognosis.

Mapping is done by:

  • Intraoperative intradermal injection of blue dye around the tumor has reported a detection rate of 100%
  • Localization of radioactive tracer-labeled tissue with a hand-held detector
  • Lymphoscintigraphy also gives a 100% detection rate

For the treatment of vulval cancer in young women, conservative ablative surgery, as well as wide local excision, is adequate. A simple vulvectomy is performed in elderly women. Radical vulvectomy is recommended in patients with regional lymph node involvement.

The prognosis depends upon the lymph node status.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte imbalances causes a shortened QT interval?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is associated with a shortened QT interval.

Hypercalcemia can cause several changes on ECG, such as bradycardia, atrioventricular block, and short QT interval. The QT interval can be monitored to identify changes in serum calcium. 

Short QT intervals, defined as QTc <390 ms, are uncommon but are associated with a high risk of ventricular arrhythmias, atrial fibrillation, syncope, and sudden cardiac death. It is also rarely caused by inherited channelopathies.

In contrast, hypocalcemia is associated with prolonged QT interval. 

Other options: 

Option B: Hypernatremia is not associated with short QT interval. 

Option C and D: Hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia delay repolarization of ventricular muscle and hence cause prolongation of QT interval.

questions.text: A study was conducted on an experimental animal to demonstrate the change in breathing patterns with transections at different levels of the brainstem. Which of the following breathing pattern is most likely observed with a complete transection at midway between pons and medulla?

choices.text: Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases

questions.solution:
The most likely breathing pattern in the above scenario is irregular but rhythmic respiration.

Pre Botzinger complex in the medulla is responsible for rhythmic respiration. The pnuemotaxic center in the pons further modifies this rhythmic discharge and plays a role in switching between inspiration and expiration. So a complete transection at midway between pons and medulla causes irregular but rhythmic respiration.

 Respiratory centers of the brain:

  • Pre-Botzinger complex- This produces rhythmic and automatic respiration. Therefore damage to the medulla results in loss of spontaneous respiration.
  • Pneumotaxic centers- The rhythmic discharge produced by the pre-Botziger complex is further modified by the pneumotaxic centers. Stimulation of the pneumotaxic center results in an increase in the respiratory rate and a decrease in the tidal volume. 
  • Vagus nerve- Stretching of the lung initiates impulses in the pulmonary vagal fibers. These signals inhibit further inspiration. Therefore in vagotomy, the inspiration has not inhibited this results in increased depth of inspiration. There will also be prolonged inspiratory spasms that resemble breath-holding (apneusis)

Other options:

Option B- Apneusis occurs in a transection through mid pontine level with vagotomy.

Option C- Spontaneous respiration ceases in a complete transection through the medulla.

Option D- Regular breathing with deep inspiration occurs in complete transection above the pons.

A 68-year-old chronic smoker complains of cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain. Radiological investigations revealed a tumor arising from a major bronchus. Some cancer patients develop signs and symptoms that cannot be explained by the location of the cancer or its cells of origin. These are called paraneoplastic syndromes. questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with swelling of joints, a hoarse voice, and subcutaneous nodules. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly is seen. The child is diagnosed with Farber's disease. Which enzyme defect is responsible for this condition?

questions.text: All the following organisms would test positive for the reaction shown in the image below, except ______.
questions.solution:
The image given shows a slide with a positive catalase test. All the organisms mentioned above test positive for this test, except Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Catalase test is demonstrated by placing a microbial colony in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). The catalase enzyme degrades hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. The liberated O2 is seen as gas bubbles. The test is particularly useful in the differentiation of staphylococci (catalase-positive) from streptococci (catalase-negative).

questions.text: Which of the following proteins connects the lines marked as A and B (indicated by red arrows) in the following image?
questions.solution:
The above image is the electron microscope view of the muscle. Line A corresponds to the M line, and Line B corresponds to the Z line. The protein that connects the M line with the Z line is titin. 

Here is an image highlighting the various zones of a sarcomere.

The area between two Z-lines is called a sarcomere. 

Apart from proteins like actin, myosin, troponin, and tropomyosin, there are some additional structural proteins that are important for the function of the skeletal muscle:

  • Actinin - It binds actin to the Z lines.
  • Titin - It is the largest protein and connects the Z lines to the M lines.
  • Desmin - It connects Z lines to the plasma membrane.

Dystrophin connects actin filaments to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan in the sarcolemma by the smaller proteins syntrophins in the cytoplasm.

The troponin molecules are attached intermittently along the sides of the tropomyosin molecules. They have three loosely bound protein subunits:

  • Troponin I - It inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin T - It binds troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin C - It binds the calcium ions and initiates contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

Related Pearl: Sarcomere

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with a 2-month history of cough and shortness of breath is found to have bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on a chest X-ray. She also complains of dry eyes and nodules in the skin over her arms. Her lymph node biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following findings can be seen in the biopsy of her lesions?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a woman with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, a history of cough, dry eyes, nodules in the skin over her arms, and non-caseating granulomas on lymph node biopsy points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis. In this condition, Schaumann bodies can be seen on biopsy.

Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that most commonly presents as bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lesions of the eyes and skin are also very common in these patients. It is seen more in middle-aged women than in men.

Sarcoidosis results from an increase in CD4+ T-cells (increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio). As a result, cytokines like IL-2, TNF, IL-8, and IFN-gamma will increase. These cytokines are the cause of granuloma formation in this disorder.

It presents with granulomas in multiple organs. They are classically described as non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis as there would be in tubercular granulomas. Laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies (shown in the image below) and star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.

 

Other options:

Option (A): Birbeck bodies are tennis racket-shaped structures found in the Langerhans cells of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (shown in the image below). Although it can occur in adults, it is seen more commonly in children. Lesions similar to seborrheic eruptions are seen on the back, scalp, and trunk.

 

Option (B): Asbestos bodies are seen in asbestosis, which is an occupational disease that causes diffuse fibrosis of the lung parenchyma. These bodies are asbestos fibers covered by iron-containing substances during phagocytosis. Initially, patients will have irregular densities in the lower lobes. The advanced disease will show a honeycomb pattern on a chest x-ray. 

Option (C): Ferruginous bodies are also seen in asbestosis. They are other inorganic particles that are covered by iron-containing substances. This iron is thought to be derived from ferritin within macrophages.

An asbestos body can be seen in the image below:

questions.text: A young man is being evaluated for sudden painless loss of vision. His fundus fluorescein angiography findings are shown below. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The fundus fluorescein angiograqphy reveals ink-blot sign. This sign, along with sudden painless loss of vision, is diagnostic of central serous chorioretinopathy. The next step in management is reassurance. 

Central serous chorioretinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular area. The pigment retinal epithelium may or may not be detached. Risk factors for its development include young males, type A personalities, steroid intake, emotional stress, pregnancy, SLE and Cushing's disease.  

Patients present with sudden painless loss of vision. They may have positive scotomas, micropsia and metamorphosia. Fundus examination shows mild elevation of macula, grey-yellow elevations, absent foveal reflex and subretinal deposits. Fundus fluorescein angiography shows ink-blot pattern or smoke-stack pattern, as shown below. 


Treatment is majorly reassurance, since 80-90% of cases spontaneously resolve. Visual acuity returns to normal within 6 months. Steroids (option D) should be discontinued if the patient is taking them. 

In long standing cases (>3 months), recurrent cases or permanent loss of vision, laser photocoagulation (option B) is done. Photodynamic treatment (option C) is done in those patients in whom laser photocoagulation is contraindicated e.g. sub-foveal leaks.

questions.text: According to the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (IUBMB), to which class of enzymes does Glutamine synthetase belong?
questions.solution:
Glutamine synthetase is classified as a ligase according to the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (IUBMB).

Ligases are enzymes that catalyze the joining of two molecules with the concomitant hydrolysis of a diphosphate bond in ATP or a similar triphosphate. Glutamine synthetase catalyzes the ATP-dependent conversion of glutamate and ammonia to glutamine. This reaction involves the formation of a new covalent bond between glutamate and ammonia, making it a ligase enzyme. This activity is essential for nitrogen metabolism and the regulation of nitrogen levels in organisms.

questions.text: While performing an elective hernia repair, the surgeon notices that the sac contains both direct and indirect components. What is this type of hernia known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is that of a pantaloon hernia.

 A pantaloon hernia occurs when both a direct and an indirect hernia develop on the same side of the groin. The hernia is named pantaloon because the two hernia sacs are divided by epigastric vessels, and so they look like a pair of pants.

A sliding hernia occurs when an internal organ composes a portion of the wall of the hernia sac.

The most common viscus involved are as follows:

  • Left side: sigmoid colon and its mesentery
  • Right side: cecum

It is more common on the left side. Most sliding hernias are variants of indirect inguinal hernias. The primary danger associated with a sliding hernia is the failure to recognize the visceral component of the hernia sac resulting in injury to the bowel or bladder.

 A lumbar hernia is a posterolateral body wall hernia where the bowel, omentum, or pre-peritoneal fat herniates through the lumbar triangles. 

A Spigelian hernia occurs through slit-like defects in the anterior abdominal wall adjacent to the semilunar line. Most spigelian hernias occur in the lower abdomen where the posterior sheath is deficient. It is also called “spontaneous lateral ventral hernia” or “hernia of the semilunar line”.

questions.text:
A researcher is investigating the association between long-term use of a specific medication and the risk of developing CVD in a group of 10,000 patients with diabetes mellitus. After 5 years, 200 patients developed CVD. The researcher selects 400 controls from the same group who have not developed CVD. From these, the researcher identifies 100 controls who have been taking the medication of interest for at least 3 years. What study design is being used here?

(CVD - Cardiovascular diseases)
questions.solution:
The study design being used here by the researcher in investigating the association between long-term use of a specific medication and the risk of developing CVD is nested case-control study.

A nested case-control study is essentially a case control study that operates within a cohort study.

In this design, cases consist of cohort members who have developed the disease of interest. Each case is matched with one or more controls from the same cohort who have not developed the disease but are comparable to cases based on age and gender.

Researchers then analyse and compare the exposure histories of cases and controls to assess the association between the risk factor and the disease outcome. Nested case-control studies provide an interim analysis within the larger cohort study, focusing on specific exposures and outcomes of interest.

Other options :

Cross-sectional study provides a snapshot of a population at a single point in time to assess disease prevalence and distribution. It does not track individuals over time, making it unsuitable for understanding patient prognosis.

Case-control study starts with identified outcomes (cases) and looks backward to explore potential exposures. While useful for studying associations, it does not directly assess patient prognosis or disease progression.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A man presents with severe pain in his leg after he sustained a wound on his leg 3 days ago. Examination of the wound reveals foul-smelling discharge, hemorrhagic bullae, and necrosis. When a sample from the wound was cultured on egg yolk agar that was treated by an antitoxin on one half, opacities were not seen on the antitoxin-treated side. Which toxin is most likely responsible for this observed phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of gas gangrene. The most likely causative organism is Clostridium perfringens.

This bacterium produces the alpha toxin, a lecithinase, which, when cultured on egg yolk agar, causes a characteristic opalescent zone by breaking down lecithin in the egg yolk. The antitoxin-treated zone does not show opalescence due to the neutralization of the alpha toxin. This reaction is known as Nagler’s reaction.

Gas gangrene is a consequence of missile wounds and crush injuries. Following crush injuries, the clostridial spores gain access to the body. These spores germinate under anaerobic conditions and start producing toxins. The alpha toxin (lecithinase), destroys red and white blood cells, platelets, fibroblasts, and muscle cells. The kappa toxin destroys connective tissue and blood vessels.

Patients present with severe pain, swelling of the limb, serosanguinous foul-smelling discharge, bluish-black discolouration, soft tissue crepitus, and hemorrhagic bullae. Other signs such as pyrexia, tachycardia, tachypnea, and altered mental status may be seen. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. A peripheral blood smear can show hemolysis. Gram stain reveals gram-positive bacilli. Radiography is used to visualise gas in soft tissue.

Robertson-cooked meat media is used for the culture of anaerobic organisms like Clostridia. Management is by admission to the intensive care unit and administering high-dose penicillin G and clindamycin with intravenous third-generation cephalosporins. Surgical excision to remove the debrided tissue should be done.


Gamma, beta, and delta toxins are also produced by Clostridium perfringens, but they do not exhibit Nagler’s reaction.

questions.text: A health center is experiencing an increase in cases of nosocomial infections linked to contamination of the water used for patient care. To address this issue, the administration has decided to review its water treatment system. Which of the following methods would be most suitable for removing microbial contaminants quickly and efficiently by chemical coagulation and sedimentation?
questions.solution:
The most suitable method for removing microbial contaminants quickly and efficiently by chemical coagulation and sedimentation among the following is rapid sand filters.

Rapid sand filters are called mechanical filters. It is a method of large scale purification of water. Coagulation is the first step involved in rapid sand filters where raw water is treated with a chemical coagulant like alum, the dose of which varies from 5 to 40 mg or more per litre depending upon colour, turbidity, temperature, and pH value of the water.

 Comparison between rapid and slow sand filters: 

Property Rapid sand filter Slow sand filter
Space Less space Large area
Rate of filtration 200 m.g.a.d 2-3 m.g.a.d
Effective size of sand 0.4 - 0.7 mm 0.2 - 0.3 mm
Preliminary treatment Chemical coagulation and sedimentation Plain sedimentation
Washing Backwashing Scraping the sand bed
Operation Highly skilled Less skilled
Loss of head 2–2.5 m/6–8 feet 1.5 m/4 feet
Removal of turbidity Good Good
Removal of color Good Fair
Removal of bacteria 98 - 99 % 99.9 - 99.99 %

 


Berkefeld filter is used for the purification of water on a small scale (ex: in households). They primarily use physical filtration, ion exchange and adsorption.

Superchlorination of water is the addition of large amounts of chlorine to the water, for disinfection. The excess is later removed. It is done for heavily polluted water with fluctuating quality.

Related Pearl: Rapid Sand Filters

  • They are also called mechanical filters and are another method of large scale purification of water.
  • The two types of rapid sand filters are gravity type (e.g. Paterson’s filter) and pressure type (e.g. Candy’s filter).
  • Steps in the purification of water by rapid sand filters are:
    • Coagulation – Raw water is first treated with a chemical coagulant like alum.
    • Rapid mixing – The treated water then undergoes violent agitation in a mixing chamber which allows complete dissemination of alum throughout the bulk of the water.
    • Flocculation – Slow and gentle mixing of water in a flocculation chamber is done for 30 minutes. This results in a thick, copious flocculate of aluminium hydroxide.
    • Sedimentation – The coagulated water is moved into sedimentation tanks where detaining it for 2 – 6 hours will result in the settling down of the flocculent along with impurities and bacteria. This is to be removed before the filtration takes place.
    • Filtration – The partly purified water is then subjected to rapid sand filtration.
      • Filter beds: The effective size of the sand particles/grains is about 0.4 to 0.7 mm. The depth of the sand bed is about 1 metre and has graded gravel below it.
      • As the filtration is done, the alum-floc which has not precipitated is held back by the sand bed. This forms a layer which adsorbs bacteria and other impurities. When the loss of head in a rapid sand filter approaches 7 – 8 feet, the filter needs to be cleaned by a process known as backwashing.
      • Backwashing is done by reversing the flow of water through the sand bed. It dislodges the impurities and cleans the bed. Skilled labor is needed for this purpose.
    • Advantages of rapid sand filter:
      • Rapid sand filter does not need storage of water before it is treated.
      • It occupies less space when compared to slow sand filters.
      • Filtration is much more rapid than slow sand filters.
      • It is easy to wash and clean.
      • There is more flexibility in its operation.

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water:
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres.
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed:
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system:
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed is kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control:
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady-state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scraping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman experiences an increased frequency of micturition, with pain relieved by micturition and aggravated by overdistension of the bladder. Urine routine tests showed no pus cells; urine culture tested negative, and cystoscopy revealed fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa, with a characteristic appearance of ulcers, as shown in the image below. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable clinical diagnosis in the reported case is interstitial cystitis. The image shows Hunner's ulcers, which are characteristic of interstitial cystitis. 

Interstitial cystitis (i.e. a chronic pelvic pain syndrome or bladder pain syndrome) is a persistent, painful form of chronic cystitis, which occurs most frequently in women.

Clinical features

  • Severe suprapubic pain
  • Urinary frequency
  • Urgency
  • Hematuria
  • Dysuria without evidence of bacterial infection

Ulcerations of the mucosa occur in the fundus of the bladder (Hunner's ulcer). It is characterized by marked submucosal edema of the bladder with mucosal ulceration, which is seen in the late phase of interstitial cystitis.

In the cystoscopic examination, fissures and punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) are seen in the bladder mucosa.

Microscopy shows mucosal ulcers covered by fibrin and necrotic material and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells.

Late in the course, transmural fibrosis may appear, leading to a contracted bladder.

The pathologic findings are nonspecific, and the main role of biopsy is to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may mimic interstitial cystitis clinically.

Treatment is difficult and unsatisfactory. Hydrostatic dilatation under anesthesia may give relief for some months. Intravesical instillation of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) results in an improvement in some patients. Other treatments that have been considered in interstitial cystitis include intravesical heparin, oral ranitidine, and steroid therapy.

Other options:

Malakoplakia (Option B) is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It has the following features:

  • Chronic inflammatory reaction, commonly affecting the urinary bladder, is seen due to acquired defects in phagocyte function.
  • It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and CNS.
  • Malakoplakia is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species.  
  • Grossly, malakoplakia takes the form of soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques, often misdiagnosed clinically as malignancy.
  • Microscopically, they are composed of large, foamy macrophages mixed with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes.
  • The macrophages have an abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with undigested bacterial products.
  • In addition, intracellular deposition of calcium and iron within enlarged lysosomes forms laminated basophilic concretions, known as Michaelis–Gutmann bodies, pathognomonic of malakoplakia.

 The following image shows the Michaelis–Gutmann bodies marked in black arrows.


Tubercular cystitis (Option-C):

Tuberculous urinary infection is secondary to renal tuberculosis. Early tuberculosis of the bladder starts around the ureteric orifice or trigone, the earliest evidence being pallor of the mucosa due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen and, in long-standing cases, marked fibrosis is seen, and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced. 

Thimble bladder is classically seen in tubercular cystitis. 


Polypoid cystitis (Option D): 

  • Polypoid cystitis is an inflammatory lesion resulting from the irritation of the bladder mucosa.
  • Although indwelling catheters are the most commonly cited culprits, any injurious agent may give rise to this lesion.
  • The urothelium is thrown into broad bulbous polypoid projections as a result of marked submucosal edema.
  • Polypoid cystitis may be confused with papillary urothelial carcinoma both clinically and histologically.

The given image below shows polypoid cystitis showing broad polypoid growth, prominent blood vessels, and metaplastic urothelium in H&E stain.

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

questions.text: A boy presents with complaints of intermittent low-grade fever and membrane over the left tonsil, which appeared insidiously. On examination of the oral cavity, the surgeon tried to remove the membrane, which came off easily revealing an irregular ulcer over the tonsil. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of low-grade fever, easily removable membrane over tonsil revealing irregular ulcers is suggestive of Vincent’s angina.

The condition presents with low-grade fever and sore throat, and a membrane over the tonsil. The membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcers over the tonsil. A throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes, specifically Borrelia vincentii.

Other Options:

Option A: Diphtheria is slower in onset with less local discomfort. In the above case, the membrane is removed easily but in diphtheria, the membrane is adherent and its removal leaves a bleeding surface. The membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils, onto the soft palate, and is dirty grey in color. The smear and culture of the throat swab will reveal Corynebacterium diphtheriae.


Option C: In Infectious mononucleosis, pharyngitis is the most prominent sign, with an exudate resembling that of streptococcal pharyngitis. Both tonsils are very much enlarged, congested, and covered with an exudative membrane. There is marked local discomfort. Lymph nodes are enlarged in the posterior triangle of the neck along with splenomegaly. There is the failure of antibiotic treatment. A blood smear may show more than 50% lymphocytes, of which about 10% are atypical. Paul-Bunnell test will show high tires of heterophile antibody.

Option D: Aphthous ulcer are shallow ulcers that are often multiple and separated by normal intervening mucosa. They may involve any part of the oral cavity or oropharynx. Sometimes, it is solitary and may involve the tonsil and the pillars. It is very painful. 

Other differential diagnoses for membrane over the tonsil:

  • Membranous tonsillitis
  • Malignancy of tonsil
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Leukemia
  • Traumatic ulcer
  • Candidal infection of the tonsil

questions.text: A 60-year-old female undergoes a prolonged gynaecological surgery. Three weeks later, she presents with fever, fatigue, and a new-onset heart murmur. Blood cultures reveal Gram-positive cocci in chains that grow well in the presence of 6.5% NaCl. Which of the following statements about the organism is true?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of fever, fatigue, and a new-onset heart murmur three weeks after a prolonged gynaecological surgery suggests a diagnosis of infective endocarditis (IE). The identification of Gram-positive cocci in chains that grow well in 6.5% NaCl strongly indicates that the causative organism is Enterococcus.

Enterococcus species are catalase-negative, bile-esculin-positive, gram-positive cocci that grow in chains and are characterised by their ability to grow in the presence of 6.5% NaCl (salt tolerance). 

They are catalase-negative, meaning they do not produce bubbles with hydrogen peroxide, and bile-esculin-positive, indicating their ability to hydrolyse esculin in the presence of bile, resulting in a dark brown or black colour change in the medium.

These biochemical characteristics are typical of Enterococcus, which can colonise the genitourinary (GU) tract and enter the bloodstream following surgical procedures, leading to infective endocarditis in susceptible individuals like this patient after a prolonged gynaecological surgery.

Enterococci possess several distinctive features that distinguish them from Streptococci :

Characteristics Enterococci Streptococci
Shape Oval cocci, sometimes at an angle to each other Spherical
Length of chain Short chains Long chains
Growth on sheep blood agar Non-hemolytic Beta or alpha-hemolytic
Growth on MacConkey medium Tiny magenta-pink colonies Usually do not grow
In the presence of 6.5% NaCl, pH 9.6, 45degrees and 10 degrees Celsius  Grow Do not grow

questions.text:
A patient is about to undergo total hip replacement. She has a prosthetic heart valve in place and is on warfarin. Which of the following measures should be followed pre-operatively ?

(LMWH - Low molecular weight heparin)

choices.text: Continue warfarin till 6 hours before surgery
Switch warfarin to LMWH 7 days before surgery
Switch warfarin to dual antiplatelet therapy 5 days before surgery

questions.solution:
In this patient, warfarin should be switched to LMWH 7 days before surgery.

Patients with a previous history of myocardial infarction, prosthetic heart valve replacement, or recent stenting will be on dual antiplatelet therapy (Combination of Aspirin and P2Y12 inhibitor) or anticoagulants. In such patients, the anticoagulants or dual antiplatelet therapy will be stopped a few days prior to surgery, and the patient will be started on a short-acting anticoagulant, such as low-molecular-weight heparin. This is called bridge anticoagulation. The goal of bridging anticoagulation is to lower the risk of blood clots, which can cause stroke in patients.

Vitamin K antagonists like warfarin should be stopped 5-7 days before the surgery, and the patient should be started on subcutaneous LMWH or intravenous unfractionated heparin 2 or more days after the last administered dose of the vitamin K antagonist. The rationale behind stopping blood thinners like warfarin is due to its longer half-life and the risk of bleeding during the surgery. LMWH has a short half-life, doesn’t need any monitoring, and its effect is easily reversible, hence it is used for bridging.

LMWH should be stopped 24 hours before surgery in the case of general anesthesia and 12 hours before surgery if it's going to be done under regional anesthesia to allow normalization of coagulation by the time of surgery. After surgery, LMWH dosing should be resumed 24 hours postoperatively in low-bleeding risk surgery and delayed until 48 to 72 hours postoperatively for surgeries with high bleeding risk.

Dual antiplatelet therapy refers to the combination of Aspirin with a P2Y12 inhibitor given to patients with a history of recent MI (within 1 year), recent stenting (within 6 months), or prosthetic heart valve replacement. In such patients, the continuation of aspirin until the time of surgery leads to increased bleeding during major noncardiac surgery. Therefore, aspirin is discontinued temporarily 3 days before surgery, and the P2Y12 inhibitor like clopidogrel is discontinued 5 to 7 days before surgery.

questions.text: What is the primary use of the brace shown in the image below?

choices.text: Scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine
Stabilisation of the spine in dorsolumbar spinal injury
Stabilisation of the spine in cervical spinal injury
Prevention of pathological fractures by anterior spinal hyperextension

questions.solution:
The given image shows a Milwaukee brace, which is used in the management of scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine.

Braces are used to prevent progression and avoid surgery in scoliotic curves between 20 and 30 degrees. A variety of braces are available, some are created as cast and some are prefabricated. They usually extend from the thoracic and lumbar spine to the pelvis and have pads to push the spine into correct alignment. 

Braces used in scoliosis:

Milwaukee brace: Originally designed cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO), introduced in the 1940s. It is less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces. Still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine.


Boston brace: It is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside. It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower. 


Charleston bending brace: It is a thoraco-lumbo-sacral orthose (TLSO) used while lying down and sleeping at night for 8 to 10 hours. Best suited for single thoracolumbar or lumbar curves.


Other options:

Option B: Taylor brace is indicated for stabilization of the spine in dorsolumbar spinal injury. It is designed to control the upper and lower regions of the spinal column and support the spine while standing, sitting, and walking after spinal surgery.


Option C: To treat cervical spine injury, a SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is used. It is a cervicothoracic orthosis. It is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine and immobilizes it. 


Option D: ASHE brace is an anterior spinal hyperextension brace will take the pressure off the weak vertebrae and limit forward bending. It is also used in dorsolumbar spinal injury.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at term is admitted for normal vaginal delivery. Her per vaginal examination shows a cervix dilatation of 5 cm and cord prolapse. Suspected fetal demise is confirmed on ultrasound. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Wait for spontaneous onset of labor

questions.solution:
In this patient with a confirmed intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD) with a prolapsed cord, the next best step is to proceed with vaginal delivery. This minimizes surgical risks to the mother and allows for a safer and more natural progression of labor.

Cord prolapse is a condition in which the membranes are ruptured and the cord is present outside the uterine cavity.

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is based on three important factors:

  • Living or dead baby
  • Maturity of the baby
  • Degree of cervical dilatation

The following steps can be taken in the management of a patient with an IUFD:

  • Provide emotional support and counseling to the mother due to the distressing nature of the situation.
  • Monitor the mother’s vital signs and labor progress closely.
  • Maintain sterile technique during labor and delivery to reduce the risk of infection.

Manage Cord Prolapse: Although the cord is prolapsed, the primary concern for cord prolapse (compression and interruption of blood flow to the fetus) is not required here due to the confirmed fetal demise. Reposition the cord gently to minimize the risk of infection or trauma.

Delivery and Postpartum Care:  The American College of Gynecology recommends waiting for spontaneous onset of labor in cases of intrauterine fetal demise to minimise risk to the mother. This patient is already dilated to 5cm and will most likely progress to spontaneous labor. However, in the event of a IUFD after 28th week of gestation, the next step in management is almost always to wait for spontaneous expulsion. This can sometimes take weeks, and the patient should be counselled for the same.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman receives neo-adjuvant chemotherapy for invasive ductal carcinoma. Clinical assessment shows that the tumor has shrunk to 3 cm with no nodal involvement or metastasis. Which of the following accurately represents the current staging?
questions.solution:
After neo-adjuvant chemotherapy and clinical assessment of tumour size, the correct representation would be ycT2N0M0.

In breast cancer, the TNM staging system is used to describe the extent of cancer spread. This system includes three primary components: tumour size (T), lymph node status (N), and metastases (M).

The TNM classification can be further detailed with prefixes to indicate the timing and method of assessment.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: denotes the staging assessment performed after initial neoadjuvant therapy, such as chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or both.
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

The "y" prefix helps distinguish the extent of the disease after treatment from its initial presentation.

  • ycTNM: represents the clinical classification after neoadjuvant therapy.
  • ypTNM: represents the pathological classification after neoadjuvant therapy.

Example
A 50-year-old woman with breast cancer initially has the following clinical stage: cT3N1M0: The tumour is larger than 5 cm, with metastasis in 1-3 axillary lymph nodes and no distant metastasis.

She undergoes neoadjuvant chemotherapy, and now the tumor has shrunk to larger than 2 cm but no larger than 5 cm, no cancer is found in the lymph nodes, and no distant metastases. Hence, now it is ycT2N0M0

In this case, the prefix "y" indicates that the staging was performed after neoadjuvant therapy, showing the actual extent of the disease following treatment.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn is referred with repetitive vomiting and diarrhea. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Based on further evaluation, a diagnosis of classical galactosemia is made. On which of the following steps does the enzyme responsible for the condition act?
questions.solution:
Classical galactosemia is caused to deficient galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. The enzyme is responsible for the conversion of galactose 1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate in the metabolism of galactose.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

Option A: Uridine diphosphate galactose 4-epimerase helps in the conversion of UDP galactose to UDP glucose. Features are similar to transferase deficiency with additional findings of hypotonia and nerve deafness.

Option B: Galactokinase is the enzyme responsible for the conversion of galactose to galactose 1-phosphate. Here the symptoms are milder. This is because galactose-1-phosphate is not formed and hence no toxic effects of this compound are manifested. Only cataract is seen.

questions.text:
During the rainy season, a patient was diagnosed with dengue fever. What is the correct sequence of events occurring in this patient with respect to the fever?
  1. Hypothalamic set point lowered
  2. Shivering 
  3. Hypothalamic set point raised
  4. Sweating
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events during fever is 3→2→1→4.

During the onset of fever, the hypothalamic set point is raised by pyrogens. As the body is still at a lower temperature, various heat generating mechanisms are activated to match the hypothalamic temperature setpoint:

  • Shivering- the shivering center is located in the posterior hypothalamus. It is normally inhibited by signals from the heat center in the anterior hypothalamic-preoptic area but is excited by cold signals from the skin and spinal cord. A sudden increase in heat setpoint results in the activation of this center. It then transmits non-rhythmic signals through bilateral tracts through the lateral columns of the spinal cord, and finally to the anterior motor neurons. They increase the tone of the skeletal muscles throughout the body. As the tone rises above a certain critical level, shivering begins. During maximum shivering, body heat production can rise to four to five times normal.
  • Vasoconstriction (decreased blood flow to skin) is mediated by increased sympathetic drive by the activation of the posterior hypothalamic sympathetic center.
  • An increase in chemical thermogenesis in which heat production takes place in the brown fat by the mechanism of uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation. This is the predominant mechanism seen in neonates.

Later, the removal of pyrogens causing the resolution of the fever occurs which lowers the hypothalamic set point to lower than the body temperature. Hence various heat loss mechanisms get activated to match the lower setpoint. It includes vasodilatation of the skin's blood vessel, sweating, and decreased thermogenesis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis notes experiencing double vision. On examination, her eye movements are normal except for her right gaze where her left eye fails to adduct and her right eye shows nystagmus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of MS and above mentioned examination likely has a lesion in her left medial longitudinal fasciculus causing a left-sided internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

INO is on the side that fails to adduct on contralateral gaze i.e. the left eye fails to adduct when looking to the right.

A left-sided INO is a lesion in the left medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). The left MLF sends conjugate signals from the (contralateral) right abducens interneurons to the (ipsilateral) left medial rectus motor neurons to adduct the left eye during the right(contralateral) gaze.

The abducting right eye demonstrates a dissociated horizontal nystagmus. This is a compensatory response to overcome the weakness of the adducting left eye explained by Hering’s law of equal innervation. Increased innervation to the medial rectus muscle is accompanied by increased innervation to its yoke muscle, the contralateral lateral rectus, resulting in nystagmus.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is associated with multiple sclerosis and although it is unilateral in this case it can often be bilateral in the context of MS.

questions.text: A biopsy of myocardial tissue is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the given biopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Histopathology shows eosinophilic contraction bands (black arrow) which occur due to reperfusion injury after a myocardial infarction

After a myocardial infarction, reperfused myocardium shows eosinophilic contraction bands on light microscopy. They occur in irreversibly injured myocytes with damaged membranes, when blood supply is restored 12-24 hours after MI.

During ischemia, the intracellular calcium levels are increased due to impaired calcium cycling and sarcolemmal damage. This leads to augmented and uncontrolled contraction of myofibrils after reperfusion. 

On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that are intensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closely packed sarcomeres.

It is also a histological feature observed in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Other options:

Option A: Ninja star nuclei in myocytes are seen in dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

Option C: Biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration in myocardial tissue is suggestive of myocarditis. Viruses are the most common causes among the infectious causes of myocarditis. Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis and it shows diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration as shown below:

 

Option D: Hyaline, amorphous eosinophilic deposits on histology are associated with cardiac amyloidosis. It results in restrictive cardiomyopathy with stiffened myocardial walls causing diastolic dysfunction. Transthyretin is the major component of cardiac amyloid deposits. questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with a rapidly enlarging mass above his knee. The mass has been present for several months and has recently become painful. On examination, there is a bony prominence with tenderness in overlying the area. MRI scan revealed a cartilage cap over the lesion more than 2 cm thick. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The boy is suffering from osteochondroma and the management in this case with probable malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma is surgical excision. 

Osteochondromas are the most common benign bone tumours, which are developmental malformations rather than true neoplasms. They typically originate from the metaphysis of long bones. The cortical and medullary continuity of the tumour with the underlying bone is a pathognomonic feature, establishing the diagnosis.

These growths develop as bony protrusions, often resembling a stalk, resulting from the gradual transformation of a cartilaginous cap into bone through endochondral ossification. In many cases, osteochondromas are asymptomatic and are only identified incidentally during routine examination. 

Malignant transformation is extremely rare and if possible may transform into a low grade chondrosarcoma. Features pointing towards possible malignant degeneration are rapidly growing tumours, cartilage caps more than 2 cm thick, more common in the trunk than in the extremities. MRI scan reveals the classic cartilage cap establishing the diagnosis. 

Treatment is not usually indicated in asymptomatic lesions. In large lesions which exert local pressure effects or have increased risk of malignant transformation is to undergo surgical removal of the lesion. En bloc resection/ Surgical excision with wide margins is indicated when imaging suggests malignant features.

questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker presented with miosis, ptosis of the right eye, and anhidrosis of the right side of the face. He also has occasional chest pain along with fever and weight loss for the past month. A pancoast tumour is suspected. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of a Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor) and the investigation of choice is MRI.

Investigations in Pancoast tumor:

  • MRI (MRI > CT) is the investigation of choice for superior sulcus tumor/ Pancoast tumor as the associated soft tissue infiltration, the extent of which can be best visualized using an MRI.
  • FDG-PET scan shows high uptake by the tumor cells. FDG is taken up by all metabolizing cells but more avidly by cancer cells.
  • Bronchoscopy can be done in endobronchial tumors to obtain a tissue diagnosis.

Pancoast syndrome/ superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots, stellate ganglion, and the chest wall.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs.

Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread can cause

  • Tracheal obstruction
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis)
