Fibrous dysplasia is a benign, non aggressive tumor that involves one or more bones. Femur, Pelvis, and Tibia are the most commonly involved bones. Mostly asymptomatic, pain and fracture are commonly involved. It can be associated with McCune-Albright syndrome with cafe-au-lait spots and endocrinopathies.

X-ray features: Non-aggressive, well-circumscribed lesion within a ground glass matrix showing ground glass appearance. A characteristic feature involving proximal femoral fibrous dysplasia is Shepherd’s crook deformity.

Histology shows proliferating fibroblast in a woven bone giving a characteristic “Chinese letter” appearance.  

X-ray showing Shepherd's crook appearance: 

 

Chondroblastoma is a benign, epiphyseal origin mostly present at the end of long bones. Typically presents with pain and can cause joint effusion or stiffness. Peak age of incidence is in the teenage years and rare greater than 35 years.

X-ray features: Appear as an oval or round cystic lesion. Appear within epiphysis as a mottled appearance

Histology shows wet sawdust appearance and pathognomonic appearance of chicken wire calcification.

X-ray showing chondroblastoma:

 

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor,metaphyseal origin  having a bimodal distribution in age of 10-14 years and greater than 7th decade.Distal femur,proximal tibia,proximal femur and humerus are most commonly involved.Typically causes worsening pain and swelling leading to non mechanical pain or joint restriction.

X-ray features: Ill-defined, bone forming lesion showing characteristic Codman’s triangle due to periosteal reaction . Sunburst appearance when the periosteum does not have enough time to lay down a new layer. 

X-ray showing sunburst appearance:

 

Chondrosarcoma are the second most common primary malignant tumors that occurs in any site of the bone. It presents in 3rd to 7th decade of life and is slow growing, with deep pain and/or shows an enlarging mass. Most commonly involves proximal femur, pelvis and proximal humerus.

X-ray features: Large, intraosseous and osteolytic tumors. Irregular and granular calcifications present which shows a characteristic “honeycomb” or “popcorn”appearance.

questions.text: Presence of which of the following is a contraindication for surgical resection of the tumor in a patient with carcinoma of the head of the pancreas?

choices.text: Lymph node metastases within operative field

questions.solution:
The presence of liver metastasis is a contraindication for surgical resection of the tumor in carcinoma of the head of the pancreas.

If the tumor minimally invades the portal or superior mesenteric vein, this is not a contraindication to surgery (as part of the vein can be resected if necessary), but complete encasement and occlusion of the vein is a contraindication for resection.

The CT shows pancreatic carcinoma involving adjacent structures. 

In any jaundiced patient, the usual workup including liver function tests and ultrasound must be done. If ultrasound shows dilated bile ducts and strong suspicion of cancer of the pancreas is present, then a contrast-enhanced CT scan is advised. 

Indications for resection include : 

  • Cystic tumors 
  • Tumors of ampulla
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • No vascular encasement
  • Lymph node metastasis close to the pancreatic head

Contraindications for surgical resection include:

  • Hepatic metastases
  • Peritoneal metastases
  • Lymph node metastases distant from pancreatic head
  • Encasement of 
    • Superior mesenteric artery 
    • Coeliac artery 
    • Hepatic artery 

Tumour size, continuous invasion of the duodenum, stomach or colon, and lymph node metastases within the operative field are not contraindications.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient arrived at the OPD complaining of mucoid diarrhoea for the past week. He also complained of a 4-week-old pink, itchy, and serpiginous perianal rash that rapidly spread to the thighs. Also, he reported having a cough for the previous six weeks. What is the causative organism that is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of chronic cough with mucoid diarrhoea and a rash starting perianally and extending to the thigh rapidly is suggestive of Larva currens that is seen in Strongyloides stercoralis infection.

S. stercoralis is an ovoviviparous parasite. It has a parasitic cycle and a free-living soil cycle, during which it persists for a long duration in the soil by feeding on bacteria. Humans get infected when the third-stage filariform larvae penetrate their bare skin. 

From here, they enter the venous circulation and travel to the right side of the heart and the lungs. From the lungs, while coughing, they are swallowed into the esophagus and reach the gastrointestinal tract. The female worms lay eggs in the mucosa leading to the release of rhabditiform larva. The larvae then migrate to the lumen of the intestine and are passed in feces. They may transform into filariform larvae while moving through the gastrointestinal tract which then penetrates the mucosa leading to autoinfection. 

Clinical manifestations of Strongyloides include cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Cutaneous manifestations include Dermatitis, pruritus, and urticaria in peri-anal skin and larva currens (multiple urticarial tracts in the skin caused by migrating larvae). This also causes bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthma as pulmonary manifestations.

It also infects the intestine leading to mucoid diarrhoea, protein-losing enteropathy, and rarely paralytic Ileus.

Diagnosis of Strongyloides infection is by the wet mount of stool showing rhabditiform larvae or aspirates of sputum, jejunum, or duodenum. Peripheral eosinophilia can be there and IgE may be raised. 

Other options:

Option A: Enterobius vermicularis also known as pinworm, causes intense pruritus of the anal region in children. The worm tends to migrate out of the anus at night leading to disturbed sleep and nocturnal enuresis. In females, it can irritate the vagina and vulva and chronic salpingitis.

Option C: Wuchereria bancroftii causes filariasis. The adult worms block the lymphatic vessels leading to inflammation and granuloma formation. This causes hard pitting or brawny edema. It can present as lymphadenitis, lymphedema, hydrocele, and elephantiasis.

Option D: Ascaris lumbricoides is also an intestinal nematode and infects through rhabtidiform larvae. This larva also ascends to the lungs through portal circulation and by coughing it gets swallowed causing reinfection. It leads to ascariasis and Loeffler’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with developmental delay and multiple seizure types. The seizures could not be controlled by an array of drugs. EEG shows 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves with poly-spike bursts in sleep. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 4-year-old child presenting with developmental delay, multiple seizure types that are not responding to drugs and an EEG showing 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep has a likely diagnosis of Lennox–Gastaut syndrome. 

Lennox–Gastaut syndrome typically starts between the ages of 2 and 10 years and consists of a triad of developmental delay, multiple seizure types (atypical absences, myoclonic, tonic, atonic, and/or generalized tonic-clonic seizures) and EEG findings of 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness.  

Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies. The drug of choice for Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is Valproate. Other drugs used for this condition are clobazam, lamotrigine, rufinamide and topiramate. 

Other options: 

Option A: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome)- Typically, it starts in early adolescence (not in childhood) and the EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges. 

Option C: Landau–Kleffner syndrome- A rare condition characterized by loss of language skills in a previously normal child (not a child with developmental delay). 

Option D: West syndrome- Starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months and typical EEG finding is called hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage, slow with chaotic background)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the boundaries of the foramen marked as 'A' in the given image?
questions.solution:
The epiploic foramen is marked as 'A' in the given image. It is related posteriorly to the inferior vena cava, right suprarenal gland, and body of the T12 vertebra.

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac) is a short vertical slit situated immediately posterior to the free margin of the lesser omentum. It is the entrance to the lesser sac from the greater sac. It measures about 3 cm in height in adults.

Boundaries of epiploic foramen are:

  • Anterior – Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile duct.
  • Posterior – T12 vertebra, inferior vena cava, right adrenal gland.
  • Superior – Caudate lobe of the liver.
  • Inferior – First part of the duodenum and the horizontal part of the hepatic artery.

Clinical note: Pringle maneuver (as shown below) is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following patterns would be seen on hemoglobin electrophoresis in a patient with sickle cell trait?
questions.solution:
Electrophoresis in individuals with sickle cell trait typically shows two bands representing both HbA and HbS. 

Sickle cell trait (Hemoglobin AS) results from inheritance of one normal hemoglobin gene (HbA) and one abnormal hemoglobin gene (HbS). The presence of HbS in sickle cell trait does not typically cause clinical symptoms under normal conditions.

Other options: 

Option 1: This pattern of two bands representing HbA and HbF is seen in normal newborns.

Option 2: This pattern is seen in sickle cell disease (HbSS).

Option 4: This pattern is seen in Hb SC disease, with two bands representing HbS and HbC.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presented 3 months ago with mild behavioral changes. He developed startle myoclonus and progressively worsening dementia. His condition deteriorated rapidly and he passed away 2 days ago. On autopsy, spongiform degeneration of the brain was noted. Which of the following histopathological findings would be seen in his brain?
questions.solution:
This elderly man, with startle myoclonus, a rapidly progressive dementia that lead to death within 3 months, and spongiform degeneration of the brain on autopsy most likely had a diagnosis of prion disease (likely Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease). Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is associated with misfolded prion protein inclusions called PrPsc.

Prion disease is a rapidly progressing neurodegenerative disorder that occurs due to abnormal protein folding of prion proteins. These proteins can undergo a structural change from an alpha helix to beta-pleated sheets (PrPC to PrPSC). These proteins then become resistant to breakdown by normal proteases in the body and can rapidly spread, invading the central nervous system and inducing neuronal cell death. Prion diseases can be sporadic, but more often they have a familial mode of spread due to mutations in the PRNP gene that codes for PrP.

The brain classically undergoes spongiform degeneration due to vacuole formation and rapid death of the neurons. Histopathological examination during post-mortem can reveal inclusion such as PrPsc deposits and Kuru plaques. 

Other options-

Option (B): Alpha-synuclein is commonly seen in Parkinson's disease, which presents with an abnormal shuffling gait, resting tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. It can also be seen in multiple system atrophy which is predominantly a disease of autonomic dysfunction. It can progress rapidly but is not associated with startle myoclonus or progressive dementia.

Option (C): Pick bodies are seen in frontotemporal lobe degeneration. Frontotemporal lobe degeneration would result in gradual behavioral changes and features of aphasia and not rapidly progressive symptoms.

Option (D): Cerebral amyloid angiopathy is often seen in Alzheimer's disease characterized by Amyloid deposition in cortical arterioles. However, Alzheimer's would present with slowly progressive symptoms.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman was diagnosed with bipolar disorder and has been taking lithium for the past 5 years. She is currently in remission. However, she now presented to the OPD with worsening depression, fatigue, weight loss, abdominal pain, renal colic, and bone pain. Which of the following tests would most likely reveal the underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of hypercalcemia due to prolonged lithium therapy. Serum calcium levels should be assessed.

Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorders in combination with other drugs such as antidepressants, antipsychotics, and benzodiazepines. One of the common adverse effects of prolonged lithium therapy is hyperparathyroidism, which presents with signs and symptoms of hypercalcemia.

Patients with hypercalcemia, depending on the severity, may present with symptoms, which include: fatigue, lethargy, anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, constipation, bone pain, depression, polyuria, polydipsia, and renal colic. The classic symptoms of hyperparathyroidism are described as 'bones, stones, and abdominal groans'.

The adverse effects of lithium include:

  • Neurological:
    • memory difficulties, tremors, peripheral neuropathy
    • dysarthria, ataxia, seizures
    • benign intracranial hypertension, myasthenia gravis-like syndrome
  • Endocrine: goiter, hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism (rare), hyperparathyroidism
  • Cardiovascular: benign T-wave changes, sinus node dysfunction
  • Renal: nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, renal tubular acidosis
  • Dermatological: Acne, hair loss, psoriasis
  • Gastrointestinal: Appetite loss, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea 

Other options:

  • Serum ferritin levels are not known to be affected with lithium therapy.
  • Some studies have shown that vitamin B12 levels may be reduced with lithium therapy. However, the symptoms given in the question are mostly related to hypercalcemia.
  • Patients with bipolar disorder on lithium therapy, are more likely to develop hypothyroidism. Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) levels may be monitored in these patients. However, as per the given clinical scenario, a patient with hypothyroidism is unlikely to have weight loss and bone pain. Hence serum calcium is the preferred option.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with asymmetrical weakness in the distal part of his upper limbs characterized by wasting, atrophy, and spontaneous twitching. He later develops dysphagia and dysarthria. On examination, he exhibits brisk reflexes and loss of dexterity. Which recently FDA-approved medication targets the underlying genetic mechanism of his condition?
questions.solution:
The recently FDA-approved medication targeting the underlying genetic mechanism of his condition is Tofersen.

The FDA approved Tofersen to treat patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) associated with a superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) gene mutation. It is an antisense oligonucleotide that targets SOD1 mRNA to reduce the synthesis of SOD1 protein. It is administered intrathecally, through a spinal injection at a dosage of 100 mg per administration. Patients receive three initial doses administered at 14-day intervals, followed by a maintenance dose every 28 days. Riluzole and edaravone are other drugs used in the management of ALS.

Initially, the patient presents with asymmetrical weakness in the upper limb's distal part, characterised by wasting, atrophy and absent motor reflex. Later other limbs are affected and extensors are involved more than flexors in the hand. Progresses to bulbar/pseudobulbar involvement leading to dysphagia, dysarthria, chewing and movements of the face and tongue. Rarely, early involvement of the muscles of respiration may lead to death before the disease is far advanced. Pseudobulbar involvement is characterised by emotional incontinence.

Upper motor neuron features such as brisk reflexes, and loss of dexterity can be seen leading to inability to perform complex activities. Importantly sensory, bowel and bladder dysfunction and cognitive dysfunction are unaffected. Also, ocular motility is spared until very late stages of the illness. Familial ALS is sometimes associated with frontotemporal dementia.

Other options

Tidrakizumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against IL-23 which is useful to improve the cutaneous symptoms as well as the quality of life in patients affected by moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis.

Siponimod is the drug approved for secondary progressive multiple sclerosis.

Trofinetide(Daybue) is an analogue of insulin-like growth factor, which is the first drug to be approved for the treatment of rett syndrome in children aged 2 years or older.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with complaints of feeling anxious, irritable, difficulty in concentrating, and worrying excessively over the past 6 months. Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of generalized anxiety disorder. Olanzapine is not used in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder. It is an atypical antipsychotic mainly used in the treatment of schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder. 

Generalized anxiety disorder is defined as excessive worry and anxiety about several activities and events for most days during a 6 month period. The worry is difficult to control and is often associated with somatic symptoms including:

  • Irritability
  • Sleeplessness
  • Restlessness
  • Difficulty in concentrating
  • Muscle tension
  • Fatiguabilty

Management of generalized anxiety disorder: A combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy is effective.

The current first-line drugs, in order of preference, are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), and pregabalin. Psychotherapy comprising cognitive-behavioral therapy, insight-oriented therapy, and supportive therapy are offered along with the medication.

Other options: 

Option B - SSRIs such as sertraline can be used for generalized anxiety disorder, especially in the presence of comorbid depression. Sertraline, citalopram, or paroxetine are usually prescribed. 

Option C - Buspirone is a second-line drug used in generalized anxiety disorder. It takes around 2-3 weeks for its actions to become evident. Hence, it is usually started with a benzodiazepine which is then tapered. 

Option D - Benzodiazepines such as alprazolam are usually prescribed on an as-needed basis so that patients can take them when they're feeling particularly anxious. They are not part of first-line management and should be used on a short-term basis only.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of lower limb pain. He says that his bones feel thickened and warm to touch. He also reports a dull constant headache and difficulty in hearing. X-ray of the skull is shown below. Which of the following biochemical profiles will be seen in this condition?


( N - Normal )
questions.solution:
In the given clinical vingette of thickening of bones, warm skin, dull headache and hearing difficulties, the most likely diagnosis is Paget's disease. Raised levels of plasma alkaline phosphatase is seen. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are usually normal.

Paget's disease is characterized by increased osteoclastic activity leading to increased bone turnover. This causes localized sites of lysis and excavations in bone. This is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone because of increased osteoblastic activity. The internal architecture is abnormal and the bone is unusually brittle.

The radiological signs seen are:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion of the involved bone.
  • Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull
  • Diploic widening: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected.
  • Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

The biochemical parameters of Paget's disease are calcium-N, PTH-N, Phosphate-N, ALP ↑

questions.text: Which of the following supplementations is recommended by WHO to prevent pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
In populations with a low dietary intake of calcium, WHO recommends calcium supplementation in pregnant women to reduce the risk of pre-eclampsia.

The recommendation is to give 1.5 to 2 grams per day in three divided doses. This is especially important in pregnant women with low dietary intake of calcium. 

Care must be taken in explaining to the pregnant women not to take calcium and iron-folic acid tablets together at the same time as calcium reduces the absorption of iron.

Administration of magnesium sulphate is recommended for the prevention and treatment of eclampsia

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male patient came to the physician due to chronic fatigue. On examination, generalized painless lymphadenopathy is noted. The findings of lymph node biopsy are shown in the image below. On immunohistochemistry, the lymphoma cells expressed CD5, CD20, and cyclin D1. Laboratory findings are given below. Which translocation is responsible for this patient's pathology?

Lab findings:

Hb: 10 g/dL

TLC: 1,40,00/mm3

Platelet: 2,26,000/mm3
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image and laboratory findings are suggestive of mantle cell lymphoma, a type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Mantle cell lymphomas have (11;14) translocation.

Mantle cell lymphoma is a rare subtype of B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma and is usually identified by a translocation of the CCND1 gene. It presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life and shows a male predominance. The tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers.

Clinical features:

  • Extensive painless lymphadenopathy
  • B-symptoms like fevers, night sweats, and weight loss symptoms
  • Splenomegaly-related discomfort
  • Blood count abnormalities due to bone marrow involvement
  • Symptoms related to extranodal organ involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, spleen, liver, and bone marrow
  • Mucosal involvement of the small bowel or colon produces polyp-like lesions called lymphomatoid polyposis

Histopathological features:

  • There is a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft nuclear contours.
  • The nuclear chromatin is condensed, nucleoli are inconspicuous, and the cytoplasm is scant. 

The image given below shows a histopathology slide depicting nodular mantle cell lymphoma:

 

Mantle cell lymphomas have (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 that leads to overexpression of cyclin D1. These cells are positive for CD19 to CD22.

The prognosis is poor with a median survival of 3 to 4 years.

Other options:

Option B: t(8;14) is seen in Burkitt lymphoma. Patients usually will be adolescents or young adults presenting with extranodal masses. It may sometimes present as leukemia.

Option C: t(11;22) is seen in Ewing sarcoma. It is a bone tumor presenting with swelling and tenderness over the site. Radiological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance

Option D: t(14;18) is seen in follicular lymphoma. They present with multiple areas of painless lymphadenopathy. Histopathology of the enlarged nodes would show nodular expansion of tumor cells, composed of small cells with cleaved nuclei (centrocytes) and larger cells with more cytoplasm (centroblasts).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Cobalt-60?

choices.text: It is used for gamma knife surgery
It is used in high dose-rate brachytherapy

questions.solution:
Cobalt 60 emits beta particles and gamma radiation. It doesn't emit alpha particles

Cobalt 60 is a radioactive metal commonly used in medical radiation therapy. Its mode of decay is via beta particles and gamma radiation. The half-life of cobalt-60 is 5.27 years.

Cobalt-60 isotope has traditionally been popular for teletherapy, although this use is decreasing. It has also been used in gamma knife surgeries. A newer use of the Cobalt 60 isotope has been in the field of high dose-rate brachytherapy.

questions.text: A baby is ready for discharge from the KMC unit. All of the following criteria should be met to discharge the baby except?

choices.text: Baby is able to breastfeed or is accepting feeds by spoon, paladai or cup
Continuous weight gain of at least 15g/kg per day for 3 consecutive days
Maintaining temperature for 3 consecutive days at room temperature

questions.solution:
All the above criteria should be met in order to discharge the baby from kangaroo mother care (KMC) unit, except that the baby's weight is > or = 2500 gms.

The following criteria should be met by the infant in order to discharge the baby following kangroo mother care (KMC):

  • Stable and not on parenteral medication
  • Maintaining temperature in mother’s bed for 3 consecutive days at room temperature
  • Continuous weight gain of at least 15g/kg per day for 3 consecutive days
  • Accepting feeds directly from breast (preferable) or by spoon, paladai or cup

KMC can be stopped:

  • When baby reaches term gestation from birth (If baby was born premature)
  • When baby weighs > or = to 2500 gm

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns.

questions.text: A young woman presents with continuous dribbling of urine per vaginum. She underwent a Caesarean section 5 days ago. She is diagnosed with vesicovaginal fistula. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the development of vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) on post-op day 5 is likely due to obstructed labour.

Leakage of urine following direct surgical injury as in Kielland forceps delivery, abdominal hysterectomy and anterior colporrhaphy occurs from the first postoperative day.

The most common type of genitourinary fistula is vesicovaginal fistula where there is communication between the bladder and the vagina and the urine escapes into the vagina causing true incontinence.

In obstructed labour, ischemia necrosis occurs as a result of prolonged compression effect on the bladder base between the head and symphysis pubis leading to infection → sloughing → fistula. Thus, it takes around 3–5 days following delivery to produce a fistula.

Vesicovaginal fistulas usually present with:

  • Escape of ammonia-smelling watery discharge per vagina is characteristic.
  • Excoriation in the groin region due to constant leakage of urine

On examination, the fistula may be visualized by observing urine collection in the vagina. Bimanual examination reveals its fixity and extent.

Methylene blue-3 swab test confirms the VVF but also differentiates it from ureterovaginal and urethrovaginal fistula. Here, methylene blue is injected into the bladder via the catheter, and three sterile swabs are placed into the vaginal cavity.  

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula

The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chassar-Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation into the sigmoid colon in case of failure of previous surgeries

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

questions.text: What is the use of this surgical instrument?

choices.text: Dilate the punctum of lacrimal gland
Curette the lacrimal sac in cases of epiphora

questions.solution:
The given image shows Bowman's lacrimal probe.  It is identified by the ends of the lacrimal probe which are blunt with a central stable platform. It is used to probe the lacrimal sac in the management of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. It is also used to identify the lacrimal sac during DCR and DCT.

Other common instruments used in lacrimal gland surgeries:

Nettleship's lacrimal punctum dilator (shown in the image attached below) is used to dilate the punctum before lacrimal sac surgeries (Option-C)

 

Lacrimal gland cannula is used for syringing the lacrimal gland and the passage. It is a long curved hypodermic needle with a blunt tip. (Option-A)

 

Lacrimal sac curette is used to curette the lacrimal sac in cases of epiphora (Option-D). It is a cylindrical instrument, one end of which is a blunt-tipped dissector, and the other end is curetted.

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrect regarding ROME IV criteria?

choices.text: Recurrent abdominal pain, on average should be present for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months
Associated with a change in stool form
Associated with a change in stool frequency
Abdominal pain for the last 3 weeks with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.solution:
The ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS  must be fulfilled for the last 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Based on bowel movement patterns, IBS is classified as:

  • IBS-C: Irritable bowel syndrome-constipation predominant
  • IBS-D: Irritable bowel syndrome-diarrhea predominant
  • IBS-M: Irritable bowel syndrome-mixed

Alteration in bowel habits (constipation/diarrhea) is the most consistent clinical feature in IBS. This means that a majority of people suffering from IBS have an alteration in bowel habits. The most common pattern is constipation alternating with diarrhea, usually with one of these symptoms predominating.

IBS is a clinical diagnosis that can be made without performing many tests if the patient presents with typical symptoms. However, it is recommended to perform the following tests in most patients to rule out other conditions:

  • Complete blood count
  • Sigmoidoscopic examination
  • Stool examination for ova and parasites
  • 3-week lactose-free diet
  • Fecal calprotectin levels help distinguish inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from IBS

In patients >40 years, air-contrast barium enema or colonoscopy should also be performed.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding the given structure.

choices.text: H1 is most tightly bound to chromatin
1.75 turns of DNA are wrapped around the octamer
The linker DNA between such units consists of 30 base pairs
Acetylation is one of the post-translational modifications

questions.solution:
The given structure is the nucleosome and the octamer, which forms the core component of the nucleosome is the core histones, namely H2A, H2B, H3, and H4. The incorrect statement is H1 is most tightly bound to chromatin.

H1 is least tightly bound to chromatin and can be removed by adding salt solution.

Nucleosomes are composed of DNA wound around an octameric complex of histone molecules. Histones are a small family of closely related basic proteins composed of arginine and lysine. H3 and H4 form a tetramer, while H2A and H2B form dimers; these histone oligomers associate to form the histone octamer. 1.75 turns of DNA are wrapped around octamer, protecting 145–150 base pairs of DNA.

The histone H1 is seen in the linker region and is bound loosely to the nucleosome. The linker region is formed of 30 base pairs of DNA.

These four core histones are subject to at least six types of covalent modification or post-translational modifications:

  • Acetylation
  • Methylation
  • Phosphorylation
  • ADP-ribosylation
  • Monoubiquitylation
  • Sumoylation

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman is 20 weeks pregnant. She mentions that her previous labour was prolonged and tedious and eventually the doctor used an instrument to deliver her first child. What size of the marked diameter would point towards the diagnosis of cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
The marked diameter is diagonal conjugate (from the lower end of pubic symphysis to the sacral promontory). Cephalo-pelvic disproportion (CPD) at the pelvic inlet is diagnosed when the diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm. 

Cephalopelvic disproportion is a state where the normal proportion between the size of the fetus to the size of the pelvis is disturbed. It can either occur due to an average size baby with a small pelvis or a relatively large baby with a normal pelvis.

A history of prolonged or tedious labor, followed by either spontaneous or difficult instrumental delivery is suggestive of pelvic contraction. Difficult vaginal delivery ending in a stillborn or neonatal death without any etiological factor also suggests a contracted pelvis. Past history of fracture, rickets, osteomalacia, tuberculosis of the pelvic joints or spines, and poliomyelitis is elicited.

CPD can occur at the inlet, mid pelvis, or at the pelvic outlet. It is diagnosed at these levels by the following measurements.

  • Inlet CPD
    • Anteroposterior diameter < 10 cm
    • Diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm
    • Transverse diameter < 12 cm
  • Midpelvis CPD
    • Sum of the interspinous and posterior sagittal diameters of the mid pelvis </= 13.5 cm
    • Interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  • Outlet CPD
    • Interischial diameter </= 8 cm

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with fever and chills for the last 7 days. A peripheral blood smear showed the following feature. Which of the following is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of fever and chills with the image showing band forms in the erythrocyte suggest that P. malariae is the causative agent.

The older trophozoites of P.malariae are sometimes seen stretched across the erythrocyte as a broad band. These band forms are a unique feature of P. malariae. Numerous large pigment granules are also seen. Fine stippling called, Ziemann's stippling may be seen with special stains. P.malariae preferentially infects older erythrocytes and the degree of parasitization is found to be low.

Other options:

Option A: Merozoites of P. vivax preferentially infect reticulocytes and young erythrocytes. Erythrocytes are enlarged and show Schuffner's dots which are red granules. The erythrocytes become irregular in shape, lose their red color, and have a pale appearance.

Option C: Erythrocytes in P. falciparum initially will show a marginal ring form known as accole. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones are commonly seen. The infected erythrocyte is normal in size and shows a few brick-red dots known as Maurer's cleft. Basophilic stippling also can be noted. 

The blood smear in P. falciparum will show multiple ring forms in the erythrocytes as shown below.

Option D: In P.ovale, the trophozoites resemble those in vivax malaria but they are usually more compact with less ameboid appearance. Schuffner's dots appear earlier and are more abundant and prominent than in vivax infection. The infected erythrocytes are enlarged and oval-shaped with fimbriated margins. The schizonts resemble those of P. malariae, except that the erythrocyte is usually oval, with prominent Schuffner's dots and the pigment is darker.

questions.text: A patient comes to you asking for emergency contraception. She had unprotected sex 4 days ago. Which of the following emergency contraceptives can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Since the patient had unprotected sex 4 days ago, an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) can be used for emergency contraception. It can be inserted within 5 days of coitus as a method of emergency contraception. All other methods of emergency contraception mentioned above need to be administered within 72 hours.

An IUCD prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium so that the fertilized egg is unable to implant.

Administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy is known as the emergency contraception method. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse.

Other options:
Centchroman (option A) is administered as two tablets of 50 mg taken 12 hours apart, within 72 hours of intercourse. It acts by preventing the implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium. It is the only contraceptive that neither suppresses ovulation nor interferes with the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

Mifepristone (option C) is administered as a single 10 mg tablet within 72 hours. It is a steroid with an affinity for progesterone receptors. It prevents fertilization by blocking the action of progesterone on the endometrium. This leads to sloughing and shedding of decidua, thus preventing implantation.

Levonorgestrel (option D) is administered as two tablets of 0.75 mg strength taken 12 hours apart, within 72 hours of intercourse. It prevents ovulation and causes desynchronization of the endometrium through its receptors (luteal phase deficiency).

questions.text: A 1-year-old child with a history of chronic dacryocystitis of the left eye secondary to scarring was treated with repeated lacrimal sac probing. There is minimal improvement in her symptoms. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
In a 1-year-old child with chronic dacryocystitis secondary to scarring and unresponsive to lacrimal sac probing, balloon catheter dilation is the next step for management. 

Congenital dacryocystitis is primarily treated with lacrimal sac massage (option B) and topical antibiotics (option A). Massaging increases the hydrostatic pressure in the sac and helps open up membranous occlusions. It is not useful for scarring.

If lacrimal sac massage fails to improve symptoms by the age of 9-12 months, lacrimal sac probing is done with Bowman's probe. It is performed under general anaesthesia. It may be repeated after 3-4 weeks if the first probing fails to improve symptoms.

When repeated probing fails, balloon catheter dilation is done. It is also used when the obstruction is due to scarring or constriction. If balloon catheter dilation fails, intubation with a silicone tube is carried out. The tube is kept in situ for 6 months. If all the above methods fail, conservative treatment is continued till the age of 4 years, following which dacryocystorhinostomy (option D) is performed. It is a surgical treatment method. 

Congenital dacryocystitis is the chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac in newborns. It may be due to a membranous or bony occlusion, or complete noncanalisation or scarring of the nasolacrimal duct. Children often present with continuous watering of the eye, mucopurulent discharge, and swelling over the lacrimal sac. The regurgitation test is positive.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with symptoms of weight gain, central obesity, easy bruising, and facial plethora over the past year. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum cortisol levels and loss of diurnal cortisol rhythm. Which of the following tests would be most useful in differentiating between an ectopic ACTH tumour and Cushing's disease in this patient?
questions.solution:
The test most useful in differentiating between ectopic ACTH tumour and Cushing's disease in this patient is high-dose dexamethasone suppression test.

Ectopic ACTH tumor is a paraneoplastic syndrome that accounts for approximately 20% of cases of Cushing syndrome. This syndrome is notably associated with neuroendocrine tumors, with small cell lung cancer (SCLC) being the most frequent cause, followed by carcinoid tumors (bronchial and thymic), islet cell tumors, and pheochromocytomas. 

Confirmation typically involves demonstrating elevated plasma ACTH levels (typically 2-4 times normal) that do not suppress with high-dose dexamethasone suppression testing. It's important to note that high-dose dexamethasone effectively suppresses plasma ACTH in pituitary ACTH-producing tumors, such as those seen in 'Cushing's disease'.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: A patient with suspected thoracic outlet syndrome is being examined. Hyperabduction of the arm on the affected side causes a reduction in the radial artery pulsation. What is this test known as?
questions.solution:
Hyperabduction maneuver to demonstrate a fall in radial pulse volume is known as Wright's test.

This reduction in volume is due to compression of the artery by the pectoralis minor tendon. An axillary bruit may be heard on auscultation.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with short stature and mental retardation. She also has coarse facial features and delayed skeletal maturation and sexual development. Evaluation of the thyroid reveals elevated TSH, low T4, and atrophic thyroid on ultrasonography. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Myxedematous endemic cretinism is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

Children with myxedematous endemic cretinism present with mental retardation, short stature, coarse facial features, deafness, delayed skeletal maturation, delayed sexual development, and no goiter. Serum TSH is elevated while serum T4 levels are low and ultrasonography shows atrophic thyroid.

Endemic cretinism occurs due to the nutritional deficiency of iodine. It can be neurological cretinism or myxedematous cretinism. Both neurologic and myxedematous types can manifest neurologic symptoms. Cretinism is a condition characterized by irreversible abnormalities in intellectual development. Iodine deficiency is also associated with poor school performance in children and recurrent pregnancy loss in women.

Iodine deficiency can be best prevented by using iodized salt and oils. The recommended daily intake of iodine is 40-120 μg for children up to the age of 10 years, and 150 μg for older children and adults. An additional intake of 25 μg and 50 μg is recommended during pregnancy and lactation, respectively.

Other options:

Option B: Neurological cretinism is characterized by deaf-mutism, squint, proximal spasticity and rigidity. Goiter is seen in neurological cretinism. In neurological cretinism skeletal and sexual maturation remains unaffected. Disorders of stance and gait with preservation of vegetative functions, signs of cerebellar or oculomotor disturbance and severe mental deficiency. Myxedematous cretinism is characterized by retarded psychomotor development, severe short stature, coarse facial features and myxedema without deaf-mutism.

Option C: Graves disease includes a triad of hyperthyroidism with goiter, ophthalmopathy, and dermopathy (no mental retardation).

Option D: Pendred syndrome is caused by a mutation in chloride–iodide transporter in the thyroid and cochlea resulting in euthyroid/hypothyroid goiter and sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: An elderly man is admitted with deep vein thrombosis in his left leg. He is a known case of hypertension and chronic kidney disease (creatinine clearance - 29 mL/min). Which of the following will you prescribe for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Unfractionated heparin is to be prescribed to manage this patient's condition. Heparin is cleared and degraded primarily by the reticuloendothelial system and only a tiny amount appears in the urine. Hence, it is safe to be used in patients with renal impairment/ chronic kidney disease.

Heparin, low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), and fondaparinux have no intrinsic anticoagulant activity. These agents accelerate the action of anti-thrombin. Heparin binds to anti-thrombin and brings about a conformational change in anti-thrombin that accelerates the inhibition of factor Xa (anti-thrombin inhibits activated coagulation factors, especially thrombin and factor Xa).

Heparin, LMWH, and fondaparinux - can be used in the initial management of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, unstable angina, and in acute myocardial infarction.

Heparin and LMWH are used in select patients with disseminated intravascular coagulation and coronary balloon angioplasty with or without stent placement to prevent thrombosis. Fondaparinux is contraindicated due to the risk of catheter thrombosis.

Heparin is the agent of choice for cardiopulmonary bypass surgeries.

Heparin, LMWH, and fondaparinux do not cross the placenta and hence are safe to use in pregnancy. The drugs may be discontinued 24 hours before delivery to minimize postpartum hemorrhage.

Other options :

Options B & C: Low molecular weight heparin and fondaparinux are both smaller molecules and are cleared almost exclusively by kidneys. These drugs can accumulate in patients with renal impairment and lead to bleeding. Both these drugs are contraindicated in patients whose creatinine clearance is below 30 mL/min. 

Option D: Rivaroxaban toxicity is increased in patients with renal impairment or severe hepatic dysfunction and should be avoided in these patients.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity. He is planned for the commando operation. Which of the following is not a part of the planned procedure?
questions.solution:
Commando operation does not include step ladder resection. Johansen 'stepladder' resection is done in carcinoma of lower lip.

Commando operation (Combined mandibular dissection and neck dissection) procedure involves wide excision of tumor or hemiglossectomy, hemimandibulectomy, and radical neck dissection together.

The procedure is en-bloc removal. It is usually performed for carcinoma of tongue or floor of the mouth.

Management of oral cavity cancers:

  1. Wide local excision (WLE): R0 resection (microscopic freedom from the disease) with a margin of 0.5 cm.
  2. Mandibular resection: Indication - involvement of mandible.
  3. Neck dissection: Indication : lymph node involvement.
  4. Reconstruction: Flaps.

Steps 1+2+3 form the commando operation

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has the same underlying pathophysiology as the mechanism of action of the drug, Eptifibatide?
questions.solution:
Glanzmann thrombasthenia has the same underlying pathophysiology as the mechanism of action of the drug Eptifibatide. Both involve the inhibition of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor, which is crucial for platelet aggregation.

Eptifibatide is a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor used to prevent platelet aggregation and thrombus formation in acute coronary syndromes. It works by blocking the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor on the surface of platelets, preventing fibrinogen binding and cross-linking of platelets, which is essential for platelet aggregation.

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a deficiency or dysfunction of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor on the surface of platelets. This results in impaired platelet aggregation, leading to bleeding tendencies. 

Bernard-Soulier syndrome: This condition involves a defect in the glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex on platelets, which is necessary for platelet adhesion to the von Willebrand factor. 

Von Willebrand disease: This condition is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (vWF), which is essential for platelet adhesion and stabilising factor VIII.

Vitamin K deficiency: This condition leads to a deficiency in vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X), which are essential for the blood coagulation cascade.

questions.text: A carpenter hurt his thumb while working. He immediately dropped the hammer due to a sharp painful sensation. Following this, he develops a poorly localized, dull aching pain. Which nerve fibers carry the two sensations respectively?
questions.solution:
The sharp painful sensation felt immediately upon injury is known as fast pain. The poorly localized dull aching pain is characteristic of slow pain. The nerve fibers carrying fast pain and slow pain are Aδ and C respectively.

Nociceptors are innervated by both Aδ and C fibers. Aδ fibers are myelinated and larger in diameter with a faster conduction velocity. C fibers are unmyelinated and conduct impulses at a slower rate. When nociceptors are activated by a noxious stimulus, activated Aδ fibers release glutamate and mediate fast pain. It is a rapid response that is responsible for localizing the noxious stimulus.

The activated C fibers release both glutamate and substance P. They conduct the impulse slowly and thus mediate slow pain. It is a dull-aching and poorly localized sensation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old professional football player was injured during a match. He complained of severe pain in the left upper abdomen. On examination, there was tenderness and crepitus over the left 10th and 11th ribs and the presence of non-shifting dullness. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of splenic injury. The Ballance sign is seen in splenic injury. It is an area of percussive dullness in the left upper quadrant due to the coagulation of blood from the injured spleen.

Option B: Kehr sign refers to referred pain in the tip of the left shoulder when firm pressure is applied over the left upper quadrant. It is also elicited by raising the left leg. It is seen in the case of hemoperitoneum, especially due to splenic injury. It occurs due to the collection of blood below the diaphragm and irritation of the phrenic nerve. 

Option C: Cullen sign refers to periumbilical bruising in cases of hemoperitoneum, especially those of pancreatic origin.

Option D: Grey Turner sign refers to bluish discoloration around flanks in case of hemoperitoneum especially acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of sudden painless visual loss in his right eye. The patient describes the loss of vision as a veil covering the visual field. He is slightly myopic and had a successful cataract extraction with intraocular lens implantation 3 years ago. His history is significant for well-controlled diabetes and hypertension. The examination finding is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows tobacco dust appearance (Shaffer's sign) in the anterior vitreous. This suggests the presence of a retinal tear. So the most likely diagnosis is rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Retinal detachment (RD) is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. It is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous RD- due to a tear or break in the retina
  • Secondary RD - due to some other preceding event
    • Exudative RD
    • Tractional RD

Rhegmatogenous RD:

In this condition, fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina. The most dangerous type of retinal break is horseshoe tear. The most dangerous location of retinal break is superiotemporal retina. Risk factors for the development of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • High myopia
  • Blunt trauma
  • Previous cataract surgery (aphakia and pseudophakia)
  • Lattice degeneration of retina

Clinical features of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • Symptoms
    • Photopsia: Flashes of light due to vitreo-retinal traction at site of the break.
    • Floaters: Due to associated vitreous hemorrhage
    • Visual field defect: A black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Shaffer's sign: Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) is a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is corrugated with undulations.

Treatment of rhegmatogenous RD includes:

  • Prophylactic laser barrage
  • Scleral buckling
  • Pneumatic retinopexy
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

Other options:

Option A: Breaks in the Descemet membrane may occur due to:

  • Corneal enlargement in infantile glaucoma. Haab striae are horizontal concentric lines representing the breaks in the Descemet’s membrane, seen in patients with congenital glaucoma.
  • Deformation such as keratoconus.
  • Birth trauma.

Option B - Exudative RD

It occurs in patients who have an accumulation of fluid beneath the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium without a retinal break.

  • Causes:
    • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis.
    • Choroidal tumours like melanoma.
    • Toxemia of pregnancy
    • Central serous retinopathy
    • Coats disease
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is smooth.
    • Shifting fluid is seen.
    • No breaks are seen.

Option C - Tractional RD:

It occurs when the vitreous has an abnormally strong attachment to the retina. With vitreous liquefaction and subsequent contraction, the retina is pulled away from the retinal pigment epithelium without a retinal break.

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Retinopathy of prematurity
    • Eales disease
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in its configuration.
    • No breaks are seen.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, skeletal abnormalities, and elevated plasma homocysteine levels. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency leads to homocystinuria, characterised by elevated plasma homocysteine levels, developmental delay, and skeletal abnormalities.

Defects in S-adenosylhomocysteine hydrolase (Option A) and S-adenosylmethionine synthase (Option C) do not lead to elevated homocysteine levels in the blood.

Cystathionase deficiency (Option D), though rare, would also lead to elevated homocysteine levels; however, it does not present with the clinical features of homocystinuria.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: A forensic specialist is conducting an autopsy of a body for suspected plant poisoning. He finds that putrefaction is delayed in this case. Which of the following plants is most likely to be consumed by the deceased?
questions.solution:
Strychnos nux vomica is the plant most likely to be consumed by the deceased. This is because the plant contains strychnine that is responsible for delay in putrefaction. The crushed seed of Strychnous nux vomica is the toxic part of the plant.

Poisoning that resists putrefaction includes

  • Potassium Cyanide
  • Barbiturates
  • Fluoride
  • Phosphorous
  • Endrin
  • Datura (genus)
  • Strychnine (Strychnos nux vomica)
  • Yellow Oleander (Cascabela thevetia)
  • Nicotine
  • Arsenic
  • Mercury
  • Copper
  • Antimony
  • Lead
  • Thallium

Kidney disease with anasarca, septic diseases, and puerperal sepsis hastens putrefaction.

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

  • Convulsions - clonic-tonic type
  • Reflex increased
  • Awful taste
  • Mind is conscious
  • Pupils dilated
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with diabetes presents with a 5-day history of fever and abdominal pain. Exam shows tenderness in the right upper quadrant. CT of the abdomen is obtained. Which empiric antibiotic regimen is most appropriate to initiate while awaiting serology and culture results?
questions.solution:
This patient with fever and right upper quadrant pain, along with above CT imaging, suggests either a pyogenic or an amoebic hepatic abscess. Initial empiric antibiotic therapy should be started with Ceftriaxone and Metronidazole.

Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be used to cover gram-negative, gram-positive, and anaerobic bacteria, with appropriate combinations such as ampicillin, an aminoglycoside, or a third-generation cephalosporin with metronidazole.

This approach targets likely pathogens, including enteric bacteria like E. coli and K. pneumoniae, Streptococcus species, and anaerobes like Bacteroides species. Additionally, metronidazole will cover E. histolytica until an amoebic abscess is ruled out. It can be changed when the specific causative organisms are identified.

Other options:

Options A: Albendazole is the drug of choice for Echinococcus granulosus, which causes hydatid liver disease. A CT scan would show well demarcated cysts and possibly eggshell calcifications in a long-standing disease. Most patients are asymptomatic, but when symptomatic, the patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Option C: Fungal liver abscesses typically occur in severely immunocompromised individuals, and fluconazole is not recommended as empiric treatment for hepatic abscess.

Option D. Vancomycin does not cover gram negative organisms and is thus not recommended. It can be used if septic shock is present or Staphylococcus aureus is obtained from culture.

questions.text: An African American man came to the clinic with the lesion shown below. He says it has been there for years and seems to increase in size. It recurred after surgery. What is the underlying abnormality of this patient's lesion?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a keloid scar. The underlying abnormality of keloid scars is the excessive accumulation of collagen with hypervascularity.

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and certain parts of the body such as the triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip. These are more common in African Americans and tend to be inherited.

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and the keloid scar's excision has a high recurrence rate.

Note: The same pathology is seen in hypertrophic scars but they tend to be within the margins of the wound and rarely grow beyond the margins of the original wound. 

Other options:

Option A: The exuberant proliferation of fibroblasts is seen in desmoid tumors, a low-grade neoplasm occurring due to exuberant proliferation of fibroblasts and other connec­tive tissue elements, following inci­sional scars or traumatic injuries.

Option B: Excessive accumulation of granulation tissue is seen in proud flesh, where excessive amounts of granulation tissue protrude above the level of the surrounding skin and block re-epithelialization.

Option D: Exaggerated wound contraction occurs in contractures, where excessive contraction leads to deformities of the wound and surrounding tissues.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 mother delivers a 4 kg baby by vaginal delivery. On examination, her uterus is atonic and you are asked to administer oxytocin and carboprost. The resident attempts bimanual compression followed by balloon tamponade despite which she bleeds profusely. She is rushed to the OT for an emergency laparotomy. Which of the following would be the next best step?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of atonic PPH refractory to uterotonics, the next best step would be uterine compression with B-lynch sutures.

B-lynch sutures refer to the use of vertical brace sutures, which appose the anterior and posterior walls of the uterus. This leads to compression of the fundus and lower uterine segment thereby controlling the hemorrhage. This procedure has a high success rate and ischemic uterine necrosis is a possible complication.

The following steps are to be carried out in a patient with atonic PPH:

  • General resuscitative measures with fluid infusions and blood transfusions.
  • Massage the uterus and start the patient on oxytocin infusion. Other uterotonics can also be administered based on the patient profile.
  • Manual exploration of the uterus to remove retained fragments of the placenta.
  • If the uterus remains atonic, mechanical methods such as bimanual compression of the uterus or balloon tamponade can be done.
  • The application of a non-pneumatic shock garment and external compression of the aorta may also aid in resuscitation.

If the uterus still remains atonic, the patient may require surgical intervention. Stepwise uterine devascularization is a novel technique for the management of PPH. It comprises:

  • Application of B-lynch sutures
  • Ligation of uterine arteries
  • Ligation of uterine and ovarian arteries
  • Ligation of internal iliac artery
  • Angiographic embolization of bleeding vessel

A hysterectomy can be considered if the uterus fails to contract despite the above measures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is in her 12th week of gestation was referred to you by an obstetrician for sonographic evaluation. You notice the following sign on USG. Identify the sign and the type of twin gestation it indicates.
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs.

A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

The "T sign" seen in sonographic images signifies a monochorionic twin pregnancy, where there is a lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A young man presented with irritation and itching in the ear, associated with discharge and a musty odor. The culture of the ear discharge shows the following appearance. What is the likely diagnosis and the organism causing it?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the culture showing black-coloured colonies on potato dextrose agar (PDA), points to a diagnosis of otomycosis by Aspergillus niger. 

Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the external ear caused commonly by Aspergillus niger, A. fumigatus, or Candida albicans.

Otoscopy will show a fungal mass whose appearance depends on the causative organism. Aspergillus niger shows black-headed filamentous growth. Infection by Candida albicans (Option B) on otoscopy shows white or creamy deposits. Aspergillus fumigatus presents as a pale blue or green mass.

Aural toileting and topical antifungal agents are the primary treatment. Nystatin, clotrimazole, and povidone-iodine are the commonly used antifungals. 2% salicylic acid in alcohol works as a keratolytic to remove the superficial layers of the epidermis along with the fungal mycelia.

Option A,D: Malignant otitis externa occurs due to infection by pseudomonas, commonly in diabetics and patients with immunosuppression. Symptoms are similar to otitis externa but examination will reveal granulations in the external auditory canal. It can cause facial nerve paralysis and has a high tendency to spread.

questions.text:
A patient presents with increased urine output. The urine osmolarity is 220 mOsm/L. On water deprivation test, the urine osmolality is unchanged. Plasma AVP is found to be elevated. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

AVP - Arginine vasopressin
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient with increased urine output, low urine osmolarity and increased plasma AVP levels, a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is most likely.

In a patient with increased urinary frequency and polyuria, 24-hour urine should be collected with unrestricted fluid intake. If the urine osmolarity is <300 mosm/L and urine volume is >50 mL/kg/day, the patient has diabetes insipidus (DI). The next step is to do a fluid deprivation test. If this results in concentration of the urine (increase in the urine osmolarity), it indicates that the patient has primary polydipsia. If, however, the urine osmolarity remains unchanged on fluid restriction, diabetes insipidus is confirmed.

To differentiate between pituitary and nephrogenic DI, desmopressin can be injected and the response noted. If there is concentration of the urine, a diagnosis of central DI is made; if there is no increase in the osmolarity of the urine, a diagnosis of nephrogenic DI is made. Another approach to differentiate between the two is to measure plasma arginine vasopressin (AVP) levels. The workup of polyuria has been shown in the algorithm below. 

Syndrome of inappropriate ADH release (SiADH) (option B) will not present with polyuria. Instead, the patient will present with features of hyponatremia, such as lethargy, altered sensorium and seizures. The urine osmolarity will be high and plasma osmolarity will be low in these patients because of increased water absorption from the distal tubule and resulting dilutional hyponatremia.

Central diabetes insipidus (option A) will present with lower levels of circulating AVP and loss of normal bright spot in the posterior pituitary on the MRI of the brain. 

Primary polydipsia (option D) will show increased osmolarity of the urine on water deprivation and low levels of circulating AVP.

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality.

Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

  • Neoplasms: 
    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)
    • Meningioma
    • Metastasis from lung and breast cancers
  • Infiltrative: 
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:

questions.text: Which image correctly depicts the pattern of spinal cord involvement in late-stage syphilis?
questions.solution:
In late-stage syphilis, neurosyphilis can manifest as tabes dorsalis, characterized by degeneration of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord (shown in image 3). 

Tabes dorsalis primarily affects the posterior columns of the spinal cord and sensory nerve roots, leading to progressive sensory ataxia and severe lancinating pains.  The presence of Argyll Robertson pupils, in which pupils react to accommodation (focusing on a near object) but do not constrict when exposed to light, is a classic sign associated with neurosyphilis. 

Classic features of tabes dorsalis include:

  1. Lancinating Pains: Sharp, shooting pains primarily in the legs, occasionally in the back, thorax, abdomen, arms, and face.
  2. Ataxia and Gait Disturbances: Resulting from loss of position sense.
  3. Paresthesias and Bladder Disturbances: Including symptoms like numbness and urinary incontinence.
  4. Visceral Crisis: Acute abdominal pain with vomiting.
  5. Loss of Reflexes: Particularly in the legs.
  6. Impaired Sensory Functions: Loss of position and vibratory sense.
  7. Romberg Sign: Unsteadiness when standing with feet together and eyes closed.
  8. Argyll Robertson Pupils

Image 1: The anterior horn of the spinal cord is highlighted in green in this image. Spinal muscular atrophy is a genetic disease characterized by progressive degeneration of anterior horn cells, which results in weakness.

Image 2: Represents the areas of the spinal cord affected by amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The pathologic hallmark of ALS is the death of the affected lower motor neurons (LMN) consisting of the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and their homologues in the brainstem, upper motor neurons (UMN) consisting of the corticospinal tract and corticobulbar tract originating in the motor cortex. 

Image 4: The dorsal columns and the lateral column tracts of the spinal cord are highlighted in green in this image. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (SACD) and affects the dorsal column and the lateral tracts.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with massive hematemesis. He is resuscitated and stabilized. Which of the following is the preferred option to prevent rebleeding?

TIPSS- Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt
questions.solution:
The preferred treatment option to prevent rebleeding is endoscopic band ligation.

In this method, a rubber band that can constrict is placed at the base of the varix. This immediately occludes the vessel and stops the bleeding. Rebleeding occurs very rarely with this method. 

Initial management of variceal bleeding involves the following: 

  • Admission to the intensive care unit
  • Placement of two large-bore peripheral cannulae
  • Blood transfusion
  • Correction of coagulopathy with fresh frozen plasma, vitamin K and tranexamic acid
  • Terlipressin, a splanchnic vasoconstrictor
  • Prophylactic antibiotic
  • Endotracheal intubation for airway protection if bleeding is uncontrolled
  • Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy

Other options

Option B - Endoscopic sclerotherapy involves injecting a sclerosant around the bleeding vessel. It is also effective in treating esophageal varices. However, the incidence of rebleeding is higher with this treatment.

Option C - Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is a temporary, stabilizing measure.  It tamponades the bleeding varices. It is not a definitive treatment for variceal bleeding but is very effective to stop the bleed and stabilize the patient.

Option D - TIPSS or transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunt placement involves the placement of a shunt to redirect blood flow and reduce portal pressure. It is very effective but requires analgesia, sedation, and fluoroscopic guidance. It is done if medical and endoscopic measures fail to control bleeding.

Related Pearl: Common sites of porto-systemic anastomosis in portal hypertension

  • Left gastric vein [portal] to Distal oesophageal [systemic] veins: Presents with oesophageal and gastric variceal bleeding
  • Superior rectal veins to Middle and inferior rectal veins: Presents with rectal varices and lower GI tract bleeding
  • Tributaries of left branch of portal vein in ligamentum teres to Periumbilical branches of epigastric and intercostal veins: Forms caput medusae
  • Tributaries of right branch of portal vein overlying ‘bare area’ of liver to Retroperitoneal veins draining into azygos, hemiazygos, lumbar, intercostal and phrenic veins
  • Omental and colonic veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures to Retroperitoneal veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures
