questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. Examination revealed poor development of breasts and normal vagina. Ultrasound showed a normal uterus but gonads were not visualized. Her karyotype is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given karyotype showing 46 XY chromosomes in an individual with female internal & external genitalia and poorly developed breasts, presenting with primary amenorrhea points towards the diagnosis of Swyer’s syndrome.

Swyer's syndrome or pure gonadal dysgenesis occurs as a result of a mutation in the SRY gene or another gene with a testis-determining effect such as DAX1, SF-1, or CBX2. This leads to underdeveloped, dysgenetic gonads that fail to produce androgens or anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH). The following features are seen: 

  • Normal prepubertal female phenotype- Absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics due to absence of sex hormones.
  • Normal Müllerian system development due to the absence of AMH. (Uterus and cervix present)
  • Female external genitalia
  • Presence of dysgenetic testes that cannot produce AMH or sex hormones. They have a risk of malignant transformation.
  • As there is gonadal dysgenesis in a patient with 46 XY karyotype, they are actually determined to be males and are a type of male pseudohermaphrodite. They present with female external genitalia, primary amenorrhea, and absence of secondary sex characters.

Points to be considered while treating these patients:

  • Cyclical estrogen and progesterone can induce menstruation
  • As they have a normal uterus, pregnancy is possible through in vitro fertilization using a donor egg.
  • Streak gonads may undergo malignant transformation and develop into germ cell tumors. Hence, they have to be removed prophylactically.
  • Hormonal replacement therapy also has a role in maintaining the bone health of these patients
  • Genetic counseling has to be offered to the affected individuals and their family members.
  • 5 alpha-reductase deficiency is a close differential of Swyer’s syndrome. It is due to a failure of conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone in a genotypic male. As testosterone levels are normal there is a normal development of Wolffian ducts and thus male internal genitalia are normal. However, some cases may have a blind-ending vagina.

As levels of DHT are low the child will have a female-looking external genitalia at birth. These children tend to be raised as females till puberty, by which they start exhibiting virilization which is caused by testosterone. Hence clitoromegaly is seen. There is a lack of breast development as testosterone is not converted to estrogen. Pubic hair is scanty as its development depends on both testosterone and dihydrotestosterone.

Option A: Androgen insensitivity syndrome has a karyotype of 46 XY, and the patients have complete insensitivity to testosterone. These individuals have female external genitalia with an absent uterus. Secondary sexual characteristics like the development of breasts are adequate. However, pubic and axillary hairs are scanty.

Option B: Turner syndrome has a karyotype of 45 XO. These individuals have short stature and streak ovaries.

questions.text: You are attending to a patient who is in labor. You can see the biparietal diameter of the fetal head stretching the vulval outlet. As the contraction gets over, the head remains in that position without recessing back. What do you expect to happen next?
questions.solution:
The biparietal diameter of the fetal head (maximum diameter of the head) stretching the vulval outlet and not recessing after the end of contraction is known as crowning. Extension is expected to happen next.

The mechanism of labor refers to the positional changes of the presenting part required for the fetus to travel through the pelvic canal during labor.

In normal labor, the most common presentation is cephalic and the presenting part is the vertex. The vertex enters the pelvis with the sagittal suture in the transverse pelvic diameter. The fetus generally enters the pelvis in the left occipitotransverse position.

The specific cardinal movements of labor are:

  • Engagement is the mechanism by which the biparietal diameter (in occiput presentation) passes through the pelvic inlet.
  • Descent is a continuous process that is completed with the expulsion of the fetus.
  • Flexion of the head occurs as soon as the descending head meets resistance from the pelvic floor/pelvic walls/cervix. With this movement, the chin is drawn closer to the fetal thorax, and the appreciably shorter suboccipitobregmatic diameter replaces the longer occipitofrontal diameter
  • Internal rotation is the mechanism by which the occiput gradually turns away from the transverse axis. Crowning occurs after internal rotation when the vulval outlet is stretched by the maximum diameter of the head and there is non-recession of the head after the contraction is over.
  • Extension- with progressive distension of the perineum, the head extends out in order as occiput, anterior fontanelle, brow, nose, mouth, and chin.
  • External rotation/restitution is the visible passive movement of the delivered head by which it untwists its neck and regains a transverse position.
  • Expulsion is the process by which the anterior shoulder is followed by the posterior shoulder and the rest of the fetal body is delivered.

The below image shows the cardinal movements of labor.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman came with complaints of bloating,  recurrent abdominal pain for more than 6 months. The frequency of this has increased to 1 day per week for the last 3 months and pain is relieved with defecation. There is a hardening of stools since her symptoms have started.  Laboratory investigations are unremarkable.  All the following drugs can be prescribed for her condition except?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a female presenting with recurrent abdominal pain for more than 6 months with increased frequency of one episode per week for the last 3 months, pain relived during defecation, hardening of stools are suggestive of constipation-predominant irritable bowel disease (IBS).  Among the given drugs, alosetron is prescribed for diarrhea-predominant IBS while all others are used for constipation dominant IBS.

Alosetron is a 5HT-3 receptor antagonist. 5HT-3 receptors enhance the sensitivity of afferent neurons projecting from the gut. Alosetron reduces the perception of painful visceral stimulation in IBS. It also induces rectal relaxation, increases rectal compliance, and delays transit from the colon. 

Lubiprostone (option A) is a chloride channel activator. It promotes the secretion of water and chloride into the bowel and improves bowel movements. It is effective in the treatment of constipation predominant IBS.

Linaclotide (option C) is a minimally absorbed 14-aminoacid peptide guanylate cyclase-C (GC-C) agonist. They bind and activate GC-C on the luminal surface of the intestinal epithelium. This triggers the secretion of fluid, sodium, and bicarbonate into the lumen.

Psyllium husk (option D) is fiber supplementation that helps to improve the stool pattern and abdominal pain in constipation dominant IBS. They tend to produce less bloating and rectal distension. 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterized by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. Diagnosis is based on ROME IV criteria. 

IBS can be presented in any age group. However, most of the patients have their symptoms before 45 years of age. They are predominantly present in females. 

Alteration in bowel habits is the consistent clinical feature in IBS. Alternating constipation and diarrhea with one of these symptoms predominating are the most common pattern seen in IBS. 

Patients with constipation-predominating IBS can have weeks or months of constipation interrupted with brief periods of diarrhea. 

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: Your friend volunteers to be a healthy subject in a research project studying the ventilation-perfusion relationships in the lung. The ventilation and perfusion were measured in different regions of his lung when he was lying in the supine position. Arrange the zones of the lung in ascending order of ventilation-perfusion ratio.
questions.solution:
In the supine position, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q) in a healthy subject does not change from the apex to the base of the lungs. Hence the order of zones in the supine position would be: Zone 1= Zone 2 = Zone 3.

V/Q ratio is the ratio of alveolar ventilation (V) to pulmonary blood flow (Q) for the lungs at rest. The average value of the V/Q ratio throughout the lungs is 0.8. Normally, in the upright position, the V/Q ratio in the normal lungs markedly undergoes changes from the apex to the base due to the effect of gravity as shown below - 

At the base of the lung: Both ventilation and perfusion increase since the flow is towards gravity. Increased ventilation is due to the less negative intrapleural pressure compared to the apex, thereby making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference less at the base. Thus, due to this low-pressure difference, the lung is less expanded compared to the apex. This makes the ventilation per unit volume rise during the lung expansion relatively higher. 

The alveolar pressure also decreases, thus reducing the compression of the vessels and increasing the pulmonary blood flow at the base. An increase in perfusion is more than an increase in ventilation, i.e., denominator increases. Hence, the ratio decreases (0.6).

At the apex (against gravity): Both ventilation and perfusion decrease since the flow is against gravity. The reason for decreased ventilation is that intrapleural pressure is more negative thus making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference increase at the apex. The capillary pressure at the apex is almost equal to atmospheric pressure, so the vessels collapse. Thus the blood flow is decreased at the apex. The decrease in perfusion is higher than the decrease in ventilation, i.e., numerator decreases. Hence, the ratio increases (3.2).

In the supine position, all three zones are at the same horizontal plane. As there is no effect of gravity, and there is no variation in ventilation or perfusion. Hence V/Q ratio remains equal in all three zones.

Related Pearl: Zones of Pulmonary Blood Flow

Zone 1

Zero perfusion

  • Does not exist in normal lungs.
  • Occurs when the Pulmonary arterial pressure becomes less than alveolar air pressure.
  • Pulmonary capillaries become collapsed.

Zone 2

Intermittent blood flow

  • This occurs during systole when the pulmonary arterial pressure raises more than alveolar air pressure.
  • In normal lungs, this zone occurs from apex to hilum of the lungs.

Zone 3

Continuous blood flow

  • Here pulmonary arterial pressure is greater than alveolar air pressure during the entire cardiac cycle.
  • In normal lungs, this zone occurs from the middle zone of lungs to base.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with rectal bleeding, a change in bowel habits, and tenesmus for 6 months. Examination reveals a mass in the rectum approximately 4 cm from the anal verge extending to the anal sphincters, and biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma. What surgical intervention is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
The surgical intervention most appropriate for a case of rectal adenocarcinoma 4cm from the anal verge is abdominoperineal resection(APR).

APR is the complete excision of the entire rectum, anal canal, and anus with the construction of a permanent colostomy from the descending or sigmoid colon. It is recommended for patients with operable low rectal carcinomas, where the tumor is located within 5cm of the anal verge. Low anterior resection (LAR) is the preferred surgery in rectal carcinoma which is located at least 5 - 5.5 cm away from the anal verge. 

Hartman's operation is indicated in elderly and frail patients who have poor anal sphincter function or postoperative incontinence. In this surgery, colorectal excision is done along with the closure of the rectal stump and permanent proximal colostomy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought for a general check-up. The child is being examined as shown below in the image. Which of the following statements is false regarding this anthropometric measurement?

choices.text: This parameter can be measured in the subscapular region also
Triceps skinfold thickness <6mm indicates severe malnutrition
Skinfold thickness is an age-dependent parameter

questions.solution:
Skinfold thickness is an age-independent parameter.

Skinfold thickness

    • Age-independent parameter.
    • Triceps skinfold thickness is measured with the help of Harpenden caliper.
      • Normal: 10 mm
      • Severe malnutrition: < 6 mm

The assessment of skinfold thickness measures the amount of subcutaneous fat. Measurement of skinfold thickness is done as it is easily accessible. It is a rapid and non-invasive method for assessing body fat. The callipers used for this purpose is called Harpenden skin calliper. 

Measurements are taken from the following four sites :

  1. Mid-triceps region
  2. Biceps region
  3. Subscapular region
  4. Suprailiac region

The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient with diabetic ketoacidosis was admitted to the ICU. He developed fever, and breathlessness, and SPO2 has been reduced to 85%. Chest X-ray shows lobar pneumonia. A serum galactomannan assay was positive. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described, with the development of pneumonia in an immunocompromised patient, and a positive serum galactomannan assay suggests a fungal infection due to Aspergillus species.

Invasive aspergillosis is an opportunistic mycosis seen in immunocompromised patients, primarily caused by Aspergillus fumigatus, A. niger, and A. flavus. This condition typically begins as pneumonia and can later disseminate to other organs.

Other conditions caused by Aspergillus species include:

  1. Aspergilloma, a fungal ball that grows within the lung and is confined to an existing lung cavity, such as those formed by old tuberculosis
  2. Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, which leads to hypersensitivity reactions (Type I in atopic individuals and Type III reactions).
  3. Superficial infections of the external ear (otomycosis), eye (keratitis), and nasal sinuses.

Laboratory diagnosis of Aspergillus species includes serum galactomannan assay, wet mount preparations in exudates, isolation by culture using Sabouraud dextrose agar, and microscopic examination of isolated colonies. Detection of galactomannan (a cell wall component of aspergillus) in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid is a marker for invasive aspergillosis in adults and children. Serological tests include ELISA and PCR.

The image below shows fungal hyphae of Aspergillus species which are narrow, septate, and have branching at acute angles.

Other options:

Option A: Cryptococcus is an opportunistic infection and capsulated true yeast. C. neoformans and C. gattii are two species that cause infection in humans. The primary pulmonary infection is mostly minor like cough, cold and sputum production but in immunocompromised it may cause CNS infections subacute and chronic meningitis.

Option B: North American Blastomycosis is a chronic infection caused by a dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. It is characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions in the lungs and skin and is caused by inhalation of spores from contaminated soil.

 Option C: Histoplasmosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by dimorphic fungi Histoplasma capsulatum. It is acquired by inhalation, a disease of the reticuloendothelial system and causes a disease similar to tuberculosis presenting as fever, chills, headache, dry cough, dyspnea and chest pain. It is stained by Gomori methanamine silver stain.

questions.text: An asthma patient comes to the clinic because she has been experiencing daily daytime exacerbations which limit her activity. She also complains of exacerbations of asthma during most nights of the week. Her regular medications include a formoterol inhaler and a daily medium dose of inhaled corticosteroid (ICS), however she often forgets to take it. Which of the following medications is not preferred in her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of daily daytime exacerbations with activity restriction and daily nighttime exacerbations is suggestive of severe persistent asthma or uncontrolled asthma. Low-dose ICS with salbutamol is not preferred as reliever therapy in severe persistent asthma in non-adherent patients.

As per Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) guidelines, formoterol + low-dose ICS is the preferred reliever in all cases of asthma irrespective of the severity of the disease. Short-acting β2 agonist is an alternative reliever that can be used to manage all cases of asthma, provided that patient adherence to daily therapy can be assured.

Asthma is categorized as intermittent if the patient has daytime symptoms up to 2 times per week, and nighttime awakenings due to symptoms up to 2 times per month. If the symptoms are more severe than this, then the patient's asthma is categorized to be persistent. Persistent asthma is further divided into the following based on the severity of the symptoms:

Category Mild persistent Moderate persistent Severe persistent
Daytime symptoms More than 2 times per week but less than daily Daily Present throughout the day along with severe restriction of daily activities
Nighttime awakenings 3-4 times a month but not every week Once per week Almost every night
Treatment Low dose ICS + formoterol as needed Low dose ICS + formoterol daily Medium to high dose ICS + formoterol/LABA daily + add-on drugs

Inhaled corticosteroids are the backbone of asthma management as they alleviate the symptoms of inflammation and improve lung function. However, there is an increased mortality risk with only corticosteroids and better patient outcomes are seen when a beta agonist is added. 

Add-on drugs for severe or uncontrolled asthma:

  • Anticholinergics: Ipratropium bromide, Tiotropium bromide
  • Corticosteroids (Systemic): Prednisolone, Hydrocortisone
  • anti-IgE - Omalizumab
  • anti-IL5 - Mepolizumab, Reslizumab
  • anti-IL4 receptor - Dupilumab

Important Update:

According to GINA 2019, Short-acting beta 2 agonists (SABA) have no role in treating acute exacerbations. Even though SABA provides short-term relief of symptoms, there is strong evidence that SABA-only treatment increases the risk of exacerbations. 

GINA now recommends symptom-driven (in mild asthma), a daily dose of ICS containing treatment to reduce the risk of serious exacerbations. This is said to be the most important change in asthma management in 30 years.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. During the examination, the patient opened his eyes when asked and responded with inappropriate words. He was able to localise his pain and one of his pupils was not reactive to the light. What is his GCS-pupil score?
questions.solution:
The GCS-pupil score of the above-mentioned patient is 10.

The GCS-pupil score is calculated as the difference between GCS and the pupil reactivity score (PRS). Here, the score according to the GCS is 11 and calculated as:

Eye opening to verbal command : 3
Verbal response: inappropriate words : 3
Motor response: localises to pain : 5

The pupil reactivity score (PRS) ranges from 0 to 2, where if only one pupil reacts to light, the score is taken as 1. Thereby, the GCS-pupil score becomes : 

GCS - PRS = 11 -1 = 10.

The Glasgow coma scale-pupil score is the incorporation of pupillary function into the GCS. The changes in pupil reactivity can influence the overall assessment of neurological status provided by the GCS. Pupil reactivity indicates the function of the brainstem, which controls basic vital functions such as breathing and heart rate.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of peripartum cardiomyopathy following a previous pregnancy presents for preconception counseling. She still has complaints of shortness of breath on mild exertion which is only relieved by rest. What would be the best advice for her regarding pregnancy?

choices.text: Pregnancy is safe with lifestyle modifications
Pregnancy is safe with close monitoring and medical management
Pregnancy is safe if her LVEF is > 30%

questions.solution:
Given the history of peripartum cardiomyopathy and ongoing symptoms of shortness of breath (SOB) on mild exertion, the best advice for her would be that pregnancy is contraindicated due to the significant risks to her health, based on both the WHO classification and her NYHA Class III symptoms.

Pregnancy is contraindicated in this patient because:

  • The history of peripartum cardiomyopathy with residual LV dysfunction (SOB on mild exertion) lies in the WHO risk class 4 category.
  • Shortness of breath on mild exertion, which gets relieved on taking rest, is a symptom of NYHA grade III heart failure, which again lies in the WHO risk class 4 category.

WHO Classification of Maternal Cardiovascular Risk:

WHO Class 4: This classification indicates that pregnancy poses a very high risk of maternal mortality or severe morbidity. Women in this class are typically advised against becoming pregnant.

It includes:

  1. Pulmonary arterial hypertension of any cause  
  2. Severe systemic ventricular dysfunction (LVEF <30%, NYHA III-IV) 
  3. Previous peripartum cardiomyopathy with any residual impairment of left ventricular function
  4. Severe symptomatic mitral or aortic stenosis 
  5. Marfan syndrome with aorta dilated >45 mm 
  6. Aortic dilation >50 mm in aortic disease associated with bicuspid aortic valve 
  7. Native severe Coarctation

NYHA Functional Classification of Cardiovascular disability:

Class I - Patients with cardiac disease but without resulting limitations of physical activity.

Class II - Patients with cardiac disease resulting in slight limitation of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea, or anginal pain.

Class III - Patients with cardiac disease resulting in marked limitation of physical activity. Less-than-ordinary physical activity and mild exertion cause fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea, or anginal pain.

Class IV - Patients with cardiac disease resulting in inability to carry on any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms of cardiac insufficiency or of anginal syndrome may be present even at rest.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with HIV infection is started on antiretroviral therapy. After a few weeks of treatment, the patient develops severe abdominal pain radiating to the back, nausea, and elevated serum lipase levels. Which of the following antiretroviral drugs could be the potential cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards pancreatitis which is a characteristic adverse effect of didanosine.

Didanosine (ddl) is an anti-retroviral drug belonging to the class of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). It is a synthetic analog of deoxyadenosine. The major clinical toxicities associated with didanosine therapy are peripheral distal sensory neuropathy and dose-dependent pancreatitis. Therefore, co-administration with drugs or conditions that increase the risk of either has to be avoided.

Other reported adverse effects include diarrhea, hepatitis, esophageal ulceration, cardiomyopathy, central nervous system toxicity (headache, irritability, insomnia), and hypertriglyceridemia.

Lamivudine and Tenofovir also belong to the class of NRTI while Nevirapine belong to the class of non nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). (option A, B and D)

Lamivudine can cause nausea, headache, fatigue, anemia, neutropenia, and lactic acidosis. Tenofovir can cause renal toxicity and a decrease in bone mineral density. Its safety profile is unknown in age less than 10 years and weights less than 30 kg. The key side effect of Nevirapine is hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: A person has been bitten by the following snake. Which of the following options describe the symptoms seen classically in this snake bite?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows common krait, which is neurotoxic and shows classical symptoms such as muscle paralysis.

The neurotoxicity symptoms that would be seen in the patient include: 

  • headache
  • blurred vision
  • perioral paraesthesia
  • hyperacusis
  • dizziness
  • vertigo
  • gooseflesh
  • vomiting
  • hypersalivation

Neurotoxicity effects are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase or they may wear off spontaneously in about a week.

Other options:

Option A: Anaphylaxis is seen in poisoning due to stiletto snakes. Other symptoms include pain, swelling, blisters and local lymph node enlargements.

Option B: Systemic bleeding such as intravascular hemolysis, ecchymosis and incoagulable blood is seen in bites due to back fanged snakes.

Option C: Myoglobinuria is seen in poisoning due to sea snakes.

questions.text: An hour after the blood transfusion, the patient develops a fever with chills and flank pain. Tachycardia and hypotension are noted on examination. The direct Coombs test is positive. Which of the following mediates this reaction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) following blood transfusion. It occurs most often due to ABO incompatibility and is mediated by IgM antibodies.
 
Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) occurs within 24 hours of transfusion and is usually caused by preformed IgM antibodies against donor red cells that fix complement. The patient presents with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, fever, flank pain, and in severe cases, hemoglobinuria, renal failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
 
It is caused by ABO incompatibility which is a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction. They test positive for the direct Coomb's test. In light of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, the transfusion is to be stopped immediately.

Allergic or urticarial reactions during transfusions are mediated by IgE antibodies.

A delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction which occurs after 24 hours (within 2 weeks) of transfusion is a reaction mediated by IgG antibodies.

questions.text: What services are typically provided at a NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) site within the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) at district level ?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the service provided at the NAAT site under NTEP is to diagnose rifampicin-resistant tuberculosis.

The services provided at NAAT site includes : 

  • Diagnose tuberculosis and rifampicin resistant tuberculosis at district and subdistrict levels
  • Maintain records and NIKSHAY
  • Reflex transportation of the second sample to concerned culture and drug susceptibility testing(C&DST) lab for fluoroquinolone-line probe assay (FL-LPA).

Other options

Option A: Distribution of free tuberculosis medication is done at designated Directly Observed Treatment, Short-Course (DOTS) centres. These centres dispense free anti-TB drugs to patients diagnosed with TB, ensuring access to treatment for all individuals regardless of their socio-economic status. 

Option B: Drug resistance surveillance and training are done at the National Reference Laboratories (NRLs) at central level. These are also responsible for external quality assurance of the lab network and research.

Option C: Maintaining records in Nikshay Aushadh is done at the state drug store. These are also responsible for managing supply chain for diagnostics and drugs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with urethral discharge and pain while passing urine. He also has malaise and fever. Which of the following constitutes the STD kit used for his treatment?

choices.text: Azithromycin 1 gm OD Stat + Cefixime 400 mg OD Stat
Secnidazole 2 gm OD Stat + Fluconazole 150 mg OD Stat
Benzathine penicillin (2.4 MU) single dose + Azithromycin 1 gm single dose

questions.solution:
In the syndromic management of STDs, the grey kit is used to manage urethral discharge. This kit contains Azithromycin 1 gm OD Stat + Cefixime 400 mg OD Stat.

The grey kit is effective for the treatment of infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. It is used in men for urethral discharge and scrotal swelling requires all recent partners to be treated. But, when used for cervical discharge in women, only symptomatic male partners need to be treated.

Urethritis is an inflammation of the urethral mucosa, commonly caused by sexually transmitted pathogens such as Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and Mycoplasma genitalium. Often asymptomatic, patients may experience urethral discharge, dysuria, and itching of the urinary meatus. Gonococcal urethritis is caused by N. gonorrhoeae, while nongonococcal urethritis is most frequently due to C. trachomatis. Other causes of non-chlamydial nongonococcal urethritis include Mycoplasma genitalium and Trichomonas vaginalis. Clinical features include dysuria, burning or itching of the urethral meatus, and various types of urethral discharge.  Diagnosis is best confirmed by urethral smear microscopy and culture.

Other options (for syndromic management of STDs)

Option B: Tab. Secnidazole 2 g OD Stat + Cap. Fluconazole 150 mg OD Stat (Kit 2/Green) is used in vaginal discharge

Option C: Tab. Acyclovir 400 mg TDS for 7 days (Kit 5/Red) is used for herpetic genital ulcers

Option D: Inj. Benzathine penicillin (2.4 MU) - 1 vial + Tab. Azithromycin (1 gm) - Single dose (Kit 3/White) is used for non-herpetic genital ulcers

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman who has had unilateral headache and jaw pain for 2 weeks, now presents with blurry vision. She also has a history of stiffness and pain in her shoulders and hips. With a high suspicion of giant cell arteritis, you order a panel of investigations. Which of the following laboratory results should prompt you to consider a different vasculitis as your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of headache, jaw claudication, visual changes, and polymyalgia rheumatica in an older woman suggests a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis/ temporal arteritis. Elevated serum creatinine levels are not expected to be seen in giant cell arteritis/ temporal arteritis and should prompt further evaluation of other vasculitides such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis due to the involvement of small renal arteries. GCA being a large vessel arteritis, rarely causes derangements of renal function. 

Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have signs of superficial temporal artery inflammation, including erythema, pain on palpation, nodularity, thickening, or reduced pulsation on the affected side. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. 

GCA is very commonly associated with polymyalgia rheumatica, which is characterized by morning stiffness and pain around the shoulders and hip. It is also associated with mononeuritis multiplex, which is characterized by peripheral neuropathy in two or more separate nerve areas.

A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness.

Elevated ESR and anemia, usually normochromic or slightly hypochromic are characteristic laboratory findings. Raised liver enzymes, especially alkaline phosphatase are common. Levels of IgG and complement may be raised. However, serum creatinine levels are not elevated.

Histopathology of giant cell arteritis shows panarteritis with infiltration of inflammatory mononuclear cells with giant cell formation. Intimal thickening and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina are also seen.

The image below shows internal elastic lamina fragmentation (black arrow) and giant cells (yellow arrow) in a cerebral artery. 

The mainstay of treatment in GCA is steroids. Prednisolone 40-60 mg is given for one month followed by tapering doses. The duration of treatment is approximately 2 years or more. Methylprednisolone 1000 mg for 3 days should be given to patients presenting with visual symptoms.

Aspirin reduces the occurrence of visual loss and can be given in addition to steroids. Newer drugs used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis are tocilizumab (anti-IL-6 receptor) and abatacept (CTLA4-Ig). Both these drugs are used adjunctively to steroid therapy.

questions.text: A patient with sudden sensorineural hearing loss is scheduled for an intra-auricular methylprednisolone injection. Which part of the inner ear will the drug reach first?
questions.solution:
Sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SSHL) can be treated by injecting steroids like methylprednisolone into the inner ear. The preferred site of administration is through the round window which leads to the scala tympani. Thus the scala tympani is the first part of the inner ear to receive the drug.

Viral and autoimmune etiologies are usually suspected in case of SSHL and intra-auricular corticosteroids are preferred because of their anti-inflammatory properties.

Other clinical uses of round window and hence scala tympani : 

  • Used also for chemical labyrinthectomy: the administration of gentamicin in case of Meniere’s disease
  • Used for passing the electrodes in case of cochlear implantation

The middle ear is connected to the inner ear via two windows : oval and round windows. Scala vestibuli accessed via the oval window is not preferred because there is a potential risk of injuring the footplate of stapes and also the utricle and saccule may get stimulated, leading to vertigo.

questions.text: A woman is being evaluated for a neck lump that moves with swallowing. Her TSH is low and a neck USG shows a 2x2 cm hypoechoic nodule with irregular margins in the right lobe of the thyroid. Her radioisotope scan is shown below.  What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Radioisotope study shows cold nodule and high-risk features on USG (hypoechoic, irregular margins). The next best step would be a fine needle aspiration.

The workup of thyroid nodules begins with assessing thyroid function through a serum TSH test and a neck ultrasound. If TSH is low, further evaluation with nuclear medicine scintigraphy is warranted to investigate identify "hot" or "cold" nodules, with cold nodules often requiring further assessment due to a higher risk of malignancy. Most thyroid nodules are benign, such as colloid nodules or follicular adenomas, but malignancies like papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) and others can occur. Neck ultrasound is the key imaging study, providing high-resolution images and aiding in fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy of suspicious nodules and lymph nodes. For hyperthyroid patients with nodules, both nuclear medicine thyroid scintigraphy and ultrasound are recommended.

The image below shows a flowchart that details the work-up of a thyroid nodule:

Intermediate Suspicion (10%-20%)

Low Suspicion (5%-10%)

Isoechoic solid nodule with regular margins.

Partially cystic nodule with eccentric solid areas.

Spongiform appearance.

Partially cystic nodule with no suspicious features.

Other options:

Option A: Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies are useful in evaluating the etiology of hypothyroidism (elevated TSH) as they are positive in autoimmune (ex. Hashimoto) thyroiditis. It is not used routinely to evaluate hyperthyroidism.

Option C: Radio-iodine ablation is not indicated as this patient requires further diagnostic work-up first.

Option D: Serum thyroglobulin (Tg) can be elevated in patients with differentiated thyroid cancer (DTC) but is not useful for routine measurements, and has low diagnostic utility before a total thyroidectomy. However, postoperative serum Tg measurement after total thyroidectomy for DTC remains one of the most sensitive cancer biomarkers.

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:

    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of pain in the leg, lethargy, and recurrent fevers. Detailed evaluation reveals TdT-positive lymphoblasts in bone marrow aspirate. Which of the following is a good prognostic marker of the above condition?

TdT - terminal deoxy- nucleotidyl transferase
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette points towards acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and translocation (12;21) is a good prognostic marker of ALL. 

Acute onset of symptoms of bone marrow suppression such as lethargy, recurrent fever due to infections, and easy bruising in a young male child is suggestive of the diagnosis as ALL. This is supported by the presence of TdT-positive lymphoblasts on bone marrow aspiration.

Favorable prognostic markers of ALL-

  • Age of 2 to 10 years 
  • Low WBC counts. 
  • Hyperdiploidy (> 50 chromosomes )
  • Trisomy 4,7 and 10
  • Translocation (12;21)

Unfavorable prognostic markers of ALL-

  • Age under 2 years, age more than 10 years
  • Peripheral blasts cells >100,000 (Option D)
  • Translocation (9;22) (Option A)
  • Hypodiploidy <44 chromosomes (Option B)
  • Translocation (17;19).

ALL is the most common cancer of children. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is neoplasms of immature B or T cells (lymphoblasts). Two distinct types of ALLs are :

B-ALL T-ALL
More common Less common
Manifest in childhood Manifest in adolescent males
Peak incidence at around 3 years Peak incidence in adolescence
May present as skin or bone manifestations. Present as thymic neoplasms

Mutations in genes such as PAX5, TCF3, ETV6, and RUNX1

 Mutations in NOTCH-1 common
Positive for CD-19, PAX-5, and CD10 Positive for CD1, CD2, CD5, and CD7

Both immature B and T cells stain positive for terminal deoxy- nucleotidyl transferase (TdT). The most common molecular pathology behind ALL is hyperdiploidy (>50 chromosomes). The chromosomal abnormalities present in ALL block the functions of transcription factors that are needed for normal B and T cell development.

Clinical features:

  • Acute in onset within days to weeks
  • Symptoms due to bone marrow depression such as lethargy and fatigue due to anemia, recurrent infections due to leukopenia, and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia.
  • Mass effects such as bone pain, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement.
  • Central nervous system manifestations such as headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies resulting from the meningeal spread.

Examination of bone marrow aspirates shows, a hypercellular bone marrow packed with lymphoblasts. In both B-ALL and T-ALL, the tumor cells have scant basophilic cytoplasm and nuclei somewhat larger than those of small lymphocytes. These cells are also myeloperoxidase-negative and often contain periodic acid–Schiff– positive cytoplasmic material.

The mainstay of treatment is multiagent chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with hypertension. After initial workup and investigations, he is started on captopril. Which of the following changes in renal function will reduce the blood pressure in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule

questions.solution:
Among the given options, decreased sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule is one of the changes seen due to captopril.

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor. It decreases the levels of angiotensin II thereby decreasing all its physiological effects leading to:

  • Vasodilatation
  • Decreased salt and water reabsorption in the proximal tubules
  • Decreased stimulation of aldosterone which reduces sodium reabsorption in the distal tubules
  • Increased renin secretion due to reduced negative feedback.

Other options:

Option B: Angiotensin II receptors are blocked by ARBs like losartan.

Option C: ACE inhibitors increase renin secretion because the decrease in the levels of angiotensin II reduces the negative feedback on renin release.

Option D: Decreased angiotensin II improves renal blood flow.

questions.text: In a patient with pancreatitis, what would be the most likely findings seen on ascitic tap?

choices.text: Serum albumin = 5 g/dL; Ascitic fluid albumin = 2 g/dL
Serum albumin = 4 g/dL; Ascitic fluid albumin = 2 g/dL
Serum albumin = 4 g/dL; Ascitic fluid albumin = 2.5 g/dL
Serum albumin = 4 g/dL; Ascitic fluid albumin = 3 g/dL:

questions.solution:
In patients with pancreatic ascites, the serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is < 1.1 g/dl which corresponds to option D (SAAG = 4 - 3 = 1).

The SAAG is calculated by subtracting the ascitic fluid value of albumin from the serum value. SAAG < 1.1 g/dl indicates that the etiology of ascites is not due to portal hypertension, seen in pancreatic ascites due to the proteinaceous ascitic fluid.

The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is the most reliable method to differentiate causes of ascites due to portal hypertension from those not due to portal hypertension.

For high-SAAG ascites, the ascitic protein level provides additional information. A protein level of ≥2.5 g/dL suggests normal hepatic sinusoids, while <2.5 g/dL indicates damaged and scarred sinusoids.

Additional tests for specific clinical situations:

  • ascitic glucose and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels for suspected secondary peritonitis
  • cytology for peritoneal carcinomatosis
  • ascitic fluid lymphocytosis and elevated ascitic adenosine deaminase for tuberculous peritonitis
  • Pro-brain-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels to identify heart failure. 

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: A lady with no previous history of chickenpox in childhood develops chickenpox 2 days before delivery. She had an uncomplicated full-term vaginal delivery of a healthy baby. Which of the following is not true about her situation?

choices.text: Baby is at high risk of developing a disseminated disease
Baby should receive varicella zoster immunoglobulin
Give prophylactic acyclovir to the baby

questions.solution:
Prophylactic acyclovir is not recommended for the baby. The neonate should be treated with acyclovir only when signs of neonatal infection develop despite administering varicella zoster immunoglobulin.

The severity of neonatal infection is inversely related to the concentration of maternal antibodies present in the newborn circulation. The mother starts producing and transferring antibodies approximately five days after the onset of her disease. Thus babies born 5 days or more from the beginning of maternal disease will be protected.

Varicella-zoster IG is recommended for neonates whose mothers develop VZV rash from five days before delivery up to two days after delivery. Neonates born before or after this time probably do not need passive immunization because they are not at risk of severe neonatal chickenpox.

Antiviral treatment should be started in a neonate exposed to varicella when there is a disseminated disease( pneumonia, encephalitis, thrombocytopenia and severe hepatitis)

Varicella in pregnant women :

The contraction of the virus by a pregnant woman increases the risk of the fetus to congenital varicella syndrome. This is seen in mothers who are affected during the first 20 weeks of gestation. Affected babies present with the following :

  • Fetal wastage
  • Cutaneous scars
  • Atrophied limbs
  • Microcephaly
  • Low birth weight
  • Cataract
  • Microphthalmia
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Deafness
  • Cerebral-cortical atrophy

Prevention:

  • Varicella-Zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is given as post-exposure prophylaxis within 72 hours of exposure and has been recommended for prevention of chickenpox in exposed susceptible individuals, particularly in immunosuppressed persons such as:
    • Persons receiving immunosuppressive therapy
    • Persons with congenital cellular immunodeficiency
    • Persons with acquired immunodeficiency including HIV/AIDS
    • Exposed pregnant women
    • Newborns
    • Premature infants of low birth weight
  • Live attenuated vaccine is administered to children who have not had chickenpox between the age of 12 to 18 months.

questions.text: You are an intern observing a surgery where the stones from the bile duct are removed. The instrument given below is used. Name the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is Desjardins choledocholithotomy forceps. It is used for the removal of stones from the common bile duct.

This is a long and slender instrument. The shaft is curved and there is a fenestra at the tip. It does not have a lock hence, accidental damage to CBD mucosa or crushing of the CBD stone is avoided.

Other options: 

Option A: Lane tissue-holding forceps have a stout and thick distal blade, with an oval fenestra in each blade. It has a lock in the proximal part. It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and lymph nodes.

Option B: Kocher forceps have an opposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades. It is used to hold pedicles, tough structures, and cut ends of muscles. It is also used for holding ribs during rib dissection and for holding the resected bowel.

Option D: Lister sinus forceps are used for draining pus from the abscess cavity in Hilton's method. Initially used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity. It has a long straight blade with serrations in the tip.

questions.text: An AIDS patient presents with gradually progressive loss of vision. He had pain in his eyes since one week. On fundus examination, retinal necrosis and vitreoretinal abscesses are seen in a ‘string of pearl’ pattern. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gradual progressive vision loss, eye pain, retinal necrosis, and string-of-pearl appearance on fundoscopy in an immunocompromised patient is diagnostic of candida ophthalmitis. 

Candida albicans is an opportunistic fungus. It infects patients with AIDS and malignancies or receiving long-term antibiotics, steroids, and cytotoxic drugs. Disseminated candida infection in the eyes presents as anterior uveitis, multifocal chorioretinitis or candida endophthalmitis. 

Candida endophthalmitis is an insidious infection. Patients present with gradual vision loss, floaters, subacute onset of pain, redness, or ocular discomfort. On examination, eyelid edema, conjunctival and circumcorneal congestion, anterior chamber inflammation, and vitreous exudates are seen. 

Fundus examination classically reveals areas of retinal necrosis. Vitreoretinal abscesses are present, which appear as puffball or cotton ball colonies joined by exudative strands. This gives the classic 'string-of-pearl' appearance. 

 

Treatment includes topical cycloplegics, topical and systemic antifungals like ketoconazole or amphotericin-B. Pars plana vitrectomy might be required. 

Other options: 

Option A - Anterior uveitis, or iridocyclitis, is inflammation of the iris and ciliary body. Examination findings include circumcorneal congestion, keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, hypopyon, and exudates in the anterior vitreous. 

Option C - Tubercular uveitis is a chronic granulomatous inflammation. It may be anterior or posterior. Posterior uveitis shows the presence of multiple miliary tubercles, multifocal choroiditis and choroidal granulomas. 

Option D - Cytomegalovirus retinitis occurs in immunocompromised patients. Hemorrhagic retinitis with yellow white exudates, perivascular exudates and retinal hemorrhages leading to 'pizza pie' appearance are characteristic.

questions.text: You are resuscitating a preterm neonate whose birth weight is 1.5 kg and who did not cry at birth. Despite 1 minute of effective PPV, the heart rate is less than 60. You decide to do intubation and start chest compression. What is the size of the endotracheal tube and blade to be used for resuscitation?
questions.solution:
A 3mm endotracheal tube and laryngoscopy blade of size 0 to visualise the glottic region are used to intubate a preterm infant for resuscitation.

Endotracheal intubation is indicated if the heart rate is less than 100 beats per minute despite 30 seconds of effective PPV. Chest compressions are to be initiated if the heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute following endotracheal intubation. A positive breath should follow every third chest compression. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3:1 (90 compressions: 30 breaths). 

For endotracheal intubation, Laryngoscopes with blades and endotracheal tubes are needed. For a term baby, a scope with a blade size of 1 is used and for a preterm baby, a blade with a size of 0 is used.

Endotracheal tubes are of two types, cuffed and uncuffed tubes. For newborn babies, uncuffed tubes are preferred because the cuffed tubes might cause pressure-induced tracheal necrosis.  

Note:

Size of ET tube with respect to infant weight

Weight <1000g - 2.5mm
Weight 1000-2000g - 3mm
Weight >2000g - 3.5mm

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant with abdominal distension, fever, and jaundice was brought to the pediatric outpatient department. Urine examination revealed a boiled cabbage odor. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the boiled cabbage odor on urine examination is hepatorenal tyrosinemia. 

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

  • Type 1 tyrosinemia also known as hepatorenal tyrosinemia is an autosomal recessive condition. The defective enzyme is fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase. Clinical features are liver failure, hypoglycemia, boiled cabbage odor in the urine, and mental retardation. 
  • Type 2 is known as oculocutaneous tyrosinemia or Richner-Hanhart syndrome. The defective enzyme is tyrosine transaminase. Clinical features are palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions, photophobia, and mental retardation.
  • Type 3 is known as neonatal tyrosinemia. It is due to the deficiency of 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase. Clinical features include normal liver function, developmental delay, seizures, and intermittent ataxia.

Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal dominant condition. It is due to the dysfunction of 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate oxidase. Clinical features are failure to thrive and metabolic acidosis in infancy.

Note: Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: Increased baroreceptor discharge leads to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Increased baroreceptor discharge leads to the production of vasodilation, venodilation, bradycardia, and hypotension not hypertension.

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels. They are stimulated by the stretching of the walls of the blood vessels when there is an increased volume or blood pressure in the vessel. They are important in the immediate management of blood pressure. They are of two types - carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions) and cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions). 

An increase in blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors. These signals are transmitted through small Hering’s nerves to the glossopharyngeal nerves and then to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. These signals release glutamate and activate the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM). This in turn inhibits the rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) considered the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart.

Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic center. The stimulation of the vagus results in a slowing of impulse generation in the SA node and a slowing of conduction velocity in the AV node. 

These neural changes produce vasodilation, venodilation, hypotension, bradycardia, and a decrease in cardiac output.
